With the encouragement of Histiaeus (his father-in-law and former tyrant of Miletus), Aristagoras induces the Ionian cities of Asia Minor to revolt against Persia, thus instigating the Ionian Revolt and beginning the Greco-Persian Wars between Greece and Persia. The pro-Persian tyrant of Mytilene is stoned to death.
Aristagoras seeks help with the revolt against the Persians from Cleomenes I, king of Sparta, but the Spartans are unwilling to respond.
First large pit house villages at Chaco Canyon are founded (approximate date).
Tikal is founded (approximate date).

Possible date for the Battle of Mons Badonicus: Romano-British and Celts defeat an Anglo-Saxon army, that may have been led by the bretwalda Aelle of Sussex or possibly Cerdic of Wessex (approximate date; suggested dates range from  to ). This battle may have influenced the legend of King Arthur.

Emperor Anastasius I concludes treaties with a number of nomad tribes in northern Arabia. In return for tribute to the Byzantine Empire and military defense of these eastern territories, such tribes are permitted to settle and farm agricultural lands in Arabia (approximate date).
Approximate year of the founding of the Kingdom of Essex.
Yayoi period starts in Ancient Japan (approximate date).
Refugees from Teos resettle Abdera.
Hanno the Navigator's naval exploration of the western coast of Africa could have reached as far south as Gabon.
The oldest known Zapotec writing appears (approximate date).
Early Pandyan Kingdom was ruled by the Pandyas during the second Sangam period.
The Sushruta Samhita medical book becomes a classic of medicine in India. The book contains descriptions of surgery, illnesses, medicinal plants, and a detailed study on anatomy (approximate date).
Muryeong becomes king of Baekje (one of the Three Kingdoms of Korea). During his reign, the kingdom remains allied with Silla and expands its relationships with China and Japan.
June  – Ahkal Moʼ Nahb I becomes the new ruler of the Mayan city-state of Palenque (in what is now the state of Chiapas in southern Mexico), and reigns until his death in .
Dong Hun Hou is killed during a siege of the capital Jiankang. He is succeeded by his  brother Qi He Di, who becomes emperor of Southern Qi (China).

Burgundian Civil War: King Gundobad breaks his promise of tribute and regains his military power. He besieges his brother Godegisel at the city of Vienne (Burgundy), and murders him in an Arian church along with the bishop.

The Nanhua Temple, located southeast of Shaoguan, is founded by the Indian monk Zhiyao Sanzang. The temple covers an area of . hectares ( acres) and consists of a set of historical Buddhist buildings.

War with Sassanid Persia: Emperor Anastasius I refuses to pay a share of the cost of defending the Caucasian Gates, through which nomadic tribes have come for raids on Persia and the Byzantine Empire. King Kavadh I invades Armenia and captures Theodosiopolis.
The Chinese Book of Song is finished. The text is one of the Twenty-Four Histories, a traditional collection of historical records during the Southern and Northern Dynasties.

Caesarius becomes bishop of Arles. His episcopal see, near the mouth of the Rhone River and close to Marseille, retains its ancient importance in the social and commercial life of Gaul for forty years.
The Persian philosopher Mazdak declares private property to be the source of all evil.
King Ernakh, third son of Attila the Hun, dies after a -year reign. He is succeeded by his two sons (Utigur and Kutrigur), who share the power with the unified Bulgars.
Mundhir III, king of the Lakhmids (Arab Christians), raids Palaestina Salutaris and Arabia Petraea. He captures a large number of Romans.

War with Sassanid Persia: Emperor Anastasius I sends a Byzantine army (, men) to Armenia, but is defeated. The Romans attempt an unsuccessful siege of the Persian-held city Amida, on the Tigris. King Kavadh I invades Osroene, and lays siege to the city of Edessa (Northern Mesopotamia).
May – Areobindus, Byzantine general (magister militum), is stationed as commander at Dara, with an army of , men to keep watch at the Persian stronghold of Nisibis (modern Turkey).
A major expansion of Copán's ceremonial center, the Acropolis complex, is undertaken by B'alam Nehn (Waterlily Jaguar), the seventh ruler (ajaw) of the southeastern Maya city (approximate date).
Theodoric the Great builds the Basilica of Sant'Apollinare Nuovo, originally dedicated to Christ the Redeemer.
War with Sassanid Persia: Emperor Anastasius I gains the upper hand in Armenia, with the renewed investment of Amida.
King  Kavadh I hands over the fortress-city of Amida, and agrees to an armistice with the Byzantine Empire.
The Ostrogoths sack Belgrade, on the Danube and Sava rivers (modern Serbia).
Emperor Anastasius I agrees to pay his share of the cost of defending the Caucasian Gates, against nomadic invasions from East Asia.
The Colosseum (Amphitheatrum Flavium) in Rome suffers damage from an earthquake, as it did in .
The white Huns (Hephthalites) from the Caucasus invade the Persian Empire.
Anastasius I decides to rebuild the village of Dara (Northern Mesopotamia). He constructs a new strategic fortress to guard the frontier.
Lý Nguyên Khải, Jiaozhou's governor, rebels against the Liang dynasty, but is suppressed by Lý Tắc, a state official,  and subsequently prosecuted.
September  – Council of Agde: The bishops of Visigothic Gaul under the presidency of Caesarius of Arles meet.
Antipope Laurentius is persuaded by Theoderic the Great to resign his claim to the throne of Pope Symmachus, ending a schism in the Catholic Church; Laurentius then fasts until his death.

February  – King Alaric II issues the "Lex Romana Visigothorum" or Breviary of Alaric, an abstract of Roman laws and imperial decrees, compiled by a commission appointed to provide a law code for Alaric's Roman subjects. The "Lex Romana" will be the standard for justice in the Visigothic realm.

November – Emperor Anastasius I accepts a peace agreement with the Sasanian Empire (Persia), based on the status quo. He upgrades the fortifications at Batnae, Edessa and Amida (Northern Mesopotamia).
The Visigoths capture the city of Dertosa in Catalonia. They arrest and execute the Roman usurper Peter, sending his head as a trophy to Saragossa (Spain).
A Mayan altar with the head of the death god is built in Copán, Honduras.
The town of Guilin, China, is renamed Guizhou.
Wooden coffins and wooden tools are used in the burial places of the Alemanni.
Gesalec succeeds his father Alaric II as king of the Visigoths. He establishes his residence at Narbonne and is supported by an alliance with the Ostrogothic king Theodoric the Great.
Hermanafrid, king of the Thuringii, marries Amalaberga. He begins his rule, shared with his brothers Baderic and Bertachar.
Winter – All the rivers in England are frozen for more than two months.

King Clovis I fails in an effort to take the walled city of Carcassonne (Southern Gaul). He establishes Paris (Lutetia) as his capital and gets baptized, making Roman Catholicism the official religion of the Kingdom of the Franks.
Emperor Anastasius I formally recognizes Clovis I of the Salian Franks as ruler of Gaul. He sends a Byzantine fleet of  warships to raid the coasts of Italy.
King Theodoric the Great sends an Ostrogoth army, led by his sword-bearer Theudis, drives the Franks out of Provence, and recovers Septimania (Languedoc) from the Visigoths.
Battle of Netley: King Cerdic of Wessex moves with an Anglo-Saxon army inland, and defeats the British king, Nudd-Lludd (according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle).
Battle of Llongborth (possibly Langport or Portsmouth): King Budic II of Brittany seeks refuge at the court of Aergol Lawhir, in Dyfed (Wales) after the battle.
The Sasanian Persians conquer the independent kingdom of Caucasian Albania, a state converted to Christianity in the  by Armenian missionaries (approximate date).

King Theodoric the Great raises the Frankish siege at Arles; the city is heroically defended by its inhabitants, assisted by the Ostrogothic general Theudis. The Ostrogoths overrun Provence (Southern Gaul), and consolidate their gains in the region.
Theodoric the Great appoints his friend Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius, Roman philosopher, to the rank of consul of the Ostrogothic Kingdom.
Construction is completed on the Second Temple in Jerusalem.
Euphronios completes Death of Sarpedon, a red-figure decoration on a calyx krater. Euxitheos is a potter. It is now at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
Western India becomes the Achaemenid satrapy of Hindush, which included the valley of the Indus River.
Sun Tzu, author of The Art of War, begins serving Helü of Wu as general and military strategist in the Wu army.
Hippias, second son of Pisistratus and tyrant of Athens, is expelled by a popular revolt supported by Cleomenes I, King of Sparta and his forces.

November  – King Clovis I dies at Paris (Lutetia) at age , and is buried in the Abbey of St. Genevieve. The Merovingian dynasty is continued by his four sons (Theuderic I, Chlodomer, Childebert I and Chlothar I), who divide the Frankish Kingdom and rule from the capitals at Metz, Orléans, Paris and Soissons, respectively.
The convent of Saint-Césaire is built in Arles.
Riots erupt in the streets of Antioch, between supporters of Patriarch Flavian II and Emperor Anastasius I, in sympathy with Non-Chalcedonianism.

Ostrogothic King Theodoric the Great assumes the regency over Amalaric, his grandson and future king of the Visigothic Kingdom - Theodoric now rules over territory stretching from the Atlantic Ocean to the Adriatic Sea.

Aryabhata, Indian astronomer and mathematician,  comes up with concepts of mathematical equations, one of which explains the rotation of the Earth on its axis. This concept is far ahead of its time and he is fairly accurate in his description of it. He also comes up with a lot of other ideas about the Solar System, but many of them are flawed because he considers the Earth to be the center of the universe. Aryabhata is often given credit for coming up with the number zero and using it as a placeholder.
Emperor Anastasius I ends a period of moderate eclectic policy, and starts strongly favoring his own monophysitist beliefs.
The island nation of Usan-guk is conquered by the Silla dynasty (Korea), under general Kim Isabu.
The first written text in the Arabic alphabet is recorded at Zabad (Syria).
King Theodoric the Great grants citizens on Mount Vesuvius exemption from taxes, after a severe eruption in southeastern Italy.
The Ostrogoths conquer the Frankish province Rouergue (Southern Gaul).
Vitalian defeats the Byzantines at Acris (Bulgaria), on the Black Sea coast. He attacks their fortified Laager in darkness, and in a crushing defeat kills a large part of the imperial army.
Anastasius I sends an embassy under the former consul Patricius to start negotiations. Vitalian declares his aims: restoration of Chalcedonian Orthodoxy and the settling of the Thracian foederati.
Anastasius I reduces taxes in the provinces of Bithynia and Asia, to prevent them from joining the rebellion. Vitalian marches to Constantinople and encamps at the suburb of Hebdomon (modern Turkey).
The Jewish community revolts at Ctesiphon against Mazdakism, and establishes an independent Jewish kingdom that lasts for seven years.
King Kavadh I adopts the doctrine of the Mazdakites, and breaks the influence of the magnates' (nobility).
Beopheung becomes king of the Korean kingdom of Silla.
Cissa of Sussex becomes king of the South Saxons after his father's death (approximate date).

Vitalian accepts the receipt of ransom money and gifts worth , pounds of gold for the release of Hypatius, a nephew of Anastasius I who has been a prisoner since the attack at Acris (see ). Vitalian retreats back to Lower Moesia.

Vitalian, Byzantine general, marches again to Constantinople. A fleet of  vessels sails from the Black Sea ports and blockades the entrance of the harbor capital. Emperor Anastasius I is disquieted by riots in the city, which cost many casualties, and decides to negotiate with Vitalian.
July  – Pope Symmachus dies at Rome after a tenure of  years,  months and  days. He is succeeded by Hormisdas.
As a sign of his victory, Anastasius I leads a procession to Sosthenion, and attends a service of thanks at the local church dedicated to the Archangel Michael.

Autumn – Revolt of Vitalian:  Byzantine general (magister militum) Vitalian mobilises his army, and marches again towards Constantinople. He captures the suburb of Sycae (modern Turkey) across the Golden Horn, and encamps there.
The St. Maurice's Abbey (Switzerland) is founded by Sigismund of Burgundy. He sets up five groups of monks to whom he entrusts the liturgy of the praise of God.
Empress Ariadne, wife of Emperor Anastasius I, dies at Constantinople and is buried in the Church of the Holy Apostles.

Emperor Anastasius I gives Marinus, former praetorian prefect of the East, command over the Byzantine army. He defeats the rebel fleet at the harbor entrance, using a sulfur-based chemical substance, similar to the later Greek fire.
King Gundobad of the Burgundians dies peacefully after a -year reign, and is succeeded by his eldest son Sigismund.
Hygelac, king of the Geats (Sweden), raids the Lower Rhine, and is defeated by a Frankish force led by Theudebert (according to the "History of the Franks").
November  – The Council of Tarragona (modern Spain) is held.

Emperor Wu appoints Lý Tắc, a Jiaozhou's state official, as the governor. Lý Tắc then suppresses the rebellion of Lý Tông Lão, a former subordinate of Lý Nguyên Khải, the previous governor of Jiaozhou, then beheads him to bring his head to Jiankang, as an offering to the emperor.
Aryabhata compiles his manual of mathematics and astronomy (approximate date).
King Sigismund of Burgundy is opposed by his son Sigeric, and has him strangled. Overcome with remorse, he retreats to the monastery that he founded, St. Maurice's Abbey (modern Switzerland).

Emperor Wu Di of the Liang Dynasty becomes a Buddhist, and introduces the new religion to central China. He demands that sacrifices to imperial ancestors be changed to using dried meat, instead of the traditional animals (goats, pigs and cows).

Council of Epaone: Bishops of southern Gaul convene near Epao (present Anneyron) in Burgundy. The synod enacts the first legislation against wooden altars, forbidding the building of any but stone altars with chrism (a mixture of oil and spice).
September  – Severus, patriarch of Antioch, is deposed by a synod for his Monophysitism. Paul the Jew is appointed to replace him.
An earthquake destroys the city of Scupi (modern-day Skopje, North Macedonia), in what once was the Roman province of Moesia Superior.
Battle of Badon, British defeat of the Saxons, traditionally associated with King Arthur
Jabalah IV ibn al-Harith becomes the king of the Ghassanids. He invades Palestine, but is defeated by a Byzantine army under general (dux) Romanus.

July  – Emperor Anastasius I dies childless at Constantinople, age , after a -year reign in which he has abolished the sale of offices, reformed taxation, and perfected the empire's monetary system, but antagonized some with his heretical Monophysite religious policies. He is succeeded by Justin (Flavius Justinus), his comes excubitorum, commander of the palace guard. After his death, he leaves the imperial treasury richer by ,, solidi or , pounds of gold.
Anjang becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Goguryeo.
The synagogues of Ravenna are burnt down in a riot; Theodoric the Great orders them to be rebuilt at Ravenna's expense.
March  – The Eastern and Western churches reconcile their differences, ending the Acacian Schism.
Cerdic becomes the first king of the Kingdom of Wessex (according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle).
Jacob of Serugh becomes bishop of Batnan (near modern Diyarbakir, Turkey).
Ostrogothic ruler Theodoric the Great builds the Mausoleum of Theodoric as his future tomb in Ravenna (Italy).
February  – Epiphanius is elected patriarch of Constantinople by Byzantine Emperor Justin I.
King Budic II returns to Cornouaille (Brittany), to claim the Breton throne (approximate date).
The monastery of Seridus, where Barsanuphius and John the Prophet lived as hermits, is founded in the region of Gaza.
Bodhidharma, Buddhist monk, arrives in Luoyang. He spreads Buddhism and travels to the northern Chinese kingdom of Wei, to the Shaolin Monastery.
Bardiya succeeds Cambyses II as ruler of Persia.
The Priam Painter makes "Women at a Fountain House", black-figure decoration on a hydria. It is now at Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.
Psammetichus III succeeds Amasis II as king of Egypt.
Jain Tirthankara Mahavira attains Moksha, according to the Swetambara Tradition.
Kore, from Chios(?), is made. It is now at Acropolis Museum, Athens.
Boethius introduces Greek musical letter notation to the West.
Ecclesius becomes a bishop of Ravenna.
February  – Samson of Dol is ordained as bishop in Brittany, on the Feast of the Chair of Saint Peter.
Future Byzantine emperor Justinian, age , is appointed consul. He later becomes Commander-in-chief of the Army of the East.
Ma`adikarib Ya`fur becomes king, supported by the Aksumites; he begins a military campaign against the Arabian tribes.
Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius, Roman philosopher, is arrested on charges of having conspired against Theodoric the Great. He is imprisoned at Pavia (Lombardy).
Amalaric, age , is proclaimed king of the Visigoths. His kingdom is threatened from the north by the Burgundians.
Dhū Nuwas moves to Najran, an Aksumite stronghold. After accepting the city's capitulation, he massacres the Christian inhabitants (some sources estimate a death toll up to ,).
Dhu Nuwas seizes the throne of the Himyarite Kingdom in Yemen. He attacks the Aksumite garrison at Zafar, capturing the city and burning the churches.
Hilderic succeeds his uncle Thrasamund after a -year reign, and becomes king of the Vandals and Alans. He favours Catholicism and grants the inhabitants religious freedom.
A revolt breaks out on the Six Garrisons, on the northern border of Northern Wei China ("Revolt of the Six Garrisons"). Tensions between the elite and the Tuoba-clan severely destabilise the state.
Justinian, later Byzantine emperor, marries in Constantinople his mistress Theodora, who is by profession  a courtesan (approximate date).
King Sigismund of Burgundy is defeated by the invading Franks under Chlodomer, Childebert I and Chlothar I. He is captured and taken as prisoner to Aurelianum (modern Orléans).
August  – Pope Hormisdas dies at Rome after a tenure of  years and  days, in which he has been instrumental in ending the Acacian Schism. He is succeeded by John I as the 53rd pope.
Date unknown – Queen Guntheuc, widow of Chlodomer, is forced into marrying his brother, Chlothar I. Her two children are murdered by him, but the eldest son Clodoald survives by escaping to Provence.

June  – Battle of Vézeronce: The Franks under Chlodomer, Childebert I and Chlothar I are defeated by the Burgundians and allied Ostrogoths near Isère (France), averting the Frankish advance into Burgundy. During the fighting Chlodomer is killed. Later Childebert annexes the cities of Chartres and Orléans.

January  – Venantius Opilio is appointed by Byzantium's Emperor Justin to administer the Western Roman Empire as the Roman consul, replacing Anicius Maximus. The Emperor Justin appoints himself as consul for the West, an office vacant since , but has Theodorus Filoxenus administering the west.
May  – King Sigismund of Burgundy is executed at Orléans after an -year reign, and is succeeded by his brother Godomar. He rallies the Burgundian army and begins plundering Frankish territory.

October  – Anicius Manlius Boethius, one of Rome's most prolific writers and philosophers, is beaten to death at the prison at Pavia, where he has been imprisoned for treason. During his prison sentence, he has written his final work,  The Consolation of Philosophy. The date of the death of St. Boethius is later celebrated as his feast day on the Roman Catholic Calendar of Saints.

Cosmas Indicopleustes, Alexandrian explorer-geographer, travels up the Nile. He will venture as far to the east as Ceylon, become a monk, and write "Topographia Christiana" to vindicate the biblical account of the world (see ).
Emperor Justin I rebuilds the city of Anazarbus (modern Turkey) and renames it "Justinopolis".

The Daisan river, tributary of the Euphrates, floods Edessa, and within a couple of hours fills the entire city except for the highest parts. Eventually the pent-up waters break through the city walls. The Shroud of Turin is allegedly discovered during the rebuilding of the city (see Image of Edessa).
Frankish tribesmen, under the command of King Chlothar I, plunder Burgundy.
King Theodoric the Great sends Pope John I to Constantinople, to negotiate a withdrawal of Byzantine emperor Justin's edict against Arian Christianity.
Ecclesius, bishop of Ravenna, commissions two new churches, one for Ravenna and one for its port, Classis.
May  – John I dies of starvation after a -year reign. Theodoric the Great selects Pope Felix IV as the 54th pope.
Probably between May  and May  –  Antioch earthquake: A great earthquake kills approximately , people in Syria and Antioch.
August  – King Theodoric the Great dies of dysentery at Ravenna; his daughter Amalasuintha takes power as regent for her -year-old son Athalaric.
Roman–Persian Wars: King Kavad I, assisted by his Arabian vassal, Al-Mundhir III, begins a campaign in the Transcaucasus region and Upper Mesopotamia.
Silla, one of the Three Kingdoms of Korea, formally adopts Buddhism as a state religion (approximate date).
Justinian I outlaws pagan religious practices in Egypt, and dispatches Byzantine missionaries to southern territories (approximate date).
April  – Emperor Justin I names his nephew Justinian I as co-ruler, as an incurable wound saps his strength.
Justinian I appoints Belisarius to command the Eastern army in Armenia and on the Byzantine-Persian frontier.
The Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem is rebuilt until , restoring the architectural tone of the basilica.
November  – Natural disaster: A second earthquake strikes Antioch, killing thousands.
The Hephthalites (White Huns) move from the Hindu Kush into the Punjab region, and eastward across the Ganges Delta, ravaging cities and Buddhist monasteries.
Yasodharman, Maharaja ("great king") of Malwa, defeats the Hun invaders under Mihirakula in central India.

May  – Empress Dowager Hu, regent of Northern Wei, having resorted to an old monarchist tool and executed lovers who have displeased her, is drowned in the Yellow River along with the nominal emperor, the baby Yuan Zhao, and prince Yuan Yong by order of General Erzhu Rong, who places -year-old Yuan Ziyou on the throne as Emperor Xiaozhuang of Northern Wei.
March  – Emperor Xiaoming of Northern Wei, emperor of Northern Wei, is poisoned by order of his mother, the regent Empress Dowager Hu.
Al-Harith ibn Jabalah becomes the fifth king of the Ghassanids. He helps the Byzantines to suppress the wide-scale Samaritan Revolt.
The Canons of the Council of Orange are established, approving the  Augustinian doctrine of sin and grace over Pelagianism and Semi-Pelagianism, but without Augustine's absolute predestination.
The Samaritans revolt and are defeated; the Church of the Nativity is burnt down during the Rebellion.
April  – Emperor Justinian I issues the Codex Justinianus (Code of Civil Laws), reformulating Roman law in an effort to control his unruly people (see ).

Queen Amalasuntha receives a delegation sent by a council of Gothic nobles urging that she have her son Athalaric, now , taught an education in the Roman tradition—not by elderly schoolmasters, but by men who will teach him to "ride, fence, and to be toughened, not to be turned into a bookworm".

Spring – Battle of Dara: Belisarius and Hermogenes (magister officiorum) defeat a combined Persian-Arab army of , men at Dara (modern Turkey), by entrenching his infantry in a refused position in the centre line, then carrying out a cavalry envelopment to culminate a classic defensive-offensive battleplan.
December  – Emperor Justinian I selects a second commission to excerpt and codify the writings of the jurists on Roman law. This becomes the Digest (Pandects).

King Hilderic is deposed by his cousin Gelimer after a seven-year reign. Gelimer restores Arianism as the official religion of the Vandal Kingdom and puts Hilderic in prison along with other supporters.
October  – Dioscorus is elected as antipope in the Lateran Palace, but he dies within a month, thus ending the schism.
Emperor Xiao Zhuang Di is arrested and imprisoned in a Buddhist temple at Jinyang (Shanxi). He is succeeded by Chang Guang Wang, who becomes the new ruler of Northern Wei.
Peplos Kore, from the Acropolis, Athens, is made. It is now at Acropolis Museum, Athens.
The Babylonian Captivity ends when Cyrus, king of Persia, allows Jews in Babylon to return to Jerusalem.
Lucius Tarquinius Superbus becomes seventh King of Rome, after murdering the sixth king Servius Tullius.
Phocaean Greek colonists clash at sea with Carthaginians and Etruscans in Battle of Alalia (Corsica).
Cyrus II is killed in war against obscure tribes.
Anwon becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Goguryeo.
King Childebert I receives pleas from his sister Clotilde, wife of King Amalaric, claiming that she is abused by her husband. Childebert invades Septimania (Gaul).
Childebert I defeats the Visigoths and conquers the capital Narbonne. Amalaric flees south to Barcelona, where he is assassinated by his own men.
King Kavad I, age , dies after a -year reign. Khosrau I, his favourite son, is proclaimed successor over his elder brothers.
The Franks under King Chlothar I march against the Thuringii with Chlothar's nephew Theudebert I. The Kingdom of Thuringia comes under Frankish domination.

January  – Nika riots in Constantinople: Anger among the supporters of the most important chariot teams—the Blues and the Greens—escalates into violence towards the emperor. For the next five days the capital is in chaos. The fires that start during the tumult result in the destruction of much of the city. The insurrection is put down a week later by Belisarius and Mundus; , people are killed in the Hippodrome.
Battle of Autun - The Franks, under command of King Childebert I and his brother Chlothar I, invade the Kingdom of Burgundy. They defeat the Burgundians under King Godomar near Autun (modern France).

September – Justinian I signs a peace treaty, the "Eternal Peace", with the Persian king Khosrau I, ending the Iberian War (-). Both sides agree to return all occupied territories, and Justinian makes a one-off payment of  centenaria (, pounds of gold), as a contribution to the defense of the Caucasus passes.

February  – Emperor Justinian I orders the building of a new Orthodox Christian basilica in Constantinople – the Hagia Sophia. He chooses Isidore of Miletus and Anthemius of Tralles as architects. The material for the construction is brought from all over the empire, such as large stones from quarries in Porphyry, Egypt. More than , people are employed.
First year in which the Anno Domini calendar is used for numbering the years.

September  – Battle of Ad Decimum: Gelimer attempts to ambush the Byzantines in a defile at the "10th milestone" from Carthage; due to inadequate coordination and the alertness of Belisarius, the attack is repulsed and the Vandals are scattered into the desert. Belisarius enters the capital and orders his soldiers not to kill or enslave the population. The fleet is stationed in the Lake of Tunis.

December  – Battle of Tricamarum: Gelimer assembles an army of about , men at Bulla Regia (Numidia), and advances towards Carthage. Belisarius moves out to meet the Vandals; he leads the Byzantine cavalry (, men) into battle. Without waiting for his infantry to come up, he charges, despite odds of almost -to-, and throws Gelimer in confusion. Belisarius captures the Vandal camp by storm. Tzazo is killed in an all-cavalry fight, and Gelimer is forced to seek refuge in the mountains of Tunis with the Berbers.

Spring – Vandalic War: Anti-Vandal revolt in Tripolitania and Sardinia; Gelimer, king of the Vandals, dispatches the bulk of the Vandal fleet ( ships and , men) under his brother Tzazo to Sardinia. Byzantine forces from Cyrenaica occupy Leptis Magna and Tripolis.

September  – The Byzantine army lands at Caput Vada (modern Tunisia). Belisarius marches his army northwards, towards Carthage (over  miles), following the coast, accompanied by the fleet and shadowed by Gelimer. During the march, the Vandal towns fall without a fight.
March  – In a letter, Emperor Justinian I declares the Bishop of Rome (currently John) to be "head of all Bishops, and the true and effective corrector of heretics."
January  – Decius Paulinus enters the office of consul (the last to hold this office in the West).
Toledo becomes the capital of the Visigothic Kingdom that controls the Iberian Peninsula. King Theudis expands Visigoth rule in the southern regions (Hispania Baetica).

October  – King Athalaric dies of tuberculosis, age , having dissipated his youth in drink and debauchery. His mother, Amalasuntha, proposes to her cousin Theodahad, the kingdom's largest landowner and her father's last male heir, that he share the throne with her but that he will be king of the Ostrogoths in name only. Theodahad has secret conversations with the Byzantine ambassador, and promises to turn over Tuscany in exchange for a large sum of money, the rank of senator, and permission to live at Constantinople.
Cynric becomes king of Wessex.

Summer – Belisarius arrives in Constantinople and is permitted by Emperor Justinian I to celebrate a triumph, the first non-imperial triumph for over  years. In the procession the spoils of the Temple of Jerusalem and the Vandal treasure are paraded.
Anthimus I becomes patriarch of Constantinople (–).
Reports of the eruption of Krakatoa (Java), which possibly led to several years of climate change (see Extreme weather events of –), are recorded in the Javanese Book of Kings.

Summer – Belisarius lands in Sicily and meets little opposition, save for the Gothic garrison of Palermo. Laying siege to the citadel, he blockades the harbour with his ships. Mundus invades Dalmatia and captures its capital, Salona.
The death of Amalasuintha gives Byzantine Emperor Justinian I a pretext to invade Italy and begin the Gothic War.
April  – King Theodahad revenges himself upon Queen Amalasuintha. He has her taken from the capital of Ravenna to a small island on Lake Bolsena, where she is strangled in her bath.
Early in  (possible) – Volcanic winter of : Famine is described in the Annals of Ulster.
Summer – Constantinianus, magister militum per Illyricum, retakes Dalmatia. The Goths abandon Salona and withdraw to the north. The Byzantines rebuild its walls and reclaim the province.
November – Siege of Naples: Belisarius captures Naples after a month's siege, by sending troops into the city through an abandoned Roman aqueduct.

December  – Belisarius enters Rome through the Porta Asinaria, and the Gothic garrison of , men flees the city. He sends an urgent request for reinforcements to Justinian I, meanwhile preparing Rome for a siege, by bringing in great quantities of food and other supplies.
January  – Senka succeeds his brother Ankan as the 28th emperor of Japan.
John Cottistis starts a short-lived rebellion against Justinian I. He is declared emperor at Dara, but is killed four days later by conspiring soldiers.

April  – Belisarius receives his promised reinforcements: , cavalry, mostly of Hunnic or Slavic origin and expert bowmen. Despite shortages, he starts raids against the Gothic camps and Vitiges is forced into a stalemate.

Spring – Battle of Scalas Veteres ( km south of Carthage, in the Praetorian prefecture of Africa): Byzantine troops under Germanus crush a large-scale mutiny. Stotzas, leader of the rebellion, flees with a handful of followers to Mauretania.

Vitiges sets up seven camps, overlooking the main gates and access routes to the city, in order to starve it out. He blocks the Roman aqueducts that are supplying Rome with water, necessary both for drinking and for operating the corn mills.

March  – Vitiges attempts to assault the northern and eastern city walls with four siege towers, but is repulsed at the Praenestine Gate, known as the Vivarium, by the defenders under the Byzantine generals Bessas and Peranius.

The first time since the Emperor Justinian's decree of , making John (the Bishop of Rome) Chief Bishop of all the churches, that the supremacy of the Bishop of Rome over the Church can actually be implemented by Pope Vigilius.

King Seong of Paekche (Korea) moves the capital from Ungjin (present-day Gongju) further south to Sabi (present-day Buyeo County), on the Geum River. He sends a diplomatic mission that formally introduces Buddhism to the Japanese imperial court (see also ).
King Cuneglas of Rhos abandons his wife in favour of his sister-in-law, a nun who he drags from her convent (approximate date).
Sittas, Byzantine general, suppresses a revolt in Armenia in protest against heavy taxation. During the campaign he is killed by Artabanes, leader of the revolt.
Gabrán mac Domangairt becomes king of Dál Riata (Scotland).
Fourth year of worldwide famine, a consequence of the Extreme weather events of –.
Kinmei succeeds his brother Senka, and ascends as 29th emperor to the throne of Japan.

March – Gothic War: The Goths and the Burgundians recapture Mediolanum (modern Milan), after many months of siege, the city reaching the point of starvation. The Byzantine garrison (, men) surrenders and is spared, but the inhabitants are massacred (according to Procopius , people are murdered), and the city itself is destroyed.
Emperor Justinian I becomes alarmed by renewed barbarian incursions across the Danube frontier from the Slavs, the Bulgars,  the Gepids, and the Avars.
November  – Antioch is struck by an earthquake.

King Khosrow I breaks the "Eternal Peace" treaty with the Byzantine Empire after eight years. Responding to an embassy from the Ostrogoths urging action against Emperor Justinian I's expanding power, he leads the Persian army up the River Euphrates. Extracting tributes from towns along the way, Khosrau I besieges and captures Antioch. He plunders the city extensively, transporting valuable artworks, including marble statues and mosaics, back to Persia.
Emperor Justinian I offers to make peace with Vitiges, but Belisarius refuses to transmit the message. The Ostrogoths then offer to support Belisarius as emperor of the West.

Cassiodorus, former Roman statesman, establishes a monastery at his estate in Italy. The Vivarium "monastery school" is for highly educated and sophisticated men, who copy sacred and secular manuscripts, intending for this to be their sole occupation (approximate date).
King Custennin ap Cado is deposed, and returns to Dumnonia in the south-west of Great Britain.
Ildibad succeeds Vitiges as king of the Ostrogoths, and installs his nephew Totila as commander of the Gothic army. He recaptures Venetia and Liguria in Northern Italy.
Cyrus of Persia completes his conquest of Lydia, and makes Pasargadae his capital.
Guided by the Chinese statesman Zi Chan, the State of Zheng institutes a formal code of law.
Exekias makes The Suicide of Ajax, black-figure decoration on an amphora. It is now at Chateau-Musee, Boulogne-sur-Mer, France.

Sparta and Argos fight the Battle of the  Champions. Both sides had agreed beforehand to resolve their dispute with just  picked men on each side, in the end just one Spartan and two Argive soldiers remained alive. Both sides claimed victory.
North Indian Prince Vijaya invades Ceylon and establishes a Sri Lankan dynasty.

Emperor Justinian I recalls Belisarius from Italy to handle the situation in Armenia. He arrives in Upper Mesopotamia and attacks the fortress city of Nisbis. After an unsuccessful siege he ravages the countryside.
Autumn – Totila is elected king by the Ostrogothic nobles after the death of his uncle Ildibad. He wins the support of the lower classes by liberating slaves and distributing land to the peasants.
January  – Anicius Faustus Albinus Basilius is appointed as consul in Constantinople, the last person to hold this office.
The Uyghurs come under the rule of the Hephthalites (approximate date).

Plague of Justinian: Bubonic plague appears suddenly in the Egyptian port of Pelusium, spreading to Alexandria and, the following year, to Constantinople. This is the beginning of a -year-long pandemic that will devastate Europe, the Middle East, and North Africa.
Gildas, British monk, writes his work "De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae" (approximate date).
Battle of Mucellium: Totila marches down into Tuscany and defeats the Byzantines at Florence, in the valley of Mugello. He treats his prisoners well, and many are induced to join his banner.
The  Sea of Marmara earthquake takes place in the winter of , in the vicinity of the Sea of Marmara. It also affects the coasts of Thrace and the Edremit Gulf.

King Childebert I and his brother Chlothar I invade Visigothic Spain. They capture Pamplona, but Zaragoza withstands a siege and the Franks retreat to Gaul. From this expedition Childebert brings back to Paris a relic, the tunic of Saint Vincent.
Spring – Battle of Faventia: King Totila scatters the Byzantine forces near Faventia (modern Faenza) with , men, beginning the resurgence of Gothic resistance to the reconquest of Italy.
The doctrine of apocatastasis is condemned by the Synod of Constantinople.
Summer – Khosrow I, Shahanshah of the Sasanian Empire, invades Syria again, and turns south towards Edessa to besiege the fortress city.

Spring – Siege of Naples (–): The Byzantine garrison (, men) in Naples surrenders to the Ostrogoths, pressed by famine and demoralized by the failure of two relief efforts. The defenders are well treated by King Totila, and the garrison is allowed safe departure, but the city walls are partly razed.

Barsanuphius, a famous hermit close to Gaza, retreats fully from the world after the death of Seridus, abbot of the nearby monastery, and fellow hermit John the Prophet with whom he wrote over  letters to people seeking his advice and guidance. Aelianos follows Seridus as abbot of the monastery.
Approximate date – The Yupian (玉篇) Chinese dictionary is edited by Gu Yewang.
Battle of Cillium: A medium-sized Byzantine army under Solomon is defeated by the Moors on the border of Numidia. Solomon and his bodyguard are forced to retreat and are later killed.
Jacob Baradaeus consecrates Sergius of Tella as patriarch of Antioch, opening a permanent schism between the Syriac Orthodox Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church.
Gothic War: Emperor Justinian I sends Belisarius back to the Ostrogothic Kingdom (Italy) with an inadequate Byzantine expeditionary force (, men and  ships).
October – The Liang dynasty retaliates against Van Xuân, and sends an imperial army (, men) under Chen Baxian to re-occupy the region.
Justinian I issues a new edict condemning the Three Chapters. In Western Europe, Pope Vigilius refuses to acknowledge the imperial edict and is ordered to summon to Constantinople.
Gothic War: King Totila establishes his military base at Tivoli (Central Italy), and prepares a campaign to reconquer the region of Latium.
The monastery of Clonmacnoise is founded in Ireland by Ciarán Mac a tSaor on the River Shannon (approximate date).
Emperor Justinian I sends Narses, Byzantine general, to the rulers of the Heruli, to recruit troops for the campaigns in Italy and Syria.
The Synod of Brefi is held at Llanddewi Brefi, to condemn the Pelagian heresy. Dubricius, archbishop of South Wales, resigns his position in favour of David (approximate date).
Yangwon becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Goguryeo.
Audoin receives subsidies from Justinian I, to encourage him to battle the Gepids in the Carpathian Mountains.
Audoin leads the Lombards across the Danube into Pannonia, and becomes an ally of the Byzantines.

December  – Sack of Rome: After almost a year's siege, the capture of a grain fleet sent by the exiled Pope Vigilius near the mouth of the Tiber, and failure of troops of the Byzantine Empire under Belisarius to relieve the city, the Ostrogoths under King Totila plunder Rome and destroy its fortifications. He then withdraws to Apulia (Southern Italy).
Audoin murders and succeeds Walthari as king of the Lombards.
Winter – Pope Vigilius arrives in Constantinople, to meet with Emperor Justinian I. The future Pope Pelagius is sent by Totila to negotiate with Justinian.
The mosaic panels of Justinian I and Theodora I with attendants, in the Basilica of San Vitale (Ravenna), are made (approximate date).
Gothic War: Belisarius recaptures Rome from the Ostrogoths, but his Italian campaign is unsuccessful (he is starved of supplies and reinforcements from Constantinople).

Battle of Marta: The Byzantine army under John Troglita is defeated by Moorish tribes in Tripolitania. He flees to Lunci ( km south of Mahares), and is forced to withdraw north to the fortress of Laribus (near modern El Kef).
Theudebald, age , succeeds his father Theudebert I after a reign of  years, and becomes king of Austrasia (or ).
The Tonkin revolt (Vietnam), led by Lý Nam Đế, is suppressed by the Chinese Liang dynasty.
Theudigisel, Visigothic general, proclaims himself ruler over the Visigothic Kingdom, after King Theudis is assassinated.
Saint Catherine's Monastery is established in the Sinai Peninsula.
Lazic War: King Gubazes II revolts against the Persians, and requests aid from Justinian I. He sends a Byzantine expeditionary force (, men) to Lazica (modern Georgia).
Emperor Justinian I relieves Belisarius from military service, in favour of -year-old Byzantine general Narses.
Spring – Battle of the Fields of Cato: The Byzantine army, under John Troglita, crushes the Moorish revolt in Byzacena (Tunisia).

Spring – Lazic War: The Byzantine army under Bessas combines forces with King Gubazes II, and defeats the Persians in Lazica (modern Georgia) in a surprise attack. The survivors retreat into Caucasian Iberia.
The Romans unsuccessfully besiege Petra, Lazica.
Siege of Rome: The Ostrogoths under Totila besiege Rome for the third time, after Belisarius has returned to Constantinople. He offers a peace agreement, but this is rejected by Emperor Justinian I.
The Roman Catholic Diocese of Ossory (which still exists) is founded in Ireland.
The Romans unsuccessfully besiege Petra, Lazica.

Totila conquers the city of Perugia (Central Italy) and stations a Gothic garrison. He takes bishop Herculanus prisoner, and orders him to be completely flayed. The Ostrogoth soldier asked to perform this gruesome execution shows pity, and decapitates Herculanus before the skin on every part of his body is removed.

The churches of Lazica (Georgia) and Armenia split. While the Armenian Church remains independent, the Georgian church unites with the Byzantine Empire. This ecclesiastical union deepens political and cultural contact between the two states. As a sign of Lazica's status vis-à-vis Byzantium, Lazic princes are vested with honorific titles of the Byzantine court, including kouropalates, or "minister of the imperial palace" (approximate date).
Chararic, king of the Suevi, converts to Catholicism.
The main redaction of the Babylonian Talmud is completed under Rabbis Ravina and Ashi (approximate date).
The last known eruption of Chimborazo (modern Ecuador) occurs.
Justinian I sends two Nestorian monks on a mission to Central Asia, to spread Christianity in the East (approximate date).
Pisistratus is exiled from Athens to Euboea.
The Temple of Artemis is completed in Ephesus.
Colonisation of Greeks ends.
Siddhartha Gautama founds Buddhism in Northern India after achieving enlightenment after six years of practicing penance and meditation.
The Temple of Hera I is built in what is now Paestum, Italy.
Jordanes, Roman bureaucrat, publishes "The Origin and Deeds of the Goths" (approximate date).

After the death of his cousin Germanus, Justinian I appoints Narses new supreme commander, and returns to Italy. In Salona on the Adriatic coast, he assembles a Byzantine expeditionary force totaling , or possibly , men and a contingent of foreign allies, notably Lombards, Heruls and Bulgars.

Spring – Lazic War - Siege of Petra (–): The Byzantine army and their Sabir allies (some , men) under Bessas recapture the strategic Byzantine fortress of Petra, located on the coast of the Black Sea. He orders the city walls razed to the ground.

Autumn – Battle of Sena Gallica: The Byzantine fleet ( warships) destroys the Gothic naval force under Indulf near Sena Gallica (Senigallia), some  miles ( km) north of Ancona. It marks the end of the Gothic supremacy in the Mediterranean Sea.
Spring – The  Malian Gulf earthquake takes place in the vicinity of the Malian Gulf; it affects the cities of Echinus and Tarphe.
Cynric, king of Wessex, captures the fortress city of Old Sarum.
Buddhism in Japan is introduced, according to the Nihon Shoki.

July  – Battle of Taginae: Narses crosses the Apennines with a Byzantine army (, men). He is blocked by a Gothic force under king Totila near Taginae (Central Italy). In a narrow mountain valley, Narses deploys his army in a "crescent shaped" formation. He dismounts his Lombard and Heruli cavalry mercenaries, placing them as a phalanx in the centre. On his left flank he sends out a mixed force of foot and horse archers to seize a dominant height. The Goths open the battle with a determined cavalry charge. Halted by enfilading fire from both sides, the attackers are thrown back in confusion on the infantry behind them. The Byzantine cataphracts (Clibanarii) sweep into the milling mass. More than , Goths, including Totila, are killed. The remnants flee, and Narses proceeds to Rome, where he captures the city after a brief siege.
The Roman Catholic Diocese of Meath is established in Ireland.
Eutychius becomes patriarch of Constantinople.

The Ostrogothic Kingdom ends after  years of rule in Italy. The Goths are allowed to return to their homes in peace and (re)settle in modern-day Austria. Some , people retreat to Campsas (Southern Gaul), and resist with minimal help from the Franks against the Byzantines until .

Gothic War: Frankish invasion — Two Frankish-Alemanni dukes, brothers Lothair and Buccelin, cross the Alps from Germany with a force of , men, mostly Frankish infantry. In the Po Valley, they win an easy victory over a much smaller Byzantine force at Parma, and are joined by remnants of the Gothic armies, bringing the total strength of the invaders to about , men. Narses, gathering his forces as quickly as possible, marches north to harass the Franks, but is not strong enough to engage them in battle. In Samnium (Southern Italy) the brothers divide their forces: Lothaire goes down the east coast, then returns to the north, to winter in the Po Valley. Buccelin follows the west coast into Calabria, where he spends the winter — his army being seriously wasted by attrition and disease.

Battle of Mons Lactarius: King Teia secretly marches to join forces with his brother Aligern in Campania, to relieve the siege of Cumae. Meanwhile at Mons Lactarius (modern Monti Lattari), Narses lays an ambush. The combined Gothic force is crushed in a hopeless last stand for two days (south of Naples), and Teia is killed in the fighting. Aligern escapes, but surrenders a few months later.
The Sassanid commander Mihr-Mihroe force the Byzantines to retreat from Telephis and later Ollaria. (See Battle of Telephis–Ollaria).
May  – The Fifth Ecumenical Council is held in Constantinople. In an edict, Emperor Justinian I condemns the Three Chapters, causing further schisms and heresies of monoenergism and monothelitism.
Wei Shou completes compilation of the Book of Wei.
Cassiodorus, Roman statesman, founds the Monastery at Vivarium (approximate date).
Baekje and the Gaya Confederacy wage war upon Silla, one of the Three Kingdoms of Korea, but are defeated.

August  – Byzantine Emperor Justinian I issues a pragmatic sanction reorganizing Italy, and rewards the praetorian prefect Liberius for over  years of distinguished service, granting him extensive estates in Italy.
Athanagild is crowned as king of the Visigoths and succeeds Agila I. He acknowledges the suzerainty of the Byzantine Empire.

By this date, the Roman Empire under Justinian I has reached its height. Justinian I has reconquered many former territories of the Western Roman Empire, including Italy, Dalmatia, Africa and Southern Hispania.
Taliesin, British poet, becomes court bard to King Brochwel of Powys (approximate date).
King Chlothar I annexes the Frankish territories of Metz and Reims, after the death of his great-nephew Theudebald.
June  – Pope Vigilius dies at Syracuse on his journey back home. His body is brought to Rome and buried in the San Martino ai Monti.
Around this time, the historian Jordanes writes several books, among them De origine actibusque Getarum (The origin and deeds of the Goths).
King Cynric and his son Ceawlin of Wessex fight against the Britons at Beranburh, now identified as Barbury Castle (Wiltshire) in South West England.
King Khosrau I opens negotiations with Justinian I, leading to the establishment of a  year peace agreement in .
Lazic War: A Byzantine expeditionary force under Justin retakes Archaeopolis (modern Georgia), and routs the Persian army.
King Chlothar I suppresses a revolt of the Saxons and Thuringii in Saxony (Germany). For some time he exacts a tribute of  cows every year.
Siege of Phasis: The Persians are defeated at the besieged town of Phasis in Lazica, held by the Byzantines.
The Liang dynasty ends: Chen Wu Di, a distinguished general, becomes the first emperor of the Chen dynasty in Southern China.
The Jiming Temple in Nanjing is built; the Buddhist pagoda is located near Xuanwu Lake.

The Avars arrive in the northern region of the Caucasus, between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea. They send envoys to the Byzantines in Lazica (modern Georgia). Like the Huns, the Avars are the former elite of a central Asian federation, which has been forced to flee westwards.
King Chlothar I of the Franks founds the Abbey of St. Medard at Soissons (Northern France).
The Göktürks under Muqan Qaghan ally with the Persian Empire, and destroy the Hephthalites (White Huns) in Central Asia.
Istämi, ruler of the Western Turkic Khaganate, establishes diplomatic relations with the Byzantine Empire.
The Bangor Abbey is founded by the Irish abbot Comgall in Northern Ireland (approximate date).
Conall mac Comgaill becomes king of Dál Riata, a Gaelic overkingdom on the western coast of Scotland.
December  – King Chlothar I reunites the Frankish Kingdom after his brother Childebert I dies, becoming sole ruler of the Franks.
May  – In Constantinople, the dome of the Hagia Sophia collapses due to an earthquake. Emperor Justinian I orders the dome to be rebuilt.
Pyeongwon becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Goguryeo.
Wen Di, age , succeeds his uncle Chen Wu Di as emperor of the Chen dynasty. During his reign, he consolidates the state against the rebellious warlords.
Glappa succeeds his father Ida as king of Bernicia (North East England). During his rule, Anglian settlers expand their territory in what is now southeastern Scotland.
The city-state Ara Gaya, a member of the Gaya confederacy, surrenders to Silla in the Korean peninsula.

Winter – The Kutrigurs and Huns under Zabergan cross the frozen Danube River, and invade the Balkans. They raid Thracia and Macedonia, but are driven back near Constantinople by a Byzantine force under Belisarius.
Ceawlin succeeds his father Cynric as king of Wessex (approximate date).
Custennin ap Cado abdicates as king of Dumnonia (South West England).
Columba quarrels with Finnian of Moville over authorship of a psalter, leading to a pitched battle the next year.
Alboin succeeds his father Audoin after his death, as king of the Lombards.
Adda succeeds his brother Glappa as king of Bernicia (approximate date).
Former pharaoh Apries invades Egypt with Babylonian help but is defeated by Saite pharaoh Amasis II (also known as Ahmose II).
Neriglissar succeeds Amel-Marduk as king of Babylon.
Amtalqa succeeds his brother Aspelta as king of Kush.
The first known Panathenaic Games of Ancient Greece are held in Athens.
An aristocrat named Pisistratus seizes the Acropolis of Athens and declares himself tyrant. He is deposed in the same year.
The First Council of Braga is held. The council condemns the doctrine of Priscillianism.
March  – Pope Pelagius I dies in Rome after a five-year reign, and is succeeded by John III as the 61st pope.
Sky Witness is crowned as leader of Calakmul.
Jnanagupta, a Buddhist monk from Gandhara (Pakistan), begins translating Buddhist texts into Chinese.
Winter – Wu Cheng Di succeeds his brother Xiao Zhao Di, who dies from injuries suffered while hunting, as Chinese emperor of Northern Qi.
King Sigebert I repels an attack on Austrasia by the Avars at Regensburg (Germany). He moves his capital from Reims to Metz (approximate date).
First Tikal-Calakmul War: The Maya state of Caracol (Belize) defeats King Wak Chan K'awiil (Double Bird) of Tikal in battle, ending his dynasty.
Emperor Justinian I signs a peace treaty with the Sasanid Empire. The status quo ante is restored, with Lazica (modern Georgia) in Byzantine hands.
Spring – Xiao Ming Di, age , succeeds his father Xuan Di as emperor of the Chinese Liang Dynasty.
The last Ostrogothic strongholds at Verona and Brixia are taken by the Byzantine Empire, ending the Gothic War.

Tauredunum event: A mountain landslide into the Rhone river destroys a fort and two villages, and creates a tsunami in Lake Geneva. The wave which reaches Lausanne is thirteen metres high, and eight metres high by the time it hits Geneva. Describing the event, Marius Aventicensis writes that the tsunami "devastated very old villages with their men and cattle, it even destroyed many sacred places", and swept away "the bridge in Geneva, windmills and men".

Columba, Irish missionary monk, travels to Scotland with twelve companions. He lands on the Kintyre Peninsula, near Southend, and begins his evangelising mission to the Picts. On the island of Iona, he founds a monastery (Iona Abbey) on the west coast in the Inner Hebrides.
The new Hagia Sophia (cost: , pounds of gold), with its numerous chapels and shrines, octagonal dome and mosaics, becomes the centre and most visible monument of Eastern Orthodoxy.
Emperor Justinian I pardons Belisarius; he orders his release from prison, and  restores his properties and honours. He permits the general to live in obscurity, and gives him a veterans' pension.
August  – Columba reports seeing the Loch Ness Monster at the River Ness (according to the "Life of St. Columba").
Samson of Dol, one of seven founder saints of Brittany, attends a council in Paris and witnesses several royal decrees (approximate date).
Tulum, Maya walled city, on the Yucatán Peninsula (modern Mexico) is first mentioned on a stele inscription.
Cadoc, abbot of Llancarfan (Wales), settles in Weedon and is made bishop (approximate date).
Columba begins preaching in the Orkney Islands (approximate date).
February  – Kʼan Joy Chitam I, ruler of the Mayan city-state of Palenque, in what is now the state of Chiapas in southern Mexico, dies after a reign of exactly  years.
May  – Ahkal Moʼ Nahb II becomes the new ruler of Palenque and reigns until his death in .
The Uyghurs are defeated by the Göktürks, who expand their territory in Central Asia (approximate date).
Gao Wei succeeds his father Wu Cheng Di as ruler of the Chinese Northern Qi Dynasty. Wu Cheng Di becomes a regent and Grand Emperor.
Ainmuire mac Sétnai becomes High King of Ireland, and rules from – (this according to the Book of Leinster).
Fei Di, age , succeeds his father Wen Di, as emperor of the Chinese Chen dynasty. He honors his grand-aunt Zhang Yao'er with the title of Grand Empress, and she becomes his regent.

A poet from Italy named Venantius Fortunatus arrives at the Merovingian court at Metz. With a strong grasp of traditional Roman poetry, Fortunatus impresses and entertains the Frankish royalty and aristocracy. The success of a Latin poet in Francia suggests that Roman culture persisted well after the Roman Empire disintegrated in Gaul in the late .

Emperor Justin II, facing an empty treasury, breaks the treaty with the Gepids that has existed since . King Alboin of the Lombards makes an alliance with the Avars under Bayan I, at the expense of tough conditions. They demand a tenth of the Lombards' cattle and half of the war booty.
Kirtivarman I succeeds his father Pulakeshin I as king of the Chalukya dynasty (India). During his rule he completes the subjugation of the Kadambas and annexes the port of Goa.
John III, patriarch of Constantinople, organizes a compromise between the Chalcedonians and Monophysites.
The Lombard–Gepid War () ends with a Lombard-Avar victory, and the annihilation of the Gepids.
The Second Council of Tours is held. It decrees that any cleric found in bed with his wife will be excommunicated.
King Charibert I dies without an heir; his realm (region Neustria and Aquitaine) is divided between his brothers Guntram, Sigebert I and Chilperic I.
Sigebert I, king of Austrasia, marries Brunhilda, and his half brother Chilperic I marries Galswintha, both daughters of the Visigothic king Athanagild.
Sigebert I, king of Austrasia, repels a second attack from the Avars. His half brother Chilperic I strangles his wife Galswintha at the instigation of his mistress Fredegund.
Battle of Wibbandun: Ceawlin of Wessex defeats Æthelberht of Kent (according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle).
Liuvigild is declared co-king and heir after the second year of the reign of his brother Liuva I. He becomes ruler over the Visigoths in Hispania Citerior (Eastern Spain).
A Turkish khan sends emissaries to the Byzantine Empire (approximate date).
Æthelric succeeds his brother Adda as king of Bernicia (modern Scotland). He rules from – (approximate date).
Emperor Justin II and his wife Sophia send a relic of the "True Cross" to the Frankish princess Radegund, who has founded a monastery at Poitiers.
The Garamantian Kingdom (modern Libya) signs a peace treaty with the Byzantine Empire. The capital city of Garama is converted to Christianity.
The Nubian kingdom of Alodia is converted to Christianity by Byzantine missionaries (according to John of Ephesus).
September – The Lombards conquer Forum Iulii (Cividale del Friuli) in northeastern Italy. Later in the year, the Lombards conquer Milan.
John of Ephesus completes his "Biographies of Eastern Saints" (approximate date).
The Jews of Clermont-Ferrand are forced to convert to Christianity.

Abraha, Christian ruler of coastal Yemen, who was acting as a general for the Christian kingdom in Abyssinia, begins a military expedition in Arabia against the predominantly pagan Quraysh of Mecca, known as the Year of the Elephant.
Ctesiphon, capital of the Sassanid Empire, becomes the largest city in the world, taking the lead from Constantinople, capital of the Byzantine Empire.
Leutfred becomes duke of Alemannia (modern Germany).
Battle of Gwen Ystrad: A British alliance is forged between the kingdoms of Strathclyde, Bryneich and Elmet (approximate date).
Amasis II succeeds Apries as king of Egypt.
( November)—Servius Tullius, king of Rome, celebrates a triumph for his victory over the Etruscans.
Berlin Kore, from a cemetery at Keratea, near Athens, is made.
Battle of Yanling: The army of the Chinese State of Jin defeats the forces of the State of Chu in ancient Henan province.
The Ishtar Gate and throne room wall are built in the city of Babylon.
Battle of Bedcanford: The Anglo-Saxons under King Cuthwulf fight against the Britons, and conquer the settlements of Aylesbury, Benson, Eynsham and Limbury (according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle).
Wuffa becomes the first king of East Anglia, as recorded in the Anglo-Saxon royal genealogies (approximate date).

The Visigoths under King Liuvigild invade the Byzantine province of Spania (modern Andalusia), and seize the city of Córdoba.   After the death of his brother Liuva I, he becomes sole ruler of the Visigothic Kingdom (approximate date).
Benevento becomes the capital of an independent duchy, under the Lombard chieftain Zotto (approximate date).
The Monophysites again reject the Council of Chalcedon, causing another schism.
Theodric succeeds his brother Æthelric as king of Bernicia (southeastern Scotland). He rules until .

June  – Alboin, king of the Lombards, is murdered at Verona in his palace, at the instigation of his wife Rosamund (daughter of the Gepid king Cunimund), and her henchman, Helmechis (the king's squire); both flee to seek Byzantine protection in Ravenna. Alboin is succeeded as king by Cleph, who is not related by blood.
Calakmul defeats Tikal, bringing an end to the First Tikal-Calakmul War.
Bidatsu succeeds his father Kinmei and ascends to the throne of Japan as the 30th emperor.

Siege of Pavia (–): King Alboin captures Ticinum (Pavia); after a siege the Byzantine garrison surrenders to the Lombards. The city is of strategic importance, lying at the rivers Po and Ticino, and becomes the capital of the Kingdom of the Lombards.
Battle of Arfderydd: Leading his warband, Gwenddoleu ap Ceidio is slain by the sons of Eliffer, Gwrgi and Peredur. Myrddin Wyllt goes mad watching this defeat (according to the Annales Cambriae).
Pope John III is forced by the Lombards to retire from Rome, and takes up residence at the Catacombs along the Via Appia (approximate date).
The Lombards again raid Southern Gaul, but are defeated by the Franks under Mummolus, patricius and son of the Gallo-Roman count of Auxerre, and are driven out.

Byzantine–Sassanid War: Persian forces under the command of King Khosrau I capture the Byzantine stronghold of Dara, after a six-month siege. Meanwhile, a smaller Persian army under Adarmahan advances from Babylon through the desert, crosses the Euphrates River and ravages Syria. The cities of Apamea and Antiochia are plundered.
King Cleph completes the Lombard conquest of Tuscany (Central Italy) and extends his dominion to the gates of Ravenna.
Áedán mac Gabráin becomes king of Dál Riata (Scotland) (approximate Date).
Winter – Empress Sophia and Tiberius agree to a one year truce with the Persians, at the cost of , solidi. The truce applies only to the Mesopotamian front; in the Caucasus, war continues.
July  – Pope John III dies at Rome after a -year tenure. The Holy See becomes sede vacante until June of the following year.
The Visigoths under King Liuvigild invade Cantabria (Northern Spain), and destroy the city of Amaya (Burgos). He massacres the inhabitants and adds the province to the Visigothic Kingdom.
A major volcanic eruption occurs in the Antarctic.
Byzantine–Sassanid War: A Byzantine army under command of Maurice drives the Persians from Cappodocia (modern Turkey), and strengthens the Byzantine position in Caucasian Albania.
The Anglo-Saxon kingdom of East Anglia is divided into the English counties of Norfolk and Suffolk, and perhaps the eastern part of the Cambridgeshire Fens (approximate date).

The Convention of Druim Cett: Irish kings discuss the relationship between them and King Áedán mac Gabráin of Dál Riata. The Irish colony (now western Scotland) is confirmed, and rights to tax and levy are agreed to between the rulers.
Zhiyi, Chinese monk, travels to Mount Tiantai for intensive study and practice. He works with a group of disciples on the Indian meditation of śamatha and vipaśyanā.
June  – Pope Benedict I succeeds Pope John III as the 62nd pope.
Jinji becomes king of the Korean kingdom of Silla.

Byzantine–Sassanid War: A Persian army under King Khosrau I breaks through the Caucasus into Anatolia (modern Turkey). They attack the cities of Theodosiopolis and Caesarea, but are thwarted. Khosrau is forced to retreat and sacks Sebasteia. On the way home, he is intercepted by a Byzantine force under Justinian (magister militum of the East), and severely defeated near Melitene. The royal baggage is captured, and many Persians drown, while escaping across the Euphrates.
The Visigoths under King Liuvigild establish the capital of their kingdom in Toledo, located in central Spain (approximate date).
Baduarius, son-in-law of the Byzantine emperor Justin II, is sent to Italy to resist the Lombard conquest. He leads an aborted counter-assault against the Lombards and dies soon after.
The Göktürks under Tardu cross the Cimmerian Bosporus into the Crimea, and besiege the city of Panticapaeum (Ukraine).
Eutychius is restored as patriarch of Constantinople, after an exile of  years at Amasia (modern Turkey).
Reccopolis (modern Zorita de los Canes) in Hispania is founded by King Liuvigild, in honour of his son Reccared.

Battle of Deorham: The Anglo-Saxons under Ceawlin of Wessex invade the lower Severn Valley, and defeat the British Celts at Dyrham (South West England). After the battle, the Saxons occupy the three cities: Cirencester, Gloucester and Bath, bringing their advance to the Bristol Channel (according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle).
Summer – Tiberius, Byzantine co-ruler (Caesar), establishes a naval base at Derbent on the Caspian Sea to construct a Byzantine fleet (approximate date).
Muhammad, age , returns to his immediate family, but within a year his mother Aminah bint Wahb dies.
October  – Tzi-B'alam, who had been the ruler of the Mayan city state of Copán in Honduras, dies after a -year reign that began in May .
November  – K'ak' Chan Yopaat, becomes the new ruler of the Mayan city state of Copán in Honduras, and rules until his death  years later in .
Kongō Gumi, the world's oldest construction company (–), is founded in Osaka (Japan).

October  – Emperor Justin II dies after several periods of insanity. On the advice of his wife Sophia, he has raised his general Tiberius to the rank of co-emperor (Caesar). From December  he has ruled jointly with Sophia, and now succeeds them as emperor of the Byzantine Empire.
Summer – Emperor Wu Di engages in military campaigns on two fronts: against the invading Göktürks to the north and against the Chen dynasty in the south.
Leander, Catholic bishop of Seville, is exiled by Liuvigild and withdraws to Constantinople. At the Byzantine court he composes works against Arianism (approximate date).
Summer – Hormizd IV refuses to give up territories, and breaks off negotiations with the Byzantine Empire. The Türks invade Khorasan and reach Hyrcania on the Caspian Sea.
Khosrau I dies after a -year reign, during which he has extended his realm from the River Oxus to the Red Sea. He is succeeded by his son Hormizd IV, who becomes king of the Persian Empire.
Heavy taxes levied by Merovingian king Chilperic I of Neustria produce a revolt at Limoges (central France), as he sells bishoprics to the highest bidder.
Emperor Xuan Di abdicates the throne to his son Jing Di, age , and rules as regent the Northern Zhou dynasty.
King Liuvigild calls for an Arian synod in Toledo (central Spain), which modifies several doctrines; he tries to unify the Christians within the Visigothic Kingdom.
The Slavs begin to migrate into the Balkan Peninsula. The Avars, under King (khagan) Bayan I, invade the Lower Danube (modern Bulgaria).
Gregory of Tours is brought before a council of bishops, on charges of slandering the Frankish queen Fredegund (approximate date).
The Northern Zhou dynasty, strategically based in the basin of the Wei River, is supreme in Northern China. In the south only the Chen dynasty remains a rival.
Siege of Sirmium: The Avars march to the right bank of the River Sava, and besiege the Byzantine stronghold of Sirmium (Pannonia).
January —The last phase of Siege of Jerusalem began.
Military clash between the major Classical antiquity powers of Egypt and Babylon.
Battle of An: Jin defeats Qi; these two Chinese states later agree to an alliance.
Suizei becomes the second Emperor of Japan.
Nebuchadnezzar forces a third deportation of Jews from Judah into Babylonian captivity.
The Lombards under Zotto, Duke of Benevento, sack the abbey of Monte Cassino near Naples. The Benedictine monks who survive flee to Rome, but they return to the site, and rebuild the monastery.
The Göktürks under Taspar Qaghan besiege the city of Chersonesos Taurica (modern Ukraine), located at the Black Sea; their cavalry keep plundering the steppes of the Crimean Peninsula until .
Second Council of Mâcon: In a council of Christian bishops in Mâcon (Burgundy), Jews are prohibited from serving as judges or customs officers.
The Anglo-Saxons under Ælla conquer Deira (Northern England) from the Britons. He becomes the first king of Deira (according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle).
Maurice accuses Mundhir III of treason, and brings him to Constantinople to face trial. Emperor Tiberius II Constantine treats him well, and allows Mundhir with his family a comfortable residence.

Autumn – Maurice elevates John Mystacon to magister militum per Orientem. He sends a Byzantine expeditionary force to Arzanene (Armenia), where they fight a pitched battle at the river Nymphius (Batman River).
The Visigoths under King Liuvigild capture the city of Mérida (western central Spain), which is under the political control of its popular bishop Masona. He is arrested and exiled for  years.

August  – Emperor Tiberius II Constantine, age , dies (possibly from deliberately poisoned food) at Constantinople, after a -year reign during which Thrace and Greece have been inundated by the Slavs. He is succeeded by his son-in-law Maurice, former notary who has commanded the Byzantine army in the war against the Persian Empire.
Spring – Emperor Xuan of Chen, age , dies after a -year reign and is succeeded by his incompetent son Chen Shubao (Houzhu), who becomes the new ruler of the Chen dynasty.
Emperor Wen of the Sui dynasty orders the building of a new capital, which he calls Daxing (Great Prosperity), on a site southeast of Chang'an (modern Xi'an).
Muhammad, age , accompanies his uncle Abu Talib during trading journeys to Syria.

Emperor Maurice decides to end the annual tribute to the Avars, a mounted people who have swept across Russia and threatened the Balkan Peninsula. They capture the cities of Singidunum (modern Belgrade) and Viminacium (Moesia).
Yohl Ikʼnal succeeds Kan Bahlam I as queen of the Maya city of Palenque (Mexico).
Smallpox begins spreading from China to Japan and Korea (approximate date).
Eboric (also called Euric) succeeds his father Miro as king of the Suevi (Hispania Gallaecia).

The Lombards re-establish a unified monarchy after a -year interregnum (Rule of the Dukes). Threatened by a Frankish invasion that the dukes have provoked, they elect Authari (son of Cleph) as their king and give him the capital of Pavia (Northern Italy).
Emperor Wéndi of the Sui dynasty organises the Grand Canal. He builds ships for transportation and grain stores are located at strategic points.
King Eboric is deposed by his mother (second husband Andeca) who becomes the new ruler of the Kingdom of Galicia (Northern Spain) and the Suevi.

The Slavs push south on the Balkan Peninsula – partly in conjunction with the Avars under their ruler (khagan) Bayan I – ravaging the cities Athens and Corinth, and threatening the Long Walls of Constantinople.

September – King Chilperic I is stabbed to death while returning from a hunt near Chelles, after a -year reign over a territory extending from Aquitaine, to the northern seacoast of what later will be France.  His wife Fredegund, who has paid for his assassination, seizes his wealth, flees to Paris with her son Chlothar II, and persuades the nobles to accept him as legitimate heir while she serves as regent, continuing her power struggles with Guntram, king of Burgundy, and her sister Brunhilda, queen mother of Austrasia.
Emperor Xiao Jing Di succeeds his father Xiao Ming Di as ruler of the Liang dynasty (China).
Columbanus, Irish missionary, gathers  companions for his journey to Britain, probably to the Scottish coast. After a short time, he crosses the English Channel and lands in Brittany (France).
Creoda becomes king of Mercia (according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle).
Hussa succeeds his brother Frithuwald as king of Bernicia (approximate date).

King Wideok of Baekje (Korea) sends an official escort (bearing tribute), along with a master of Buddhist meditation, a reciter of Buddhist magic spells, a temple architect, and a sculptor of Buddhist images, to the Chinese court of the Sui dynasty (approximate date).
Spring – Emperor Maurice rejects a peace proposal of the Persians, in exchange for renewed payments in gold.
The Avars besiege Thessalonica (Central Macedonia), the second city of the Byzantine Empire.
Slavs advance to the gates of Thessaloniki and the Peloponnese.
The Page with the Crucifixion, from the "Rabbula Gospels", at the Monastery of St. John in Beth Zagba (Syria), is completed. It is now kept at the Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana, Florence, Italy.
Japanese Buddhism comes under attack as a "foreign" religion.
King Guntram sends envoys to Brittany, to stop the raiding on Frankish territory. He compels obedience from Waroch II and demands , solidus for looting Nantes.
Sledd succeeds his father Æscwine as king of Essex (approximate date).
The filioque clause is first used in the Nicene Creed, against the Arians in Visigothic Spain (approximate date).
November  – Treaty of Andelot: Guntram recognizes King Childebert II of Austrasia as heir. He signs a treaty with Queen Brunhilda at Andelot-Blancheville.
Comentiolus, Byzantine general (magister militum), assembles an army of , men at Anchialus (modern Bulgaria). He prepares an ambush for the Avars in the Haemus Mountains.
Emperor Wéndi of the Sui dynasty prepares a campaign against the Chen dynasty. He amasses , troops along the northern bank of the Yangtze River, stretching from Sichuan to the Pacific Ocean.
Byzantine-Sassanid War: Unpaid Byzantine troops mutiny against Priscus (magister militum per Orientem). King Hormizd IV begins a Persian offensive, but is defeated at Martyropolis (modern Turkey).
The Lombard Kingdom (Italy) is converted to Roman Catholicism under the rule of King Authari (approximate date).
The Franks and Burgundians under King Guntram and his nephew Childebert II invade Northern Italy, but suffer a disastrous defeat against the Lombards.

Summer – Guaram I of Iberia, Georgian prince in exile, is sent by Emperor Maurice to the city of Mtskheta (Georgia). He restores the monarchy and is bestowed with the Byzantine court title of curopalates.
May  – King Authari marries Theodelinda, daughter of the Bavarian duke Garibald I. A Catholic, she has great influence at court and among the Lombard nobility.
Byzantine–Sassanid War: A Persian army under Bahrām Chobin captures the fortress city of Martyropolis (modern Turkey).
The Council of Narbonne is held. In Septimania, Jews are forbidden from chanting psalms while burying their dead.
King Guntram sends an expedition into Septimania (Southern Gaul), in support of a rebellion by the Arian bishop Athaloc.

The Chinese Empire is reunited under the leadership of Emperor Wéndi (Sui dynasty), who defeats the Chen forces at Jiankang (modern Nanjing), ending the Chen dynasty (the last of the Southern dynasties) that has ruled since .
Comentiolus, commander (magister militum) of the eastern army, receives the legitimate Persian king, Khosrau II, as a refugee in his headquarters at Hierapolis.
Gregory I begins a vigorous program of rebuilding aqueducts and restoring Rome. He feeds the citizens with doles of grain, as under Roman imperial rule.
Kadungon becomes king of the Pandyan Kingdom in South India (approximate date).
The Franks and Burgundians under King Guntram invade Italy. They capture the cities Milan and Verona, but are forced to leave by a plague outbreak in the Po Valley.
John of Biclaro, Visigoth chronicler, finishes his "Chronicle" before he is appointed bishop of Girona (Catalonia, Spain).
March , —Babylonians capture Jerusalem following a siege, replace Jeconiah with Zedekiah as king, and send many Jews (including Ezekiel) into Babylonian captivity.
Early history of Sudan: An Egyptian army sacks Napata, compelling the Cushite court to move to a more secure location at Meroë near the sixth cataract of the Nile.
Kamarina is founded in Sicily (traditional date).
Jeconiah succeeds Jehoiakim as King of Judah.
Exile of Sappho and Alcaeus (Alkaios) of Mytilene in Sicily.
A locust swarm destroys the harvest in Northern Italy (approximate date).

Khosrau II is reinstalled as king of the Persian Empire. Peace with Constantinople is concluded after a war of almost  years. Maurice receives the Persian provinces of Armenia and Georgia. The recognition of the traditional frontiers, and the cessation of subsidies for the Caucasus forts, leaves the Byzantines in a dominant position in their relations with Persia.

Summer – Maurice begins a series of military expeditions, to defend the Balkan provinces from the Avars and Slavs. He establishes the Danube frontier (Limes Moesiae) from the Delta to the fortress city of Singidunum (Belgrade), and permits the Byzantines to reassert their authority in the interior.
The first city wall of Hangzhou (Eastern China) is constructed.
May  – A Mesoamerican ballgame court is dedicated at the Mayan city of Chinkultic (Mexico).
Gregory, bishop of Tours, completes his Historia Francorum ("History of the Franks").
Winter – Empress Suiko moves the imperial capital of Japan to Asuka-Toyura Palace (Nara Prefecture) during the Asuka period.

January  – King Guntram, age , dies after a -year reign, and is succeeded by his nephew Childebert II, who becomes ruler of Burgundy. He is buried at Saint Marcellus of Chalons Church, in Chalon-sur-Saône (Eastern France).

Emperor Maurice regains the Byzantine stronghold Singidunum (modern Belgrade) from the Avars. By counter-invading their homelands on the Balkans, Byzantine troops increase their pay by pillaging in hostile territory.

Summer – Emperor Wéndi reduces taxes, due to an overflowing abundance of food and silk in the governmental stores. He sends messengers around central China, redistributing land to give the poor farming land.

Autumn – Emperor Maurice orders Priscus to spend the winter with his troops on the northern Danube bank, but he disobeys the emperor's order and retreats to the port city of Odessus (Varna) on the Black Sea Coast.
Pybba succeeds his father Creoda as king of Mercia (approximate date).
The Persian usurper Hormizd V (who rises temporarily to power) is defeated by King Khosrau II.

Empress Suiko begins a long reign during a pivotal period, in which Buddhism influences the development and culture of Japan. She is the first female ruler and the first to receive official recognition from China.
The Shitennō-ji monastery is founded at Osaka (Japan) by Shōtoku.
Approximate date – Pope Gregory I publishes his Dialogues.
Autumn – Emperor Maurice replaces general Priscus for disobeying orders. He installs his inexperienced brother Peter, as commander-in-chief in charge of the war against the Avars.
Amos succeeds John IV  as Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem.
