July  – Reconquista: In Spain, the army of the Crown of Castile, led by Álvaro de Luna, defeats the Moors of the Emirate of Granada, led by the Sultan Muhammad IX, in the Battle of La Higueruela, fought at Vega de Granada.

January  –
Yusuf IV is placed on the throne as the new Sultan of Granada, after Muhammad IX is deposed with the support of King Juan II of Castile and Leon. Yusuf dies later in the year and Muhammad IX is restored to the throne a third time
Iliaș succeeds his father as Prince of Moldavia.
September  – The Ses of Aragon defeating the soldiers of Ifriqiya.
October  – Grand Duke Sigismund of Lithuania signs a document at Grodno (now part of Belarus swearing his loyalty to Poland.

January  – The siege of Pouancé is undertaken by John V, Duke of Brittany, against his nephew Jean II, Duke of Alençon, as part of a conflict involving the payment of a dowry. The siege lasts until February  when Alençon surrenders.
The first baccalaureate service is believed to have originated at the University of Oxford.
Kalantiaw (of what would later be known as the Philippines) supposedly promulgates the legal code eventually referred to as the Code of Kalantiaw. Modern historians doubt its existence.
May  – The Regency Council for King Henry VI summons the members of Parliament to assemble at Westminster on July .

July  – Admiral Zheng He and the crew of the seventh Ming Chinese overseas expedition return to China, arriving at Beijing two and one half years after their departure on January ,  from Nanjing.  With the completion of the maritime expedition, the fleet is dispersed, altering the balance of power in the Indian Ocean, and making it easier for Portugal and other Western naval powers to gain dominance over the seas.

September  – Cosimo de' Medici, later the unofficial leader of Florence and patron of Marsilio Ficino, is imprisoned in the Palazzo dei Priori. Initially facing life imprisonment, Medici is then exiled by the Albizzi/Strozzi faction instead. He returns a year later, on October , .
July  – The English Parliament assembles at Westminster, and Roger Hunt is elected as Speaker of the House of Commons.

August – Portuguese explorer Gil Eanes and his crew sail around the dangerous Cape Bojador of North Africa (off of Western Sahara) and survive, becoming the first Europeans to make the voyage and ending the legends about what lies on the other side of the "Dark Sea". The achievement is a breakthrough in trade between Europe and Asia.
February  – In India, Mubarak Shah II, the Sultan of Delhi, is assassinated. His nephew, Muhammad Shah IV becomes the new Sultan.

January  – (Rajab ,  AH) King Alfonso V of Aragon ruler of the Kingdom of Sicily as well, contracts with tapestry weaver Guillem d'Uxelles to Flanders to begin learning the Flemish methods to be duplicated in Spain, beginning the "Hispano-Flemish" style.

July – In the Kingdom of León in Spain, Suero de Quiñones and his companions stage the Passo Honroso, at the bridge across the Órbigo River near Santiago de Compostela. Any knight attempting to cross the bridge is challenged to a joust by the Quiñones knights. The challenge continues for the next  days.
October  – The University of Catania is founded in Italy.
Francis of Paola founds the Order of the Minims in Italy.

December  – As the English Parliament closes, King Henry VI's regents give royal assent to new legislation, including the Safe Conducts Act , the Wools and Fells Act (directing that wool not be exported from England to any other location except Calais), and the Alien Goods Act (subtitled "Merchandises taken in Ships of the King's Enemies, though belonging to Foreigners in Amity with the King, shall not be restored")
Gil Eanes and Afonso Gonçalves Baldaia explore the coast of Africa, as far as the Angra dos Ruivos (in modern-day Western Sahara).

January  – Sweden's first Riksdag of the Estates is summoned under rebel leader Engelbrekt Engelbrektsson, who is elected rikshövitsman (military commander of the realm), in the absence of a king, on January .
China returns to a policy of isolation.

In Ming dynasty China, a significant portion of the southern grain tax is commuted to payments in silver, known as the Gold Floral Silver (jinhuayin). This comes about due to officials' and military generals' increasing demands to be paid in silver instead of grain, as commercial transactions draw more silver into nationwide circulation. Some counties have trouble transporting all the required grain to meet their tax quotas, so it makes sense to pay the government in silver, a medium of exchange that is already abundant amongst landowners, through their own private commercial affairs.

The Florentine polymath Leon Battista Alberti begins writing the treatise On Painting, in which he argues for the importance of mathematical perspective, in the creation of three-dimensional vision on a two-dimensional plane. This follows the ideas of Masaccio, and his concepts of linear perspective and vanishing point in artwork.

December  – King Charles VII of France arrives at Lyon to personally begin an inquiry into the rebellion that had lasted in the city for two months, ending on June , . Ultimately, three rebels are executed and  others are permanently banished from Lyon.
September  – Eric of Pomerania is once again reinstated as king of Sweden. Karl Knutsson, at the same time, resigns the post of rikshövitsman.
Date of the Visokom papers, the last direct sources on the old town of Visoki.
Ulugh Beg's Zij-i Sultani star catalogue is published.
December  – King Henry VI reaches the age of majority on his 16th birthday and is deemed ready to rule the Kingdom of England in his own right.
October  – After negotiating a surrender and exchanging prisoners of war with the Moroccans, the Portuguese troops leave Tangier and sail away from Morocco.

March  – In Scotland, Walter Stewart, Earl of Atholl, at one time the heir presumptive to the Scottish throne until the birth of James II, is brutally executed for the assassination of King James I. A red hot iron crown placed upon his head, after which he is cut into pieces while still alive and his heart was taken out, after which his body is thrown into a fire.

January – The Compacts of Basel are ratified by the Council of Basel in Switzerland, as the Roman Catholic Church ends its campaign against the Hussites. Among other things, the Church authorizes Hussite priests to administer sacramental wine to their congregations as part of the Communion during the Eucharist before Easter without declaring the same to be heresy, but stops short of allowing the Communion wafer.

November  – Following approval by the General Council of Scotland, regents for King James II of Scotland give royal assent to the Inquisitions in Last Reign Act, providing for the continuation of any inquisition by the Roman Catholic Church for heresy that had been started prior to the assassination of King James I.

August  – The reign of Friedrich I von Helfenstein as Count of Helfenstein (in the modern-day German state of Baden-Württemberg) ends after  years. Friedrich and his brothers Conrad and Ulrich had become joint rulers in  on the death of their father, Ulrich XIII, but Ulrich IX and Conrad I had died in  and , respectively. Friedrich's three sons become the joint rulers.

October  – At Mandore (part of the modern-day state of Rajasthan in India), Rao Ranmal, King of Marwar is assassinated after becoming drunk during the festival of Diwali, when one of his wives, Bharmali, ties him up and opens his bedroom door to admit a team of assassins. Ranmal's son, Rao Jodha, becomes the new King.

December  – The siege of Brescia in Italy, started on September  by troops of the Duchy of Milan under condottieri Niccolò Piccinino to liberate the city from its control by the Republic of Venice, is raised after the arrival of Scaramuccia da Forlì. According to tradition, two Brescian martyrs from the second century, Saints Faustinus and Jovita, appear on the top of the city walls and repel the cannonballs fired at the city, and the Milanese abandon the siege.
September  – Afonso V becomes King of Portugal upon the death of his father King Duarte I.

March  – Meeting in Germany, the Diet of Mainz, summoned by the new Holy Roman Emperor, Frederick III, to consider the case of Pope Eugene IV, votes to deprive Eugene of his authority within the Empire and to elect a new Diet to meet in Frankfurt in .

June  – Joseph II, the leader of the Eastern Orthodox Church as the 155th Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, dies after a reign of  years, leaving a vacancy that is used by the Roman Catholic Pope Eugene IV to declare a unification of the two churches to end the East–West Schism of .
September  – King Henry VI of England summons the English Parliament, directing all members to assemble at Westminster on November .
Beginning of the settlement of the Azores with the arrival of the first Portuguese settlers in Santa Maria.
June  – The Council of Basel formally declares that Pope Eugene IV is deposed.
Casimir IV Jagiellon is proclaimed as the new Grand Duke of Lithuania by the Lithuanian Council of Lords.
February–June – The Praguerie, an uprising by the French nobility against King Charles VII.
Uwaifiokun, Oba of Benin, is killed by his brother, the Prince Ogun, who succeeds him as Ewuare I.
March  – The Prussian Confederation is formed by  nobles and clergy, representing  Prussian cities, who meet at Elblag to form an opposition to the Teutonic Knights.

November  – Charles, Duke of Orléans, is released from incarceration in England,  years after he had been taken as a prisoner of war at the Battle of Agincourt in . His freedom is gained after negotiations made by two of his former enemies, the Duke of Burgundy and the Queen of Portugal, and payment of a ransom of , gold coins. The Duke of Orleans, now aged , returns to French soil after more than a quarter of a century in England.
The Book of Leviticus is written.
Fíachu Labrainne, Milesians' High King of Ireland, is killed and succeeded by Eochu Mumu
: The Gnbtyw people (Genebtyw or Genebtyu) first appear in Ganibatum during the 32nd year of the reign of Thutmose III, the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt
: first recorded urban settlement on or near Mount Yamanlar which controlled the Gulf of İzmir
A revolt occurs in the Mayan nation of Mayapan; the Maya civilization splits into warring city-states.
November  – Alfonso V of Aragon lays siege to Naples.

October  – In accordance with the proposals for the Peace of Cremona to end the war between Venice and Milan, Francesco I Sforza of Venice marries Bianca Maria Visconti, daughter of the Duke of Milan. An Italian tradition credits the creation of nougat to the celebration of the wedding.
February  – Luchuan–Pingmian campaigns: The second campaign against the Mong Mao state is launched.
December  – ( Sha'ban  AH) Ali ibn Hasan ibn Ajlan takes office as the new Emir of Mecca.

December  – In Italy Tomaso di Campofregoso, Doge of the Republic of Genoa, is removed from office by a group of armed men, led by Raffaele Adorno and  Giovanni Antonio Fieschi, who invade the Ducal Palace and force him to leave.
Jelena Balšić completes writing the Gorički zbornik manuscripts at her church of St. Mary, on the island of Beška in the Serbian Despotate.
June  – After a six-month siege, King Alfonso of Aragon proclaims himself King of Naples. Alfonso allows the French ruler, King René of Anjou, to return to France.

January  – Two months after the death of the Burmese King Minye Kyawswa I of Ava, his brother-in-law Thihapate of Mohnyin turns down an offer to rule the kingdom, and recommends that Kyswswa's younger brother, Thihathu, Viceroy of Prome, become the new King.
August  – Fransez I becomes the new Duke of Brittany upon the death of his father, Yann V. Princess Isabella of Scotland, who had been part of a contract to marry Jean V, arranges to marry Francis I
November  – Skanderbeg and his forces, rebelling against the Ottoman Empire, liberate Krujë, in Middle Albania, and raise the Albanian flag.
September  – Pope Eugene IV returns to Rome for the first time in more than nine years, after having been forced to flee on June , .
February  – The Spanish monarch, King Alfonso V of Aragon, makes a triumphant entrance into the city of Naples in order to assume the throne of the Kingdom of Naples.

December  – King Sejong the Great of Korea announces the creation of the Hunminjeongeum (literally "The Proper Sounds for the Instruction of the People") a manual for Hangul, a standardized writing system for the Korean language.
June  – Afonso V of Aragon formally reunites the Kingdoms of Naples and Sicily.
August  – The Peace of Szeged is signed between the Turkish Ottoman Empire and Hungary.
Forces of the Sultan of Egypt fail to take Rhodes from the Knights of Rhodes.
The Iguvine Tablets are discovered at Gubbio, Italy.
March  – The League of Lezhë, an alliance of Albanian principalities, is established in Lezhë; George Kastrioti Skanderbeg is proclaimed commander of the Albanian resistance.
August  – A Portuguese fleet of caravels, led by Lançarote de Freitas, lands  slaves at Algarve, Portugal.
Stephen II remains sole ruler of Moldavia.

December  – At a monastery in Neuwerk in Halle, with the mediation of the Landgrave Louis II of Hesse, the Archbishop Frederick III of Magdeburg, and the Margrave Frederick II of Brandenburg, William III, Duke of Luxembourg and his brother Frederick II, Elector of Saxony, the two surviving sons of Frederick I, Elector of Saxony, make a final attempt to agree on the division of lands in Thuringia which they had inherited from their father's cousin, Frederick IV, Landgrave of Thuringia. Despite the mediation, Frederick of Saxony and William of Luxembourg are not able to agree and the Saxon Fratricidal War begins a few months later.
February  – The English Parliament is opened by King Henry IV. On the first day, the House of Commons elects William Burley as its Speaker.
April  – King Henry VI  of England marries Margaret of Anjou, daughter of René of Anjou, the former King of Naples, at a ceremony at Titchfield Abbey in Hampshire.

September  – Đurađ Branković, Despot of Serbia, and his sons Grgur, Stefan and Lazar sign a charter confirming the sovereignty and privileges of the Republic of Ragusa, located in what is now Croatia.
December  – King Henry VI summons the English Parliament to assemble at Cambridge on February .

August  – After many years of fruitless negotiations between Christopher of Bavaria and Eric of Pomerania, a Swedish war march to Gotland is launched in the early summer of . King Christopher comes with a force to the island and on an open field in Västergarn with crossbowmen at gunpoint behind each monarch's back; regular peace negotiations take place.

April  – In England, Thomas de Ashton and Edmund de Trafford, both knights of Lancashire, are granted special dispensation by King Henry VI to use their research in alchemy to transmute substances into precious metals.

February  – Vasily II, the Grand Prince of Moscow and ruler of much of Russia, is kidnapped from Trinity Monastery the Kremlin by allies of his cousin, Dmitry Shemyaka. Four days later (February ), the conspirators tear out the eyes of Grand Prince Vasily and send him into exile at Uglich with his wife.

January  – The Battle of Arbroath takes place in Scotland as the monks of the Abbey of Arbroath dismiss Alexander Lindsay, son of the Earl of Crawford, from the position of Bailie of the Regality, and replace him with Alexander Ogilvy, Baron of Inverquharity. Lindsay attacks the abbey with fellow members of his own Clan Lindsay and the assistance of Clan Hamilton, while Ogilvy is supported by Clan Oliphant, Clan Seton, Clan Gordon and Clan Forbes. The Earl of Crawford, seeking to avert the battle, rides his horse to the battlefield in hopes of conferring with Ogilvy, but is killed by a member of Ogilvy's infantry. In the battle that follows, Clan Lindsay prevails and Ogilvy is killed.

June  – Kazimieras Jogailaitis, Grand Duke of Lithuania since , is crowned King of Poland as Casimir IV Jagiellon, bringing an end to an interregnum that had existed since  when Casimir's brother King Wladyslaw III had left Poland to fight in a Crusade against the Ottoman Turks.

March  – The papal conclave opens at the Santa Maria sopra Minerva in Rome with  of the  living members of the College of Cardinals arriving to select a new Pope With  votes necessary for the require two-thirds needed for an election, Cardinal Prospero Colonna receives  and Cardinal Domenico Capranica gets .

February  – Humphrey, Duke of Gloucester, uncle and heir apparent of King Henry VI of England, is arrested on a charge of treason. He dies from a stroke three days later while imprisoned at Bury St Edmunds in Suffolk Richard of York becomes next in line for the throne.

March  – On the fourth vote of the papal conclave, Prospero Colonna is still unable to gain more than  votes, and Cardinal Capranica addresses the group, warning that Rome would be under attack from the King of Aragon. At the intervention of Cardinal Giovanni Berardi, the cardinals begin voting for a compromise candidate, Tommaso Parentucelli, who wins  votes. Parentucelli then takes the regnal name of Pope Nicholas V, the 208th Bishop of Rome and Pope.

April  – Abdal-Latif Mirza, son of the recently-crowned Timurid Emperor Ulugh Beg, is defeated in battle at Nishapur by his cousin Ala al-Dawla Mirza, another claimant to the Timurid throne, shortly after Abdal-Latif had captured the city of Damghan and al-Dawla had conquered Mashad.

June  – The regency of Portugal ends as Dom Pedro, Duke of Coimbra, as King Afonso V, now , dismisses his uncle who had served as regent for almost  years after the death of King Duarte in . Influenced by Afonso de Braganza, King Afonso begins nullification of all of the decrees made in his name by Dom Pedro.
September  – Prince George of Poděbrady, leader of the Hussites in Bohemia (now the Czech Republic) captures Prague after leading , of his troops from Kutná Hora.
June  – The Regency period of Sweden ends with the election by Swedish nobles of Karl Knutsson Bonde as King Karl VIII.
July  – The League of Lezhë, made up of the armies of various Albanian principalities, defeats the forces of the Venetian Republic and the Ottoman Empire at the battle of Scutari.
April  – Queens' College, Cambridge is founded by Margaret of Anjou.

July  – News arrives at the imperial court of the Emperor Yingzong of China of a Mongol invasion from the north, led by the Khagan Esen Taishi. Yingzong orders the dispatch of , soldiers from the Beijing garrison, led by four generals, to advance to Datong and Xuanfu to guard the border.
March  – Hundred Years' War: English forces capture Fougères in Brittany.
April  – The Council of Basel dissolves itself.
October  – Prince Alexăndrel is replaced as Prince of Moldavia by Bogdan II.
April  – The last Antipope, Felix V, abdicates.
August  – Cherbourg, the last English territory in Normandy, surrenders to the French.

September  – China's Emperor Yingzong returns to Beijing after having been held as a prisoner of war by the Mongols since September , . Upon returning, he is held under house arrest in the Forbidden City along with his wife, the Empress Qian, on orders of his younger brother Emperor Daizong.
July  – Caen surrenders to the French.
October  – Jews are expelled from Lower Bavaria, by order of Duke Ludwig IX.
March  – Colonization of Terceira Island by Portugal begins as Dom Henrique, om Navigador (known in English accounds as "Prince Henry the Navigator" assigns jurisdiction to Jácome de Bruges.
– BCE—Minoan Second Palace period ends and Late Minoan/Final Palace culture.
BCE—Mycenaeans attack and capture Crete, destroying many royal palaces including Knossos.

Battle of Megiddo ( BC) between Thutmose III and a coalition under the King of Kadesh. It is the first battle to have been recorded in what is accepted as relatively reliable detail. The battle took place in year  I Shemsu day  (or possibly day ). The exact year depends on the year Thutmose ascended to the throne of Egypt and among scholars the estimates range from  to  BCE. Using the  BCE estimate the battle could have taken place in May  BCE.
BCE—According to James Ussher's chronology, this is when the Israelites entered the Promised Land.
August  – The French capture Bayonne, the last English stronghold in Guyenne.

December  – ( Zilhicce  AH) In Mamluk ruled Egypt, the Amir Asanbay al-Jamali al-Zahiri returns from a trip to the Ottoman Empire with a group of Ottoman diplomats, and the Mamluk Sultan Mehmed II hosts them at a banquet, granting them a private audience the next day. The Ottomans depart on January .
October  – Revolt of Ghent: Ghent takes up arms against Philip the Good, Duke of Burgundy.
February  – Murad II, Sultan of the Ottoman Empire, dies and is succeeded (on February ) by his son, Mehmed II.

November  – At the Korean capital, Hanseong, Hwangbo In becomes the Chief State Councillor (Yeonguijeong) of the Kingdom of Korea as leader of the governing State Council, second in status only to King Munjong, replacing Ha Yeon.
August  (25th day of 7th month of Hōtoku  – The Kyōtoku era is proclaimed in Japan during the reign of the Emperor Go-Hanazono.
September  – Pope Matthew II of Alexandria is elected as the new Patriarch of the Coptic Christian Church, succeeding Pope John XI, who died on May .
February – Alexăndrel retakes the throne of Moldavia, in his long struggle with Petru Aron.
May  – Pope John XI of Alexandria, leader of the Coptic Christian church since , dies, leaving a vacancy in the Coptic papacy.
November  – The Canton of Appenzell becomes an associate member of the Swiss Confederacy. Full membership will be granted more than  years later in .

October  – At the Battle of Kruševac, the Serbian Army, commanded by General Skobaljić with the assistance of troops from John Hunyadi and Đurađ Branković, destroys Ottoman invaders commanded by Feriz Beg.
May  – King Casimir IV of Poland receives an oath of allegiance from the citizens of Toruń and other cities in the Chelmno area.
July  – At Valladolid, Enrique IV is proclaimed as the new King of Castile on the day after the death of his father,  King Juan II.
June  – In Poland, the landholders and bishops of Eblag pledge allegiance to King Casimir IV, and Gdańsk follows on June .
Ulrich II, Count of Celje becomes the new Ban of Slavonia upon the death of his father, Frederick II.

January  – Pope Nicholas V publishes Romanus Pontifex, an encyclical addressed to King Afonso V of Portugal, which sanctions the conquest of non-Christian lands, and the reduction of native non-Christian populations to 'perpetual slavery'. (Later there will be a dramatic reversal when, in , the bull Sublimis Deus of Pope Paul III forbids the enslavement of non-Christians.)
August  – Prince Sejo, son of the late King Sejong, becomes the new monarch of Korea in Hanseong following the forced abdication of King Danjong.

June  – In Egypt, the Sultan Sayf al-Din Inal confronts a revolt of  of his ethnic Circassian slave-troops (mamluks) after rejecting the soldiers' requests for camels to accompany them on an expedition against Bedouin invaders in the Nile Delta. After attempting to assassinate the Sultan's secretary, Yunus al-Aqba'i, the rebels join discontented Zahiri troops and besieged the Cairo Citadel. Facing a withdrawal of support from the Egyptian Caliph, the Sultan eventually meets the rebels' demands.

October  – Threatened with an invasion by the Ottoman Empire, the Principality of Moldavia sends its first tribute to the Ottoman Sultan, paying , ducats (equivalent to . kilograms (. lb) of gold) in response to an ultimatum.

September  – Pope Calixtus III decides to send Christians on a crusade against the Ottoman Empire in an attempt to recapture Constantinople. At a ceremony at St. Peter's Basilica in Rome, the Pope provides Cardinal Alain de Coëtivy with the crusader's cross and sends him on a mission to meet with King Charles VII of France in hopes of getting French support for the proposed crusade.

October  – The University of Greifswald is established, making it the second oldest university in Northern Europe. Due to border changes, from  to  it is the oldest in Sweden, and from  to  the oldest in Prussia.
Petru Aron becomes the first ruler of Moldavia to pay tribute to the Ottomans.
June   – Halley's Comet makes an appearance, as noted by the humanist scholar Platina.
May  – Second Battle of Oronichea (): Ottoman Forces of , are sent to capture Albania, but are met and swiftly defeated by Skanderbeg's smaller forces.
September  – Pope Calixtus III issues a papal bull granting a seven-year indulgence to any Christian who makes a pilgrimage to Our Lady of the Pillar in Zaragoza in Spain's Kingdom of Aragon

March  – At the age of , Mirza Shah Mahmud briefly becomes the Sultan of the Timurid Empire upon the death at Mashhad of the Sultan Abul-Qasim Babur Mirza. Shah Mahmud is overthrown a few weeks later by his cousin Ibrahim Mirza.
January  – Jan IV, Duke of Oświęcim, sells the duchy to the Kingdom of Poland.
June  – Christian I is elected king of Sweden, ending the war between Sweden and Denmark and restoring the Kalmar Union.
Edo Castle is built by Ōta Dōkan in modern-day Tokyo.
December  – Pope Calixtus III declares Albanian hero Skanderbeg to be a Captain-General of the Holy See and gives him the title Athleta Christi ("Champion of Christ").
October  – King Afonso V of Portugal conquers the area around Ksar es-Seghir in the Sultanate of Morocco, led by Sultan Abd al-Haqq II.
February  – Stefan Branković, blind since , becomes the Despot of Serbia upon the death of his brother, Lazar Branković.
December  – François II becomes the new Duke of Brittany upon the death of his uncle Arthur de Richemont.
November  – (6th waxing of Nadaw  ME) Min Khayi, ruler of the Burmese Kingdom of Arakan leads a successful defense of an invasion from the Shan State by his son, Prince Min Swe.
March  – The Loveday is staged in London, by which Henry VI of England attempts to unite the warring factions who have triggered the Wars of the Roses.

October  – Wars of the Roses: With a royal force advancing on his fortress at Ludlow, Richard Plantagenet, Duke of York, flees to Ireland, while his ally Richard Neville, 16th Earl of Warwick (Warwick the Kingmaker, eldest son of the Earl of Salisbury) goes to Calais.
February  – Frederick III, Holy Roman Emperor and Archduke of Austria, proclaims himself to be rightful King of Hungary and prepares to invade the kingdom in order to overthrow King Mathias Corvinus.
September  – Wars of the Roses: At the Battle of Blore Heath in the Kingdom of England, Yorkists under Richard Neville, 5th Earl of Salisbury, defeat a Lancastrian force.
November  – Pope Pius II issues the papal bull Inter Ceteras, founding the University of Basel in Switzerland, though the university does not begin operations until April  the following year.

December  – England's "Parliament of Devils" is dissolved after accomplishhing its purpose of passing bills of attainder for high treason, indictments of  Richard of York, 3rd Duke of York and other Yorkist supporters in the War of the Roses. Other prominent Yorkists charges are Edward, Earl of March (the future King Edward IV), Edmund, Earl of Rutland, Richard Neville, 5th Earl of Salisbury, and his son, Richard Neville, 16th Earl of Warwick.
October  – Richard, Duke of York enters the Council Chamber, places his hand upon the throne, and announces that he is the rightful King of England. He then takes up residence at the royal palace.

March  – King Christian I of Denmark, the various nobles of the Duchy of Schleswig and the County of Holstein agree to the Treaty of Ribe, electing King Christian as the new Duke of Schleswig and Count of Holstein, and placing both political entities under Denmark's control.
July  – The town of Marienburg is captured by the Polish army after a four-month siege that had been started by General Proandota Lubieszowski, who had died during the fighting.

August  – King James II of Scotland is killed by the explosion of a cannon which he had purchased from Flanders as part of acquiring the most up-to-date military technology for Scotland. The King had been supervising the bombardment of Roxburgh Castle during a siege to force out the English occupation troops. Historian Robert Lindsay of Pitscottie later writes "as the King stood near a piece of artillery, his thigh bone was dug in two with a piece of misframed gun that brake in shooting, by which he was stricken to the ground and died hastily.  He is succeeded by his -year-old son, who becomes King James III, with power exercised by the boy's mother, the Queen Regent Mary of Guelders.
July  – The city of London opens its gates to the Yorkist invaders and puts up no resistance to their occupation.
In the Battle of Megiddo, Egypt defeats Canaan. It is the first battle recorded in history.
Thutmose III encounters the Mitanni in his conquest.

October  – With the Yorkist victory in the War of the Roses, the proposal by the new English King, Edward IV for an alliance with Scottish nobles against the former King Henry VI is approved by Scottish Highland lords at Ardtornish Castle. The agreement will become the basis for the Treaty of Westminster four months later on February , .

July – The last remnant of the Byzantine Empire is lost to the Ottomans as General Graitzas Palaiologos honourably surrenders Salmeniko Castle, the last garrison of the Despotate of the Morea, to invading forces after a year-long siege.
July  – Stephen Tomašević becomes the last King of Bosnia, on the death of his father Stephen Thomas.
November  – The coronation of Stephen Tomašević as the King of Bosnia takes place at Saint Mary's Church at Jajce.
March  – Edward, Duke of York, son of the late Richard of York and heir to the English throne, seizes London, and proclaims himself King Edward IV.

April  – Matthias Corvinus, King of Hungary, and Frederick III, Holy Roman Emperor, come to an agreement to return the Crown of St. Stephen to Hungary in return for payment of , florins, and recognizing Matthias as King.

April  – Bishop Antony Kokkas becomes the new Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, succeeding the late Patriarch Isidore II as leader of the Eastern Orthodox Christians in the Ottoman Empire. He takes the name Ioasaf I.
October  – Adolph II of Nassau captures the town of Mainz and ends the Mainz Diocesan Feud, then carries a massacre of more than  citizens.

April  – Pope Pius II issues the papal bull Cum almam nostram urbem prohibiting the destruction or removal of the ancient ruins in Rome and Campagna or the burning of ancient marble for lime, with violators subject to excommunication.

January  – The conflict in Poland over who should be the bishop of Krakow — Pope Pius II's appointee Jakub of Sienno or King Casimir IV's pick, Jan Gruszczynski — Pope Pius sends his legate, the Archbishop of Crete Hieronymus Landus, to negotiate a compromise that ultimately ends with Jakub being recognized by King Casimir as Bishop.<
Corpus Hermeticum is translated into Latin, by Marsilio Ficino.

October  – Pope Pius II issues the papal bull Ezechielis prophetae, offering an indulgence to any Christians who take part in a crusade against the Ottoman Empire for at least six months or who donate funds to support it.
June  – The free imperial city of Rottweil, part of the Holy Roman Empire and now a part of Germany, becomes an associate state of the Swiss Confederacy.
September  – Pope Pius II calls for all Christians to participate in a crusade against the Ottoman Empire.
February  – At the University of Cambridge in England, Henry Abyngdon becomes the first person in the world to receive a degree of Bachelor of Music

September  – King Edward IV of England surprises his advisors and the nation by introducing Elizabeth Woodville as his wife at Reading Abbey, and revealing that he had been married for almost five months, the ceremony having taken place on May . The marriage outrages King Edward's mentor, Richard Neville, 16th Earl of Warwick, who had been arranging a marriage between the King and Bona of Savoy, sister-in-law of France's King Louis XI.

November  – Filip I is appointed by the Grand Duke of Moscow as the new List of metropolitans and patriarchs of Moscow, leader of the Russian Orthodox Church, after the September  death of the Patriarch Theodosius.
August  – Emperor Go-Hanazono of Japan abdicates, and is succeeded by his son, Emperor Go-Tsuchimikado.

February  – After leading the Ottoman Empire's conquest of his native Bosnia, General Isa-beg Isaković becomes the first Ottoman Governor of Bosnia. The province will remain under Turkish control for more than  years until .

March  – Pope Pius II excommunicates the entire town of Prudnik (now part of Poland and its Roman Catholic inhabitants for its failure to pay its share of the debts owed to the Duke of Oels, Konrad IV the Elder.Tadeusz Kwaśniewski, ( August ).

July  – Henry of Lancaster, the former King Henry VI of England, is imprisoned in the Tower of London by order of King Edward IV. His queen consort Margaret of Anjou and Edward of Westminster, Prince of Wales, have fled to France.

March  – Queens' College, Cambridge, dormant since , is re-established on the campus of the University of Cambridge by the queen consort of England, Elizabeth Woodville, with the official name of "the College of St. Margaret and St. Bernard in the University of Cambridge."
September  – King Ferrante of Naples creates the award Order of the Ermine (L’Ordre de l’Hermine)
September  – With the approval by the Holy Roman Emperor Friedrich III, the Bohemian captain Hinko Tannfeld to plunder the Hungarian town of Sopron.
February  – In the Catalan Civil War, the Battle of Calaf is fought and Pedro V, the self-proclaimed King of Aragon, is defeated near Barcelona by the legitimate King, Juan II.

May  – On his deathbed, Bosnian nobleman Stjepan Vukčić Kosača, Grand Duke of Bosnia, dictates a testament proclaiming that his son Vladislav Hercegović, "brought the great Turk to Bosnia to the death and destruction of us all" and blames Vladislav for the end of the Kingdom of Bosnia. Vladislav becomes the Grand Duke of Bosnia the next day with the approval of the Ottoman governor.
February  – Gabriel VI is elected as the new Pope of the Coptic Christian Church, succeeding the late Matthew II.
July  – King James III of Scotland is taken hostage while he is hunting near his palace at Linlithgow, in a coup d'etat led by Lord Robert Boyd.

October  – King James III of Scotland gives royal assent Among the many acts passed into law by the Parliament, including the Hospitals Act ("for the reformacioune of the hospitalis") and the Benefices Act against Englishmen being allowed to receive a benefice (payment of a reward for services rendered) from the Crown or from the Church ("na Inglis man have benefice with Scotlande")

July  – In the fourth year of the Ottoman–Venetian War, Admiral Vettore Cappello of the Republic of Venice Navy lands on the Greek mainland at Piraeus and the Venetians begin marching toward Athens to free it from Ottoman control.
King Matthias Corvinus founds the first university in Slovakia, the Universitas Istropolitana in Bratislava.
Choe Hang is appointed as the news prime minister (yonguijong) of Korea by the Emperor Sejo, succeeding Sim Hoe.
The first European polyalphabetic cipher is invented by Leon Battista Alberti (approximate date).

July  – In one of the largest battles of the  in Italy, the Battle of Molinella is fought along the Idice River near Bologna by the army of the Republic of Venice against the armies of the Republic of Florence and the Duchy of Milan. The battle marks the first extensive use of artillery and firearms in combat in Italy, and while relatively few of the , troops from both sides sustain casualties ( dead, , wounded) the battle is notable for the killing of almost , horses. Although both sides withdraw, the Venetian General Bartolomeo Colleoni abandons further attempts to conquer Milan.
November  – Regent of Sweden Erik Axelsson Tott supports the re-election of deposed Charles VIII of Sweden to the throne.

May  – After invading Syria, Shah Suwar, the Ottoman Governor of Dulkadir, triumphs in battle over various Mamluk Syrian governors and emirs and captures Kulaksiz. The Governor of Damascus, Uzbek Bey, is seriously wounded but manages to escape.
July  – (5th waxing of Wagaung,  ME) At Pyay (now in Myanmar) Thihathura of Ava becomes the new Burmese King of Ava upon the death of his father, Narapati I of Ava.

January  – Abu Al-Nasr Sayf ad-Din Al-Ashraf Qaitbay (generally referred to as "Qaitbay") is installed by Mamluk Egyptian nobles as the new Sultan of Egypt and Syria, the day after the Sultan Timurbugha had been removed after less than two months on the throne.

September  – The Orkney Islands are pledged to Scotland by King Christian I of Kingdom of Norway in consideration of an agreement for the marriage of -year-old King James III of Scotland to Princess Margrete, King Christian's daughter, with the islands pledged as security against the payment of the dowry. As the money is never paid, the connection with the crown of Scotland becomes perpetual.

February  – A "marriage treaty" is signed between representatives of the Kingdom of England and the Duchy of Burgundy, providing for the marriage of King Edward IV's sister, Margaret of York, to Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy.
June  – King Henry IV of Castile makes a gift of Gibraltar to Enrique de Guzmán, 2nd Duke of Medina Sidonia, as a reward for Guzman's work in capturing Gibraltar from the Moors.
July  – The Holy Roman Emperor Frederick III issues a decree nullifying the  Treaty of Soldin between Brandenburg and Pomerania.

March  – With Abu Sa'id Mirza having been killed at the battle of Qarabagh, the Timurid prince, Sultan Husayn Bayqara captures Herat (now in Afghanistan), the capital of the Timurid Empire, and proclaims himself the Emperor.
Sigismund of Austria sells Upper Alsace to Charles the Bold, in exchange for aid in a war against the Swiss.
Han Myŏnghoe is appointed by King Yejong of Korea as the new Chief State Councillor, replacing Pak Wŏnhyŏng.
Johann Heynlin introduces the printing press into France and prints his first book this same year.
May  – Charles VIII of Sweden, who has served three terms as King of Sweden, dies. Sten Sture the Elder proclaims himself Regent of Sweden the following day.
Between this year and , , witches are tried in the Swiss Confederation; , of them are executed.
May  – Yun Chaun becomes the new Chief State Councillor (Yonguijong, equivalent to a prime minister as head of government) of Korea, when he is appointed by King Seongjong to replace Hong Yunsŏng.
August  – Battle of Lipnic: Stephen the Great defeats the Volga Tatars of the Golden Horde, led by Ahmed Khan.
– – Funerary temple of Hatshepsut, Deir el-Bahari is built. Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt.
–—Hatshepsut as sphinx, from Deir el-Bahari was made. Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. It is now in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
–—Hand mirror, Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt, is made. It is now at the Brooklyn Museum, New York.
Hatshepsut (18th Dynasty) started to rule. She is a daughter of Thutmose I. Married to her half brother Thutmose II.

October  – Eleven days after Hungary's King Matthias is supported to be King of Bohemia, Prince Casimir of Poland, a younger son of King Casimir IV (who is later canonized as a Roman Catholic saint) leads an army on an invasion of Bohemia and begins a war against Hungary.
June  – Edward of York, the -month-old son of King Edward IV of England, is created Prince of Wales, two months after his father has regained the throne.

January – Portuguese navigators João de Santarém and Pedro Escobar reach the gold-trading centre of Elmina on the Gold Coast of west Africa, and explore Cape St. Catherine, two degrees south of the equator, so that they begin to be guided by the Southern Cross constellation. They also visit Sassandra on the Ivory Coast.
September  – After being tracked down by King Edward IV and taken prisoner at Southampton, the rebel Thomas Neville is beheaded at Middleham Castle in his native Yorkshire.

February  – In what is now south Vietnam, the Champa–Dai Viet War begins when the Dai Viet Emperor Lê Thánh Tông sends  warships to block the Champa Kingdom's Bay of Sa Ky, while another , troops block all entrances to the capital city of Vijaya at what is now the Quảng Ngãi Province. The Me Can citadel in Quang Na falls two days later and the Vietnamese advance.

June – Leonardo da Vinci is admitted as a master in his own right to the artists' Guild of Saint Luke in Florence. An entry is made in the register of the Compagnia di San Luca reading "Anno Domini — Leonardo, son of Ser Piero da Vinci, painter, to pay the sum of  sol, for the whole month of June , for the remittance of his debt to the Company until July ... and to pay for the whole of November ,  sol due on  October ."

October  – King Edward IV of England gives royal assent to the Statute of Westminster  which requires, effective immediately, a tax of four bow staves per every tun ( wine gallons) of cargo brought in by a ship to an English port. The Statute is passed to remedy a shortage of yew wood, from which longbows are made, following the issuing of an edict in  requiring compulsory training for soldiers to use the longbow.
January  – The Great Comet of  passes within . astronomical units of Earth (. million miles or . million km), the closest approach in recorded history for a  great comet
August  – King Edward IV summons the members of the English Parliament to assemble at Westminster on October .
March  – A mount of piety is established in Siena (Italy), origin of Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the world's oldest surviving retail bank.
August  – At the Battle of Otlukbeli, Ottoman Sultan Mehmed II defeats the White Sheep Turkmens, led by Uzun Hasan.
The city walls and defensive moat are built in Celje, Slovenia.

August  – King James III of Cyprus becomes the de jure monarch of Cyprus from the moment he is born,  days after the death of his father, King James II, although the rule of Cyprus is carried out by his mother, Catherine, Queen regent. King James III lives for only one year and  days before dying on August , .

November  – The negotiators for Burgundy and the Holy Roman Empire tentatively agree on creating a Kingdom of Burgundy, ruled by Charles the Bold, that would become a member of the Empire and that would include Burgundy, Holland, Luxembourg, Savoy, Lorraine and other parts of what are now the Netherlands, Belgium and France. A coronation ceremony for Charles as King of Burgundy is tentatively scheduled to take place on November .

Axayacatl, Aztec ruler of Tenochtitlan, invades the territory of the neighboring Aztec city of Tlatelolco. The ruler of Tlatelolco is killed and replaced by a military governor; Tlatelolco loses its independence.
November  – An alliance pact is signed between the Duchy of Milan, the Republic of Venice and the Republic of Florence.

June  – Venetian captain general Triadan Gritti, with six armed galleys to protect the Albanian coast, destroys Ottoman forces attempting to take over the Albanian kingdom, and forces the others to retreat.

August  – In the city of Modica on the island of Sicily, a massacre is carried out in the Jewish neighborhood of Cartellone, and  Jews are killed in what is later referred to as the "Massacre of the Assumption".

May  – The English royal title of Duke of York is created by King Edward IV for his second-born son, Prince Richard. Thereafter, the title of Duke of York is reserved for the second son of the English monarch, while the title of Prince of Wales is reserved for the first-born son.

August  – James III, the one-year old de jure King of Cyprus, dies  days after his first birthday, apparently from malaria. His mother, Catherine Cornaro, who had been serving as regent since her son's birth, becomes the ruling queen of Cyprus.
March  – The city of Perpignan is recaptured by the army of the Kingdom of France after having been captured by the Spanish king John II of Aragon.
August  – The Treaty of Picquigny ends the brief war between France and England.
October  – The Swiss Confederacy Canton of Bern invades the Canton of Vaud, at the time under the control of Jacques of Savoy, one of the nobles in the Duchy of Savoy.

April  – While in Valladolid, capital of the Kingdom of Castile and León, to celebrate a tournament in their honor, the joint rulers of Castile, Queen Isabella and King Fernando II are interrupted by a messenger sent by King Afonso V of Portugal. King Afonso announces a declaration of war against the crown of Castile and León.

January  – At Madrid, Queen Isabella I of Castile, who had been crowned on December , declares her husband Prince Fernando de Aragón to be the joint ruler with her, and is proclaimed as King Fernando V of Castile. Fernando, the oldest son and heir to the throne of King Juan II of Aragon, will make Isabella co-ruler of Aragon when he ascends the throne upon his father's death in .

February  – In the Swiss Canton of Vaud, after a seven-day siege, Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy, obtains the surrender of Swiss Confederacy troops at the garrsion of the village of Grandson (originally Grancione). The surrender had been obtained by the promises of Charles that the lives of the  Swiss defenders would be spared if they gave up, but Charles orders that they be executed anyway. Some are hanged, while others are drowned in Lake Neuchâtel over a period of four hours.

March  – In retaliation for the massacre of the Swiss defenders of the Grandson Castle, troops from the Canton of Bern and the Old Swiss Confederacy defeat the Burgundian troops of Charles the Bold and force him to flee.
June  – Burgundian Wars: In the Battle of Morat, The Burgundians suffer a crushing defeat, losing half of its army of at least , soldiers, at the hands of the Swiss, who sustain only  casualties.
May  – Hans Böhm, the "rummer of Niklashausen", incites a peasant uprising in an around Niklashausen in the German Prince-Bishopric of Würzburg. He is captured and eventually executed on July .

October  – Burgundian Wars: Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy, begins the Siege of Nancy, capital of the Duchy of Lorraine, in an attempt to regain control of it after Rene II, Duke of Lorraine, had captured it earlier. Rene II, aided by the Swiss Confederation, makes plans to break the siege, leading to the Battle of Nancy on January , .
October  – The University of Tübingen, one of the  German Excellence Universities, is founded in Württemberg by Count Eberhard I.

May  – Pope Sixtus IV grants a special dispensation for Richard of Shrewsbury, Duke of York, the three-year-old son of King Edward IV, is betrothed to -year-old Anne de Mowbray, 8th Countess of Norfolk, in a waiver of canon law that sets a minimum age for marriage as  for boys and  for girls. The children's wedding will take place on January , .
Ivan III of Russia marches against the Novgorod Republic, marking the beginning of Russian Colonialism.

September  – King Ferrante of Napoli marries Princess Juana, daughter of the Spanish King John II of Aragon and Navarre after being brought to Naples by King Ferrante's son Prince Alfonso, Duke of Calabria.
Giovanni Pico della Mirandola starts to study canon law, at the University of Bologna.

November  – The Spanish Inquisition begins as Pope Sixtus IV promulgates the papal bull Exigit sinceras devotionis affectus, permitting the Crown of Castile, at the request of  Queen Isabella, to create the office of Inquisitor General, with the Dominican bishop Tomás de Torquemada to prosecute accused heretics.
August  – Following a storm that prevents the landing of other ships at the island of Gran Canaria, the Portuguese Navy withdraws and sails back to Portugal.

September  – King Matthias Corvinus of Hungary accepts the draft of the Treaty of Brno with slight modifications regarding the division of the lands of the Bohemian crowned claimed by both Hungary and King Vladisalus II of Bohemia. Under the terms, Vladislaus II cedes  Moravia, Silesia, and Lusatia to Corvinus, and both monarchs are permitted to refer to themselves as "King of Bohemia".
October  – The University of Copenhagen is established by decree of King Chrisitian I, who sets down the rules and laws to govern the institution.
January  – At Tabriz, Khalil Mirza is proclaimed the Sultan of Aq Qoyunlu (now in Iran) after the death of his father, Uzun Hasan. Khalil is overthrown by his brother Ya'qub in July.
March  – Matthias Corvinus, King of Hungary, concludes a treaty with the Swiss Confederacy hindering the recruitment of Swiss mercenaries by the Emperor.

December  – The surviving suspect in the Pazzi conspiracy and April , , assassination of Giuliano de' Medici in the Republic of Florence, is executed after being returned to Florence by order of the Ottoman Sultan Mehmed II. The conspirator, Bernardo Bandini dei Baroncelli, is hanged from a window of the Palazzo del Popolo, Florence's "Palace of the People".

May  – Christopher Columbus, an experienced mariner and successful trader in the thriving Genoese expatriate community in Portugal, marries Felipa Perestrelo Moniz (Italian on her father's side), and receives as dowry her late father's maps and papers, charting the seas and winds around the Madeira Islands, and other Portuguese possessions in the Ocean Sea.
January  – Leonor de Trastamara, who had served as regent of the Kingdom of Navarre in Spain during the absence of her father, Juan II, is crowned at Tudela. She dies  days later at the age of .
April  – The ratification of the Treaty of Constantinople in Venice ends the Siege of Shkodra after fifteen months, and brings all of Albania under the Ottoman Empire.
January  – King Louis XI buys the succession rights to the Duchy of Brittany from the Countess Nicole de Châtillon for , livres

June  – The Senate of the Republic of Venice votes to approve the transfer of ownership of the island of Santorini (now the Greek island of Thera) to Domenico Pisani. The island was the dowry given to Pisani for the marriage of Fiorenza Crispo, by Firenzo's father, Giacomo III Crispo, Duke of the Archipelago, a set of  of the  inhabited Cyclades islands in the Aegean Sea.
May  – Pedro del Algaba, the Spanish colonial Governor of the Canary Islands, is arrested by Juan Rejón, and is executed on Rejón's orders on May .

September  – The co-rulers of most of Spain, Ferdinand II of Aragon and Isabella I of Castile initiate the Spanish Inquisition to look for heretics and unconverted Jews, appointing the Dominican Order clerics  Miguel de Morillo and Juan de San Martín to serve as the first two inquisitors.

October  – The Great Stand on the Ugra River begins as troops of the Grand Duchy of Moscow, led by the Grand Duke Ivan III and General Ivan Molodoy battle against the invading Mongol armies of the Golden Horde, led by their ruling monarch, Akhmat Khan. The invasion began after Ivan III stopped paying tribute to the Horde. The Theotokos of Vladimir icon is credited with saving Moscow. The standoff between the troops lasts five weeks before Akhmat and the Mongol troops retreat.
August —Lunar Saros  begins.
Amphictyon, son of Deucalion and Pyrrha, legendary King of Athens, dies after a reign of  years and is succeeded by Erichthonius I of Athens, a grandson of Cranaus.
November  – At Târgoviște, Basarab Țepeluș cel Tânăr replaces his successor, Vlad Călugărul as the voivode (prince) of Wallachia (now part of Romania)

December  – The city of Zahara de la Sierra, now part of Spain, is captured by the Moorish Emir Abu'l-Hasan Ali of Granada in a surprise attack, leading to a counterattack by the Kingdom of Castile two months later.
April  – King James III of Scotland gives royal assent to the six Defence of the Realm Acts and to the Benefices Act , passed by his parliament in anticipation of a war with England.
Axayacatl, Aztec ruler of Tenochtitlan, dies and is succeeded by his brother Tízoc.
August  – John II of Portugal starts to rule in his own right.
July  – Cem Sultan of the Ottoman Empire flees to the island of Rhodes after having turned down two offers from his half-brother, Sultan Bayezid II, to give up all claims to the Ottoman throne.
August  – The Scots surrender the border town of Berwick-upon-Tweed to Richard, Duke of Gloucester, ending his campaign against Scotland.

August  – Portuguese navigator Diogo Cão and his crew arrive at Loango Bay in East Africa on Saint Dominic's Day, and Cão names the body of water Praia Formosa de São Domingos; from there he and the crew become the first Europeans to enter the Congo River.

January  – ( Adar ) The first printing of the Torah by movable type, in the original Hebrew language, is made in Bologna, marking the first use of the Hebrew alphabet rather than the Roman alphabet in printing.

June  – The Treaty of Fotheringhay is signed between King Edward IV of England, and Alexander Stewart, Duke of Albany, the younger brother of King James III of Scotland, with Alexander being promised the Scottish throne in return for swearing loyalty to England and participating in an English invasion of Scotland.
June  – Richard, Duke of York, the younger brother of King Edward V, arrives at the Tower of London.
June  – The Grand Duke Ivan IV of Ryazan signs a treaty with his uncle, Grand Duke Ivan III of Moscow, placing Ryazan under Moscow's control and end—ing Ryazan's independence.

April  – Pluto moves inside Neptune's orbit until July , , according to modern orbital calculations. At the time, neither planet has been discovered by Earth astronomers. The event of Pluto being closer to the Sun than Neptune will happen again during the period lasting from  to .

April  – At the age of , Edward V becomes King of England upon the sudden death of his father, King Edward IV. The young king will reign for only  days before being deposed, imprisoned and murdered by his uncle, Richard III.
February  – The General Council of the Inquisition is created in Spain.

January  – In France, the Estates General, a consultative assembly of  delegates ( apiece) representing the three economic classes — the First Estate (clergy), Second Estate (nobility) and— for the first time, the Third Estate (commoners, including peasants) is convened for the first time since . The convening of the Estates General of  at Tours has been ordered by Anne of France, the mother of and regent for the -year-old King Charles VIII since the death of King Louis XI, with the goal of designating the regent during Charles's minority. Although King Louis had designated Anne and her husband, Pierre de Beaujeu, to serve as regents, Louis, Duke of Orleans, the second cousin of the late King, seeks approval from the Estates General for the regency. The session of the Estates General becomes a call for reform of the laws of France.
September  – Treaty of Nottingham: A three-year truce between the kingdoms of England and Scotland is signed.
January  – King Richard III of England assembles his first, and only Parliament, opening a -day session.

October  – The "White Elephant War", which had started in  with the invasion of the Kingdom of Lan Xang (now Laos) by the Dai Viet Empire (now northern Vietnam) with the Vietnamese withdrawing their troops and failing to conquer the Laotians.

November  – Louis, Duke of Orleans a contender for the French throne, signs a treaty with François II, Duke of Brittany, with an agreement for the marriage of the Duke's -year-old daughter, Anne of Brittany to Louis, with a goal of Louis having control of Brittany and of France. The proposed marriage, however, is contingent upon the annulment of Louis' existing marriage to Joan of France, Duchess of Berry.

April  – Vuk Grgurevic Brancovic, the Despot of Serbia under Hungarian rule, dies after a reign of  years, bringing the Brankovic dynasty to an end, leaving the office vacant and prompting Hungary's King Matthias Corvinus to find a suitable heir.

September  – The army of the Grand Duchy of Moscow forces, led by Ivan III, invades the city of Tver, ruled by Mikhail III and capital of the Duchy of Tver. Within  days, Ivan is able to claim the Duchy.
August – Henry Tudor's army begins crossing the border from Wales into England at Mathafarn, then marches towards London.

January  – The siege of Vienna, capital of the Holy Roman Empire, is started by the Black Army of the Kingdom of Hungary  in the ninth year of the ongoing Austrian-Hungarian War. Vienna is defended by a force of only , soldiers and cavalry, against , soldiers and cavalry of the Black Army, and the city falls to Hungary within four months.

January  – Saint Leopold of Babenburg, who died almost  years earlier in , is canonized as a Roman Catholic saint by Pope Innocent VIII. Saint Leopold will be celebrated as the patron saint of Austria in the centuries that follow.
Sigismund, Archduke of Tyrol, issues Europe's first large silver coin, the guldengroschen, which will later become the thaler.

June  – King Henry VII of England issues a proclamation confirming that Pope Innocent VIII had issued a papal bull recognizing Henry's title as the rightful King. In the same proclamation, King Henry asserts that opposition to his title will be punishable by excommunication under the papal bull, and declares that the marriage to Elizabeth of York ended "the variances, dissensions and debates that had been in the realm of England between the houses of the Dukes of Lancaster on the one part and the house of the Duchy of York on the other." King Henry uses the new technology of the printing press as his means of mass communication throughout England, and hires printer Walter de Machlinea mass produce the declaration for distribution.

May  – Humphrey Stafford and his brother Thomas Stafford, who had been given sanctuary by the church at Culham, Oxfordshire, are forcibly removed by Sir John Savage and  armed men on charges of treason. Protests are made to Pope Innocent VIII against the breaking of the right of sanctuary in the Roman Catholic Church, and while Thomas is pardoned by King Henry, Humphrey is executed for treason on July .
April  – The adoption of the Sentència Arbitral de Guadalupe ends the War of the Remences, in the Principality of Catalonia.
March  – King James III of Scotland gives royal assent to acts passed by the Scottish Parliament, including the Tallow Act, the Hides Act and the Currency Act.
July  – The Khanate of Khazan surrenders after a siege of seven weeks, and Khazan becomes a vassal of the Russians in the Grand Principality of Moscow.

After failed attempts by King Ferdinand of Aragon to negotiate Granada's surrender of the city of Malaqa, the siege of Málaga begins, with the Granadan General Hamet el Zegri defending against a larger contingent of Aragonese and Castilian troops. At the same time, the Spanish fleet blocks the harbor and all access to Malaga from the sea. The city surrenders after three months.
June  – French–Breton War: The siege of the city of Nantes in the Duchy of Brittany is started by King Charles VIII of France, but fails after less than two months and is lifted on August .
August  – The County of Tyrol within the Holy Roman Empire defeats the attack of the Republic of Venice at the Battle of Calliano, with , of the Venetians and  of the Tyroleans killed.
August  – The siege of Málaga ends, when the Spanish take the Granadan city. Most of the , surviving residents are taken prisoner and then sold into slavery in Castile and Andalusia.
January  – In the Kingdom of France, Louis II, Duke of Orleans and François II, Duke of Brittany, are both declared rebels by the Parlement of Paris.
Rathbornes Candles is established in Dublin; the company is still trading in the .
Jasper Tudor, 1st Duke of Bedford, takes possession of Cardiff Castle.

October  – King James IV of Scotland gives royal assent to numerous laws approved by the Scottish Parliament during its  session, including the France Act ("to renew the confideracioun betuix the realmez of France and Scotland") and the Rebel Officers of Law Act (disbarring and suspending any wardens, justices or other officials "who were in battle at Stirling against our sovereign Lord").

March  – The Bartolomeu Dias expedition from Portugal arrives at the Cape of Good Hope and the crew of the two expedition ships, São Cristóvão and São Pantaleão, become the first Europeans to set foot at Good Hope. They anchor at the Boesmans River at what is now the South African city of Kwaaihoek. In that the landing took place on the feast day of Saint Gregory, the Portuguese sailors erect the Padrão de São Gregório, a stone pillar and cross, to mark their arrival.
January  – Johann von Tiefen becomes the new Grand Master of the Teutonic Order upon the death of Martin von Wetzhausen.
Lucas Watzenrode becomes bishop of Warmia.
November  – Arthur Tudor, heir apparent to  the throne of England as the son of King Henry VII, is named Prince of Wales.
April  – At Jodhpur, in what is now the state of Rajasthan in India, Rao Satal becomes the new ruler of the Kingdom of Marwar upon the death of his father, King Rao Jodha.
June  – King James IV grants Andrew, Lord Gray, the lands and Barony of Lundie in Scotland.
Pêro da Covilhã arrives in Ethiopia.

February  – The Scottish Parliament passes an Act to restore lands forfeited by the losers in the war between the supporters of the late King James III against his son, the reigning King James IV, and nullifying transfers of land made to new owners after the forfeitures.
February  – The Scottish Parliament opens in Edinburgh to address matters of lands confiscated in the year before.
John Colet receives his M.A. from Magdalen College, Oxford.
September  – The coronation of Vladislaus II as King of Hungary takes place at Székesfehérvár.
Thutmose I dies (other date is ).
Cranaus, legendary King of Athens, is deposed after a reign of  years by his son-in-law Amphictyon of Thessaly, son of Deucalion and Pyrrha.
According to James Ussher's chronology, this is when Moses led the Hebrews from Egypt. This was called the Exodus.
April —Lunar Saros  begins.
Thutmose I (Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt) died.
November  – Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor and King Vladislaus II of Bohemia and Hungary sign the Peace of Pressburg, formally ending the Austrian–Hungarian War.
October  – The English Parliament assembles at Westminster, and Richard Empson is elected as Speaker of the House of Commons.
May  – The ruler of the Kingdom of Kongo, Nkuwu Nzinga, is baptised by Portuguese missionaries, adopting the baptismal name of João I.
November  – Anne of Brittany annuls her marriage contract with the Archduke Maximilian of Austria and is formally engaged to be married to King Charles VIII of France.
September – At the battle of Vrpile Gulch in southern Croatia, the armies of the Ottoman Empire are defeated by those of the Kingdom of Croatia.
October  – The English army besieges Boulogne.

August  – The papal conclave, the first to be held in the Sistine Chapel, begins balloting with  of the  members of the College of Cardinals in attendance. With  votes needed for the required two-thirds majority, the first ballot is split among three candidates, with Oliviero Carafa receiving , Rodrigo Borja  and Giuliano della Rovere , while two cast a blank vote.
Stiegl brewery first recorded in Salzburg.
May  – In the Canary Islands, the Spanish conquistador Alonso Fernandez de Lugo finishes the conquest of the island of La Palma by capturing Tanausu, King of the native Guanches.
September  – Christopher Columbus sails from La Gomera in the Canary Islands, his final port of call before crossing the Atlantic Ocean for the first time.

January  – Christopher Columbus and his crew begin their voyage back to Europe on their two remaining ships, the caravel La Niña (guided by Columbus) and the Pinta (piloted by Martín Alonso Pinzón), departing from the island of Hispanola and what is now the Bay of Rincón in the Dominican Republic. The decision to return to Spain comes two days after the crew's battle with the indigenous residents, the Ciguayos.
March  – Christopher Columbus anchors in Lisbon and completes his February  letter on the first voyage, conveying the news of his discoveries.
September  – At the Battle of Krbava Field in southern Croatia, forces of the Ottoman Empire defeat those of the Kingdom of Croatia.
April  – Battle of Anfao: Askia Mohammad I defeats Sonni Baru in what is now the African nation of Mali, and usurps the throne of the Songhai Empire.
September  – Pope Alexander VI issues the bull Dudum siquidem to the Catholic Monarchs, extending the grant of newly discovered lands he made them in Inter caetera.
December  – King Louis VIII of France and the French Army peacefully march into Rome after being granted free passage by Pope Alexander VI.
Johann Reuchlin publishes De verbo mirifico.
September  – King Charles VIII of France and Ludovico Sforza, regent for the Duke of Milan, meet in Asti and conclude an alliance against King Alfonso II of Naples.

November  – Italian War of –: The armies of King Charles VIII of France enter Florence. Charles is dissuaded from destroying the city by the Florentine leader, Girolamo Savonarola, who had recently taken control from the Medici family. After being persuaded that he has a divine role of reformation of the Roman Catholic Church, King Charles spares Florence from destruction and leaves the city on November , guiding his troops onward toward Rome.

In a battle fought at the village of Igris (now part of western Romania) in territory claimed by Hungary and the Ottoman state of Wallachia, the Hungarian General Pál Kinizsi defeats Turkish armies led by the Ottoman governor Basarab II of Wallachia."Istorie". Primăria comunei Sânpetru Mare.

The oldest extant cable railway, the Reisszug, is created by order of the Archbishop Leonhard von Keutschach shortly after his election on July , . The railway is used for the manual pulling of a wheeled cart up an incline, to provide goods for the Hohensalzburg Fortress, at Salzburg in Austria.

March  – In response to the French invasion and rapid subjugation of the Italian nations, the League of Venice is formed by representatives of Pope Alexander, King Ferdinand of Spain, the acting Holy Emperor Maximilian, and Ludovico, Duke of Milan.

July  – Winning the Battle of Fornovo, the French army under King Charles secures its retreat from Italy, by defeating a combined Milanese-Venetian force of the League of Venice, commanded by 
Francesco Gonzaga, Marquis of Mantua.

July  – After failing at the Battle of Deal, Perkin Warbeck and his troops land with  ships at the Ireland port of Waterford to gain a foothold in his attempt to invade England. Warbeck is joined by an Irish noble, Maurice FitzGerald, Earl of Desmond, and begins an -day siege. The defenders of Waterford protect the walled city by damming the St. John's River to flood the marshes around Warbeck's soldiers, and fire the fortresses cannons at Warbeck's ships.

June – Gribshunden, the flagship of King Hans Oldenburg of Denmark sinks off the coast of Ronneby in Sweden while King Hans is ashore to negotiate with Sten Sture the Elder to restore the power of the Kalmar Union. According to some accounts, the sinking (and the death of more than  crew) happened after an explosion and fire, though explorations of the shipwreck centuries later show no indication of burning.

August  – Bartholomew Columbus, brother of Christopher Columbus, formally founds the city of Santo Domingo (first settled in March) on Hispaniola (in the modern-day Dominican Republic), making it the oldest permanent European settlement in the New World.
July  – In the Canary Islands, the native kings of Tenerife surrender to the Spanish conquistador Alonso Fernández de Lugo.
November  – King Henry VII of England summons the English Parliament to assemble starting on January .

May  – The Marquis of Mantua makes a further adjustment to his April  decree on Jewish identification, making further allowances to the dress code of Jewish women,and excusing the requirement of wearing a veil to cover the face. Unmarried women must still wear yellow headgear and drape a veil over their shoulders; married women are excused from covering their faces with veils but must wear headgear;  and widows may wear their color of choice for headgear.

September – King James IV of Scotland and his army invade Northumberland in the Kingdom of England, in support of the pretender to the English throne, Perkin Warbeck. The invaders leave on September  and travel back to Scotland.
The Ottomans give Russian merchants freedom of trade within the empire.

October  –
Sten Sture the Elder agrees to recognize Hans, King of Denmark and of Norway as the rightful King of Sweden and ends his -year term as the Swedish Regent.
June  – The coronation of Federico di Trastamara, son of King Alfonso II, as King of Naples takes place at the Cathedral of Barletta.
October  – Leaders of the Second Cornish Uprising surrender to the King at Taunton; the following day, Warbeck, having deserted his army, is captured at Beaulieu Abbey in Hampshire.
July  – Vasco da Gama's fleet departs from Lisbon, beginning his expedition to India.
July  – Columbus becomes the first European to visit the island of Trinidad.

January  – In a letter to the Archbishop of Canterbury, who is also the Chancellor of the English treasury, King Henry VII of England formally authorizes, from his own funds, declares that "we, for certain considerations us especially moving, have given and granted unto our well-beloved John Calbot of the parts of Venice an annuity or annual rent of £ sterling, to be had and yearly perceived from the Feast of the Annunciation of our Lady last past, during our pleasure, of our customs and subsidies growing in our port of Bristol by the hands of our customs there for the time being, at Michaelmas and Easter, by even portions.
August  – Columbus lands on the Paria Peninsula, in what is now Venezuela in the first definitely recorded landing of Europeans on the mainland Americas.
August  – Columbus begins eight days of exploring the Gulf of Paria between Trinidad and Venezuela.

November  – In the Kingdom of the Catholic Monarchs of Spain, Diego de Deza, Bishop of Jaén, is commissioned as the Grand Inquisitor for the Crown of Castile, the Kingdom of León, and for Granada. His power is expanded in September to include the rest of Spain.
October  – King Louis XII of France and his troops seize Milan, driving out Duke Ludovico Sforza, and Leonardo da Vinci flees to Venice.
May  –  Catherine of Aragon, the future first wife of Henry VIII, is married by proxy to his brother, Arthur, Prince of Wales.
June  – Queen Isabella of Spain orders Christopher Columbus to liberate and repatriate Indians from the New World, declaring that nobody had authorized him to kidnap any of her subjects.
Johannes Trithemius inadvertently reveals interests in magic by writing a letter to a Carmelite friar about a treatise he is writing on steganography.
Montenegro, the last free monarchy in the Balkans, is annexed by the Ottoman Empire, as part of the sanjak of Shkodër, and Stefan II Crnojević is removed from office.
December   – The last incunable is printed in Venice.
October  – Christopher Columbus and his brothers, arrested and in chains, are deported from Santo Domingo to Spain.

September  – Pedro Cabral's fleet of nine ships arrives in India, more than six months after departing from Portugal, and lands at the port of Calicut, which had been visited two years earlier by Vasco da Gama.
May  – Cabral and his fleet depart from Brazil and sail eastward toward Africa, resuming their journey to India.
December  – The Siege of the Castle of St. George ends, and the island of Cephalonia is captured by a joint Venetian–Spanish fleet.
Egypt conquers Nubia and the Levant (–).
Earliest remains of domesticated ferrets found.
: Many scholars date early parts of the Rig Veda to roughly the .
Eleusinian Mysteries start in Ancient Greece.
: The Phoenicians develop an alphabet—see Timeline of communication technology.
November  – Arthur, Prince of Wales, marries the Spanish princess Catherine of Aragon.
January  – Cesar Borgia returns triumphantly to Rome, from Romagna.
March  – Portuguese navigator João da Nova discovers Ascension Island. It is definitely sighted and named on May ,  (Feast of the Ascension) by Afonso de Albuquerque.
Martin Luther enters the University of Erfurt.

August  – King Federico of Naples abdicates upon the conquest of the Kingdom of Naples by France, and France's King Louis XII becomes the nominal monarch as Luigi II, re di Napoli. King Louis appoints Louis d'Armagnac, Duke of Nemours as France's Viceroy of Naples.
Wittenberg University is founded.
June  – Columbus and his crew land on the island of Martinique and land at Le Carbet.
Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa receives the degree of magister artium from the University of Cologne.
December  – Cesare Borgia kills Ramiro d'Orco; this incident is referenced in Machiavelli's The Prince
November  – Ismail I founds the Safavid dynasty and proclaims himself the Shah of Iran after defeating tribes of the Aq Qoyunlu confederation.

June  – After his ships are damaged in a storm, Christopher Columbus and his  men are forced to beach at the island of Jamaica (at modern-day Saint Ann Parish) and remain stranded there for the next six months.

August  – Pope Alexander VI dies after a reign of  years, and the largest gathering of cardinals up to that time—  from Italy,  from Spain and  from France— is called to Rome for a papal conclave, to start in September.
June  – The book The Imitation of Christ by Thomas à Kempis is re-published in an English translation.
Hieronymus Bosch works on the triptych The Garden of Earthly Delights, although other sources suggest a - date range for when he worked on it.
February  – Challenge of Barletta: Thirteen Italian knights defeat thirteen French knights, near Barletta.
October – Babur besieges and captures Kabul.
February  – King Ferdinand V of Castile contracts with Juan de la Cosa to finance an independent expedition to the Pearl Islands and the Gulf of Urabá.

In Florence, Leonardo da Vinci and Niccolò Machiavelli become involved in a scheme to divert the Arno River, cutting the water supply to Pisa to force its surrender: Colombino, the project foreman, fails to follow da Vinci's design, and the project is a major failure.
July  – At the age of , Lê Túc Tông becomes the new Emperor of Vietnam (Dai Viet) after the death of his father, Lê Hiến Tông, but serves for only six months before dying.
March  – In what is now India's Kerala state, a second invasion of the Portuguese-supported Kingdom of Cochin by the Zamorin of Calicut takes place, beginning a war that lasts until July .
Martin Luther, aged , vows to become a monk in a moment of terror, as a result of a close lightning strike during a thunderstorm, near the village of Stotternheim.

February  – During a visit to Windsor Castle as guests of King Henry VII of England, Philip the Handsome, Duke of Burgundy, plays a game of tennis against Thomas Grey, 2nd Marquess of Dorset in the first recorded use of tennis rackets. A year later, a chronicler notes that on the 7th of February, "the kynge of Castelle played w the Rackete and gave the marques xv".
Francisco de Almeida arrives in the Anjediva Islands to begin construction on the first of four fortresses he needed to construct for his appointment as viceroy.
Old St. Peter's Basilica is demolished under the orders of Pope Julius II. Construction of the new basilica begins the following year.

The Pomander Watch of , the earliest known pocket watch, is made by Peter Henlein in Germany at Nuremberg. After an absence of  years, the watch will be rediscovered at a flea market in London; an inscription on the watch, "MDVPHN", will be interpreted in  as meaning a rendition of the year (MDV,  in Roman numerals); the inventor (PH for Peter Henlein) and the place of manufacture (N for Nuremberg).
October  –  Charles II, the six-year-old son of King Philip of Castile, inherits his father's title of Duke of Burgundy and is proclaimed "Lord of the Netherlands".
August  – Battle of Kletsk: The Grand Duchy of Lithuania defeats the Tatars of the Crimean Khanate.
June  – Mahmud Shah II begins a -year reign as the Sultan of Kedah, a Muslim kingdom on the Malay Peninsula, on the death of his father, Adilin I.
November  – Pope Julius II personally leads his troops into Bologna, retaking the city from the excommunicated tyrant Giovanni II Bentivoglio.
June  – The Treaty of Villafáfila is signed between Austria and Spain.
April  – French troops retake the city of Genoa after a seven-day siege, defeating rebels who had taken control in July .
The Aztec New Fire ceremony is held for the last time (according to Bernardino de Sahagún).
Raphael paints The Deposition, among other works.

June  – Ferdinand II is welcomed by Louis XII of France at the Italian city of Savona in a spectacular ceremony, and the two monarchs begin a series of meetings on the division of the Italian kingdoms between France and Spain.

April  – Martin Waldseemüller publishes his Cosmographiae Introductio ("Introduction to Universal Cosmography") and accompanying wall map, the first to show the Americas as a separate continent, naming them in honour of Amerigo Vespucci, his friend and idol.
June  – The coronation of Prince Lajos as the designated successor to his father, King Vladislaus II of Hungary, takes place in Székesfehérvár.
March  – The oldest annual foot race in Europe, the "Red Hose Race", is run for the first time, taking place in Scotland at Carnwath, Lanarkshire.
February  – During the Glinski rebellion, Lithuanian noble Mykolas Glinskis attacks Grodno (now in Belarus) and decapitates Jan Zabrzeziński, the top ally of Grand Duke Alexander.
January  – Maximilian, King of the Romans, requests permission to march to Rome through Venetian territory, but is denied and begins his Italienzug.
July  – The process of removing the former layers of paint on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel is completed, and Michelangelo begins the next phase of marking the surface for painting.
Royal Grammar School, Guildford, England, is founded under the will of Robert Beckingham.
Georg Tannstetter is appointed by Maximilian I as the Professor of Astronomy at the University of Vienna.
September  – Portuguese fidalgo Diogo Lopes de Sequeira becomes the first European to reach Malacca, having crossed the Gulf of Bengal.
The Venetians, encamped around the town of Treviglio, move south towards the Po River in search of better positions.
Erasmus writes his most famous work, In Praise of Folly.
April  – The "Disturbance of the Three Ports", an uprising by Japanese merchants against the Korean government, begins in what is now South Korea in the cities of Dongnae, Changwon and Ulsan.
October  – Mingyi Nyo declares independence from the Ava Kingdom in upper Burma, by establishing the Toungoo dynasty.
Sunflowers are brought to Europe by Spaniards.
