October  – The Spanish Armada reaches the English Channel without opposition. An English ship sees the invading force's approach, but is intercepted and sunk, with the survivors being taken prisoner. The Armada encounters a storm the next day.
August  – The Siege of Namwon begins in Korea.
April  – The Serb uprising of – ends in defeat for the rebels, at the field of Gacko (Gatačko Polje).
November  – Pope Clement VIII authorizes the marriage between Albert of Austria and Isabella Clara Eugenia of Spain. The two will be married on April .
May  – The Peace of Vervins, mediated by Cardinal Alessandro de Medici, ends the war between France and Spain.

September  – Battle of Stångebro at Linköping in Sweden: The Catholic King Sigismund of Sweden and Poland is defeated in his attempt to resume control of Sweden by the Protestant forces of his uncle, Charles. Sigismund is deposed shortly thereafter.

July  – William Shakespeare registers the rights to his new play, The Merchant of Venice, in the Register of the Stationers Company, under the title The Marchaunt of Venyce or otherwise called The Jewe of Venyce.
February  – Boris Godunov is elected as the Tsar of Russia by unanimous vote of the parliament of nobles, the Zemsky Sobor.

February 
At Southwark, near London on the south bank of the River Thames, the land upon which the Globe Theatre will be built is leased by Nicholas Brend to a team of investors led by William Shakespeare, Thomas Pope, actors Cuthbert and Richard Burbage, and three others.
Lorenzo Sauli becomes the new Doge of the Republic of Genoa, succeeding Lazzaro Grimaldi Cebà. Sauli will serve until .
May  – Anglo-Spanish War (–): The Siege of Zaltbommel, located in the Dutch Republic, is begun by Spanish general Francisco López de Mendoza.
August  – First Battle of Curlew Pass: Irish forces defeat the English.
July  – Swedish King Sigismund III Vasa is dethroned by his uncle Duke Charles, who takes over as regent of the realm until , when he becomes King Charles IX.
February  – On Shrove Tuesday, the earliest known performance of William Shakespeare's play As You Like It is given, presented at Richmond Park for Queen Elizabeth.
January  – Scotland adopts January  as New Year's Day instead of March .
May  – Michael the Brave becomes ruler of Wallachia, Transylvania and Moldavia, formally uniting the three Danubian Principalities under one Romanian ruler.
December  – The East India Company is granted a Royal charter in the Kingdom of England for trade with Asia.
February  – The Huaynaputina volcano in Peru erupts, in what is still the worst recorded volcanic eruption.
October  – Persian diplomats, led by Husayn 'Ali Beg of Persia, and Englishman Anthony Shirley (who serves as translator) arrive in Prague to meet with Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor.
The overthrow of the ruling Amorite dynasty in Aleppo, Syria.
–—"Mask of Agamemnon" Funerary mask, from the royal tombs at Mycenae, Greece, is made. Grave Circle A. It is now at National Archaeological Museum of Athens.
Egypt—End of Fourteenth Dynasty.

The creation of one of the oldest surviving astronomical documents, a copy of which was found in the Babylonian library of Ashurbanipal: a -year record of the appearances of Venus (which the early Babylonians called Nindaranna).
Cycladic civilization ends.

August  – The Battle of Guruslău takes place in Goroszlo in (now Guruslău in Romania), as Wallachian troops led by Michael the Brave and Giorgio Basta defeat Transylvanian defenders commanded by Sigismund Báthory. Wallachia, assisted by Austrian troops from the Holy Roman Empire, retakes the Principality of Transylvania from Ottoman rule.

December  – The Battle of Castlehaven is fought off of the coast of southern Ireland as six Spanish Navy ships led by General Pedro de Zubiaur are intercepted by an English fleet of four warships led and commanded by Sir Richard Levenson.  Two of the Spanish ships are sunk, and the other four are run aground.
April  – At an assembly of nobles at Kolozsvár (now Cluj-Napoca in Romania), Sigismund Báthory is again proclaimed Prince of Transylvania.
April  – The first expedition of the East India Company sets sail from England for the Spice Islands with John Davis as pilot-major.

September  – 4th Spanish Armada is sent; a fleet of  ships and , men, under the command of Admiral Juan del Águila, departs Portugal after being dispatched to Ireland by King Philip III. The Spanish fleet is intended to support an Irish rebellion led by Hugh O'Neill, Earl of Tyrone and Hugh Roe O'Donnell against the British.
The Portuguese are expelled from Bahrain.

June  – James Lancaster's East India Company fleet arrives at Achin (modern-day Aceh), Sumatra to deal with the local ruler. Having defeated Portugal's ally, the ruler is happy to do business, and Lancaster seizes a large Portuguese galleon and loots it.

The iconoclast and Confucian scholar Li Zhi commits suicide while in a Chinese prison, during the late Ming dynasty; he had taught that women were the intellectual equals of men and should be given equal opportunity in education; he was charged with spreading "dangerous ideas".

September  – The Mutiny of Hoogstraten, a rebellion by soldiers of the Army of Flanders, begins with the seizure by , disgruntled mercenaries of the town of Hoogstraten (now in Belgium). The mutineers hold the town for almost two years before surrendering on  May .

June  – Dutch explorer Joris van Spilbergen lands on the eastern side of the island of Sri Lanka, at Santhamuruthu, and begins the process of attempting to establish a relationship with the rulers of the Kingdom of Kandy.

May  – The King's Men, a troupe of English professional actors composed primarily of former members of the Lord Chamberlain's Men, is granted its royal patent by King James. The company will give the first performances of many of the plays of William Shakespeare, who is one of the company's  principal actors. Named in order of priority on the patent are manager Lawrence Fletcher, Shakespeare, and Richard Burbage.
October  – On the Philippine island of Luzon, the Sangley Rebellion against Spanish rule ends with the massacre of , Sangley Chinese residents in Manila.
October  – Ottoman–Safavid War (–): The Safavid Army of Iran, led by Emperor Abbas the Great,  recaptures Tabriz from the Ottoman Empire after  years of Ottoman occupation.
May  – Mozes Székely is installed as the Prince of Transylvania by the Ottoman Sultan, Mehmed III. Székely is killed in battle on July .
The earliest of eight companies that will eventually merge to form the Kikkoman Corporation, the producers of soy sauce, is founded in Japan.

Five conspirators in England, led by Robert Catesby, who has invited Thomas Wintour, John Wright, Thomas Percy and Guy Fawkes, meet at the Duck and Drake Inn in London to make a plan for the assassination of King James.

January  – The Hampton Court Conference is held between James I of England, the Anglican bishops and representatives of the Puritans. Work begins on the Authorized King James Version of the Bible and revision of the Book of Common Prayer.
The Papacy is expected to fall this year by Tobias Hess and Simon Studion according to their correspondence in .
June  – Thomas Percy, one of the English conspirators in the Gunpowder Plot to assassinate King James I, is appointed as one of the king's bodyguards by the Earl of Northumberland.
August  – Sokolluzade Mehmed Pasha becomes the new Ottoman Grand Vizier, replacing the late Yavuz Ali Pasha
April  – The city of Oulu (Swedish: Uleåborg) is founded by King Charles IX of Sweden.
In England, John Winthrop, later governor of the future Massachusetts Bay Colony, marries his first wife (of ), Mary Forth, daughter of John Forth, of Great Stambridge, Essex.

December  – On behalf of Spain, Portuguese navigator Pedro Fernandes de Queirós begins his expedition to the South Pacific Ocean with  men on three ships. Queiros departs from Callao in the Viceroyalty of Peru with his flagship, San Pedro y San Pablo, and San Pedro and Los Tres Reyes.
February  – Stephen Bocskai is elected Prince of Transylvania at the capital, Belugrad (modern-day Alba Iulia in Romania.)
June  – Pretender Dmitriy and his supporters, including troops of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, march to Moscow.

February  – Sailing on the Dutch ship Duyfken, Dutch navigator Willem Janszoon and the crew make the first confirmed sighting of Australia by a European, reaching the Cape York Peninsula, at the Pennefather River  near what is now Weipa, Queensland.  The Duyfken follows by exploring the western coast.

July  – King Christian IV of Denmark, as the guest of his brother-in-law, King James of England, Scotland and Ireland, is welcomed at London, and the two monarchs are driven by coaches to a banquet at Theobalds House at Cheshunt, Hertfordshire. They are entertained by playwright Ben Jonson's play, The Entertainment of the Kings of Great Britain and Denmark.
April  – Venetian Interdict: Pope Paul V places the Republic of Venice under an interdict, as well as excommunicating Leonardo Donato, the Doge of Venice, and members of the Venetian Senate.
Simion Movilă becomes the new Prince of Moldavia upon the death of his older brother, Ieremia Movilă. Simion will reign for only  months before being poisoned on September , .
July  – The Russian Orthodox bishop Hermogenes is installed as the new Patriarch of Moscow and all Russia, replacing Ignatius.

June  – Newton rebellion: The Tresham landowning family kills more than  peasants during protests against the enclosure of common land in Newton, Northamptonshire, England, at the culmination of the Midland Revolt.

April  – Battle of Gibraltar: A Dutch fleet of  warships, led by Admiral Jacob van Heemskerck, stages a surprise attack on a Spanish fleet anchored in the Bay of Gibraltar. In the battle that ensues, Spain loses as many as  galleons and  smaller ships, and at least  men are killed. The disaster causes Spain to go into bankruptcy by October.

May  – At Jamestown, the president of the governing council, Edward Wingfield, directs the fort to be strengthened and armed against the many attacks of the natives:  "Hereupon the President was contented the Fort should be pallisadoed, the ordinance mounted, his men armed and exercised, for many were the assaults and Ambuscadoes of the Savages ..."  armed Indians attack the Jamestown settlement, killing two people and wounding .
May  – Jamestown, Virginia, is established as the first permanent English settlement in North America, beginning the American frontier.
In the Midland Revolt against Enclosures in England, the term Levellers is first used.

February  – Don Julius Caesar d'Austria, the illegitimate son of Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor, brutally murders his girlfriend, Markéta Pichlerová, then dismembers her body. Emperor Rudolf imprisons Julius for the rest of his life.
September  – The siege of the Troitsky monastery by the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth begins in Russia north of Moscow, but fails after  months.
August  – The first official English representative to India, Captain William Hawkins, lands at Surat.
April  – Old Bushmills Distillery is first licensed to distil whiskey at Bushmills, County Antrim, Ireland by King James I.

October  – The second of the Jamestown supply missions, which set out in July from England, arrives at Jamestown, Virginia, with Christopher Newport commanding the Mary and Margaret carrying  settlers, bringing the population back up to ; the passengers include two women and some skilled artisans, mostly from continental Europe, to develop industries.

July 
The Sea Venture, flagship of the nine-ship fleet of the London Company is deliberately wrecked at Bermuda during a storm, as Admiral George Somers drives the ship into the reefs of Discovery Bay in order to prevent the ship from sinking. A group of  survivors stay, making the first English settlement of the island.
After a fight on November  in Portuguese Macau between Japanese traders and Portuguese soldiers, Japan's ruling shogun, Tokugawa Ieyasu, strictly prohibits further trade between Japan and Portugal.

June  – With the Sea Venture as its flagship, a fleet of nine English ships and more than  passengers altogether, departs from England to bring supplies to the English settlement in Jamestown, Virginia. The fleet runs into a storm in July and the Sea Venture is wrecked in the Bermuda islands on July .
August  (August  O.S.) – English astronomer Thomas Harriot becomes the first person to make a detailed drawing of the Moon, based on his observations through a telescope.
May  – The Second Virginia Charter is officially ratified; it is intended to replace the council with a governor, who has absolute control in the colony.

January  – The Basque witch trials are started in Spain as the court of the Inquisition at Logroño receives a letter from the commissioner of the village of Zugarramurdi, and orders the arrest of four women, including María de Jureteguía and María Chipía de Barrenetxea.
September  – The Siege of Jülich ends as the Holy Roman Imperial city surrenders to Maurice of Nassau, commander of the Dutch Republic troops.
February  – English courtier Thomas Roe sets out on an expedition to The Guianas and Amazon River.
March  (March  O.S.) – Mikhail Skopin-Shuisky, nephew of the Tsar Vasili, liberates Moscow from rebels.

April  – The Treaty of Brussol is signed between Charles Emmanuel I, Duke of Savoy, and a representative of King Henry IV of France, at a meeting at Bruzolo near Turin. The agreement for France and Savoy to remove Spanish occupiers from Italy, is never carried out because King Henry is assassinated one month later.
September  – Claudio Monteverdi's musical work Vespro della Beata Vergine (Vespers for the Blessed Virgin) is first published, printed in Venice and dedicated to Pope Paul V.
The Chinese records a famine accompanied with frost in July. They also recorded a dim sun and yellow fog during this time.
A volcanic eruption at Thera island destroyed the ancient city of Akrotiri.
November  – At Whitehall Palace in London, William Shakespeare's last solo play, The Tempest, is given its earliest reported performance.
August  – Nasuh Pasha becomes the new grand vizier of the Ottoman Empire after the death of Kuyucu Murad Pasha.
August  – Jamestown's Deputy Governor Sir Thomas Gates returns to Virginia with  people, provisions and cattle on six ships and assumes control, ruling that the fort must be strengthened.
Construction begins on Naqsh-e Jahan Square in Isfahan, Persia.
April  – The Colegio de Nuestra Señora del Santísimo Rosario is established in Manila, the Philippines (later renamed Colegio de Santo Tomas, and later still the University of Santo Tomas).
June  – The coronation of Matthias as Holy Roman Emperor takes place at the Frankfurt Cathedral.

December  – Galileo Galilei becomes the first astronomer to observe the planet Neptune when in conjunction with Jupiter. He mistakenly catalogues it as a fixed star, because of its extremely slow motion along the ecliptic. Neptune will not be truly recognized as a planet until , about  years later, when Johann Gottfried Galle first sights it in the Berlin Observatory.
September  – Retreating Polish and Lithuanian troops burn the Russian city of Vologda in reprisal for their defeat at Moscow.
June  – Archduke Matthias of Austria is formally elected as the new Holy Roman Emperor.

September  – Battle of Moscow (): Led by General Jan Karol Chodkiewicz, a relief force from the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, whose troops had been occupying Moscow for two years, make an unsuccessful attempt to break the Russian siege of the Kremlin, where General Mikolaj Strus and his troops are trapped. Both the Russians (led by Dmitry Pozharsky) and the Commonwealth troops suffer at least , deaths, but the Russians prevail. General Chodkiewicz tries a second attack the next day and fails.
November  – King Anaukpetlun of Burma sends an army of , troops to drive the Siamese occupiers from the Tenasserim coast.
The Earl of Somerset marries Frances Howard, following the September  annulment of her marriage to Robert Devereux, 3rd Earl of Essex; the event is the inspiration for John Donne's Eclogue.
May  – Mikhail Romanov arrives in Moscow to begin his reign as Tsar of Russia, after having been elected on March .
August  – The Sicilians under de Aragon defeat the trade fleet of the Ottoman Empire, ending the Battle of Cape Corvo.
December  – The Burmese Army defeats the Siamese Army at Tavoy. The city is now part of Myanmar as Dawei.

April  – The Kingdom of Lan Na (in modern-day northern Thailand) is invaded by , troops commanded by King Anaukpetlun of Burma (modern Myanmar). Lan Na's King Thado Kyaw is unsuccessful in getting assistance from the Kingdom of Siam, and turns to the Kingdom of Lan Xang (modern Laos), which provides assistance.
June  – The Addled Parliament is dissolved by King James I of England, having sat or two months without imposing any new taxes.

Pocahontas, the -year-old daughter of Chief Wahunsenacawh of the Powhatan Algonquian  native tribe in the modern-day U.S. state of Virginia, is forced into child marriage with English colonist John Rolfe at Jamestown, a year after her capture in war. She is given the name of Rebecca Rolfe and departs with John Rolfe to England in , dying before she can return.

January  – Led by Hasekura Tsunenaga, Japan's trade expedition to New Spain (modern-day Mexico) arrives on the Mexican coast with  samurai,  Japanese merchants, sailors and servants, and  Spaniards and Portuguese who serve as interpreters. Having reached the Americas after a voyage that began on October , the expedition travels to Acapulco and arrives on January .
The Fama Fraternitatis is published, the first of three allegorical Rosicrucian manifestoes in the Holy Roman Empire.
January  – The New Netherland Company is granted a three-year monopoly in North American trade, between the 40th and 45th parallels.
John Browne is created the first King's Gunfounder in England.
May  – The Peace of Tyrnau is signed between Matthias, Holy Roman Emperor, and Gábor Bethlen.
June   – The Eastern Army of Tokugawa Ieyasu and the Osaka Army of Toyotomi Hideyori clash during the Battle of Dōmyōji and the Battle of Tennōji.
September  – Japanese diplomat Hasekura Tsunenaga and his entourage become the first officials from Japan to visit Italy, and are received in Rome by Cardinal Burgecio
February  – Manchurian leader Qing Tai Zu, referred to in the west as "Nurhaci", declares himself khan and crowns himself as Emperor of China, founding the Later Jin dynasty.
November  – In England, Sir Edward Coke is dismissed as Chief Justice of the King's Bench by royal prerogative.

January  – The city of Belém, Brazil is founded on the Amazon River delta, by Portuguese captain Francisco Caldeira Castelo Branco, who had previously taken the city of São Luís in Maranhão from the French.

The States of Holland sets up a commission to advise them on the problem of Jewish residency and worship. One of the members of the commission is Hugo Grotius, a highly regarded jurist and one of the most important political thinkers of his day.
The Ottoman Empire attempts landings at the shoreline between Cádiz and Lisbon.

December  – Lord Clifton is imprisoned at the Tower of London for threatening Francis Bacon, Lord Chancellor. Clifton is prosecuted by the Star Chamber on March  and eventually commits suicide in Fleet Prison.

May  – King James VI of Scotland authorizes the Scottish East India Company, led by Lord Glencairn to trade to the East Indies, the Levant, Greenland, Muscovy and all other islands in the north, north-west and north-eastern seas. James VI is advised that the authorization is not in conflict with charters granted by him in his capacity as King James I of England to England's East India Company, the Levant Company, and the Muscovy Company.
August  – King James of England and Scotland returns to England after having spent three months in Scotland, arriving at Wharton, Cumbria.
September  – The weighing ceremony of Jahangir is described by the first English ambassador to the Mughal court, Sir Thomas Roe.
October  – The coronation ceremony of King Gustav Adolf of Sweden takes place in Stockholm, almost six years after he succeeded to the throne.
January  – Rules are established for the Ōoku, the section of Edo Castle that housed the Shōgun's consort and his concubines.
September  – The Siege of Pilsen begins as the first major battle of the Thirty Years' War, as Bohemian Protestants lay siege to the Bohemian Catholic city and lasts for more than two months.
April  – Spanish-born Jesuit missionary Pedro Páez becomes (probably) the first European to see and describe the source of the Blue Nile in Ethiopia.
The margraves of Brandenburg are granted Polish approval to inherit the Duchy of Prussia, creating the state of Brandenburg-Prussia.
Ben Jonson's play Pleasure Reconciled to Virtue is given its premiere performance, presented at the Palace of Whitehall in London.
January  – James I of England's Banqueting House, Whitehall in London is destroyed by fire. Inigo Jones is commissioned to design a replacement.
Dutch statesman Johan van Oldenbarnevelt is executed in The Hague, after having been convicted of treason.
August  – A group of "twenty and odd" enslaved Africans, onboard the privateer ship White Lion (the first in the state of Virginia), are landed at Point Comfort in colonial Virginia.
July  – In Jamestown, Virginia, the first English-speaking representative assembly in the Americas, the Virginia General Assembly (later named House of Burgesses), convenes for the first time.
Anne of Denmark, queen consort of England, is buried at Westminster Abbey.
Shōgun Tokugawa Hidetada begins restoring Osaka Castle in Japan. Its modern-day appearance dates from this remodeling.

Mayflower and Speedwell return again to England, anchoring at Plymouth; the  latter ship is given up as a participant in the voyage and on September  (September  OS) departs for London, most of her passengers and stores having been transferred to the Mayflower.

August  (probable date; August  OS) – Mayflower and Speedwell depart together from Southampton, but are forced to put back into Dartmouth, Devon, for repairs to a leak in the latter ship on August  or  (August  or  OS).
February  – Prince Bethlen Gabor secures a peace treaty with Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor.

November  (November  OS) – The Mayflower arrives inside the tip of Cape Cod (named from the Concord voyage of ), at what becomes known as Provincetown Harbor, with the Pilgrims and Planters;  Plymouth Colony settlers sign the Mayflower Compact, the first governing document of the colony, on board the ship.
Samsu-Ditana becomes King of Babylon (middle chronology).
Lullaia becomes the King of Assyria.
Mursili I becomes King of the Hittite Empire (middle chronology).

Beginning of a period of cooling of the world climate lasting several years, recorded in tree-rings all over the world. Various volcanic eruptions have been suggested for the cause of this climatic event; the Minoan eruption of Thera, the Avellino eruption of Mount Vesuvius, or the eruption of Mount Aniakchak.
March  – The Pilgrims of Plymouth Colony sign a peace treaty with Massasoit of the Wampanoags.
May  – The Protestant Union is formally dissolved.
November  – The ship Fortune arrives at Plymouth Colony, with  more settlers.
January  – The Tianqi era begins in Ming Dynasty China, six months after Zhu Changluo becomes the Taichang Emperor.

The Dutch East India Company sends , soldiers, under the command of Jan Pieterszoon Coen, to the Banda Islands, in order to force the local inhabitants to accept the Dutch trade monopoly on the lucrative nutmeg, grown almost exclusively on those islands. The soldiers proceed to massacre most of the , indigenous inhabitants.
January  – The Holy Roman Empire and Transylvania sign the Peace of Nikolsburg.
December  – The Spanish colonial city of Bucaramanga is founded in the colony of Nueva Grandada in what is now Colombia.
July  or July  – English and Dutch ships defeat the Portuguese, near Portuguese East Africa.

July  – Thirty Years' War: After Mansfeld fails to relieve the siege of Heidelberg, Frederick V of the Palatinate cancels Mansfeld's contract and disbands his army. The unemployed army of Mansfeld and Christian the Younger of Brunswick is subsequently hired by the Dutch.

November  – King Christian IV of Denmark invites the Sephardic Jews of Amsterdam in the Dutch Republic to settle in the newly-built Danish town of Lykstad, promising them the free exercise of their religion without persecution. The city remains part of Denmark until  until it is captured in the Second Schleswig War and is now part of Germany as Glückstadt.
On the coast of New Hampshire, the settlement of Hilton's Point, which will become Dover, New Hampshire, is established by men from London, England, the first European settlers in the state.
Wilhelm Schickard devizes a Calculating Clock, an early mechanical calculator.

March  – Amboyna massacre: Ten English merchants in the service of the British East India Company, together with nine Japanese and one Portuguese, are executed by agents of the Dutch East India Company in Ambon, Maluku (Amboyna).
June  – The first breach-of-promise lawsuit: Rev. Gerville Pooley, in Virginia, files against Cicely Jordan, but loses.
The  Malta plague outbreak is contained after killing around  people on the island of Malta.
After years of unprofitable operation, Virginia's charter is revoked, and it becomes a royal colony.

September  – Ketevan, former queen consort of Kakheti (located around Gremi in what is now the Republic of Georgia), is tortured and killed in the Persian city of Shiraz after refusing to renounce Christianity to convert to Islam.
February  – Kara Mustafa Pasha becomes the Ottoman Governor of Egypt for the second time.
The Japanese shōgun expels the Spanish from Japan, and severs trade with the Philippines.
April  – Garcia Mvemba a Nkanga is enthroned as King Garcia I of the southern African nation of Kongo (now in Angola), upon the death of his father, King Pedro II.
January  – Led by the Duke of Soubise, the Huguenots launch a second rebellion against King Louis XIII, with a surprise naval assault on a French fleet being prepared in Blavet.
April  – Albrecht von Wallenstein is appointed German supreme commander of the armies of Holy Roman Emperor Ferdinand II.
August  – Ernest Casimir of Nassau-Dietz is appointed as stadtholder of Groningen.
The Dutch settle Manhattan, founding the town of New Amsterdam. The town will transform into a piece of New York City.
The first members of the Society of Jesus move to Quebec, Canada.
February  – Emperor Susenyos of Ethiopia and Patriarch Afonso Mendes declare the primacy of the Roman See over the Ethiopian Church, and Roman Catholicism the state religion of Ethiopia.
February  – King Charles I of England is crowned, but without his wife, Henrietta Maria, who declines to participate in a non-Catholic ceremony.
Establishment of the coastal settlement of Salem, Massachusetts.
May  – Peter Minuit buys Manhattan from a Native American tribe (Lenape or Shinnecock) for trade goods, valued at  guilders ($, U.S. dollars as of ).
January  – Polish-Swedish War: Battle of Wallhof in Latvia – Gustavus Adolphus, King of Sweden, defeats a Polish army.
November  – Polish-Swedish War: Battle of Oliwa – A Polish-Lithuanian fleet defeats a Swedish fleet.
Habsburg Spain suffers an economic collapse.
December  – La selva sin amor (The Forest without Love), written by Lope de Vega and with music by Alessandro Piccinini, premieres as the first Spanish opera.
April  – The States of Friesland agree on the -point Appeal about Abuses after allowing the citizens to voice their complaints.
June  – The States of Friesland promulgate the Resolution on the April  appeal about abuses.
The first black slaves arrive in Dutch Manhattan.

May  – Mehmed III Giray, the Khan of Crimea, is forced to leave after an invasion of , Cossacks and a four week siege of the capital Bakhchysarai. The attack is led by Mykhailo Doroshenko, who is killed in the battle.

February  – The Chongzhen Era begins in Ming dynasty China after the October  ascension of Zhu Youjian, the Chongzhen Emperor, on the first day of the Chinese New Year, and the Tianqi era formally ends.
December  – The attempt by the Mataram Sultanate to drive the Dutch East India Company from the western part of the island of Java fails after  days.
The War of the Mantuan Succession breaks out over Mantua and Montferrat. The war is fought between the Duke of Savoy, who is supported by Spain, and the Duke of Nevers, who is supported by France.
January  – Sam Mirza, son of the late Mohammad Baqer Mirza and grandson of Abbas the Great, is crowned as the new Shah of Persia and takes the regnal name Safi.
September  – Polish–Swedish War (–): Sweden and the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth sign the Truce of Altmark, ending the war in highly favourable terms for Sweden.

Chongzhen, the Chinese emperor of the Ming dynasty, reiterates the state prohibition against female infanticide, while the empire and the Chinese economy begins to crumble. In the same year, a third of the courier stations are closed down due to lack of government funds to sustain them.
September  – ( Safar  AH) Ahmad ibn Abd al-Muttalib, who had become Emir of Mecca and King of the Hejaz by force  months earlier, is assassinated by order of Kansuh Pasha, Governor of Yemen.
November  – The St Etienne baronets British nobility title is created.

January  – In China, General Yuan Chonghuan is invited to an audience with the Chongzhen Emperor and is arrested on charges of collusion with the enemy. Yuan is executed by the slow death on September .

June  – Scottish-born Presbyterian (and former physician) Alexander Leighton is brought before Archbishop William Laud's Star Chamber court in London for publishing the seditious pamphlet An Appeale to the Parliament, or, Sions Plea Against the Prelacy, an attack on Anglican bishops (printed in the Netherlands, ). He is sentenced to be pilloried and whipped, have his ears cropped, one side of his nose slit, and his face branded with "SS" (for "sower of sedition"), to be imprisoned, and be degraded from holy orders.
October  – Frendraught Castle in Scotland, the home of James Crichton of Frendraught, burns down.
May  – The Battle of Villabuona is fought in Italy at Lombardy, with more than , French and Venetian troops killed in an attack by Matthias Gallas of the Holy Roman Empire's army.
The central square of Covent Garden in London is laid out, and a market begins to develop there.

August – Thirty Years' War: Running out of supplies, Tilly is forced to send his army into the Electorate of Saxony in order to secure supplies, as well as to force a reaction from John George, Elector of Saxony and Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden.
March  – Ambrósio I Nimi a Nkanga, the ruler of the Kingdom of Kongo (in what is now Angola) dies after a reign of five years.
Antonio Colmenero de Ledesma's [es] Chocolate: or, An Indian Drinke.
Moses Amyraut's Traite des Religions.

September  – Thirty Years' War – Battle of Breitenfeld: Tilly's Holy Roman Imperial army is decisively defeated by Gustavus II Adolphus of Sweden, shattering the imperial army of the Holy Roman Empire, and marking the first significant victory for the Protestants in the war.
Two ships, Saint Jean ( tons) and L'Esperance-en-Dieu, set sail from La Rochelle in France, bound for Acadia in North America.
June  – Sir Francis Windebank is made chief Secretary of State in England.
November  – Wladyslaw IV Waza is elected king of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, after Sigismund III Vasa's death.

April  – Thirty Years' War: Battle of Rain – Gustavus Adolphus defeats Tilly's Catholic League armies for the second time within a year; Tilly is severely wounded during the battle and dies on April .

June 
Charles I of England issues a charter for the colony of Maryland (named in honor of Henrietta Maria), under the control of Lord Baltimore.
Two ships, Saint Jean ( tons) and L'Esperance-en-Dieu, set sail from La Rochelle in France, bound for Acadia in North America.
English colonists settle what will become the town of Hingham, Massachusetts.
October  – Battle of Liaoluo Bay: A large Ming dynasty fleet under Zheng Zhilong defeats a Dutch East India Company fleet at the island of Quemoy.
October  – Thirty Years' War: Siege of Rheinfelden – Spain recaptures Rheinfelden from Sweden.
Mission San Luis de Apalachee is built in the New World by two Spanish friars.
Galileo Galilei arrives in Rome for his trial before the Inquisition.
February  – Rebel Scots and Irish soldiers assassinate Bohemian military leader Albrecht von Wallenstein at Cheb.
Moses Amyraut's Traité de la predestination is published.
February  – By this date, the Paulaner Brewery is established in Munich, by Minim friars.
March  – Belgian scientist Jan Baptist van Helmont is interrogated by the Spanish Inquisition and put under house arrest for his experiments into plant growth.
January  – After suspecting that he will be dismissed, Albrecht von Wallenstein, supreme commander of the Holy Roman Empire's Army, demands that his colonels sign a declaration of personal loyalty.
February  – The Académie française in Paris is formally constituted, as the national academy for the preservation of the French language.
May  – France declares war on Spain.
August  – The Great Colonial Hurricane strikes Narragansett Bay as a possible Category  hurricane, killing over  people.
Dominica is claimed by France.
The Ottomans are expelled from Yemen.
The first synagogue of the New World, Kahal Zur Israel Synagogue, is founded in Recife by the Dutch.
October  (September  Old Style) – Thirty Years' War – Battle of Wittstock: A Swedish-allied army defeats a combined Imperial-Saxon army.
August  (August  Old Style) – The covenant of the Town of Dedham, Massachusetts Bay Colony is first signed.
January  – The Duke's Mistress, the last play by James Shirley, is given its first performance.
January  – Anthony van Diemen takes office as Governor-General of the Dutch East Indies (now Indonesia), and will serve until his death in .
February  – Ferdinand III becomes Holy Roman Emperor upon the death of his father, Ferdinand II, although his formal coronation does not take place until later in the year.
Scottish army officer Robert Monro publishes Monro, His Expedition With the Worthy Scots Regiment Called Mac-Keys in London, the first military history in English.
After a court battle, King Charles I of England hands over title to the North American colony of Massachusetts to Sir Ferdinando Gorges, one of the founders of Plymouth Council for New England.
December  – The Shimabara Rebellion erupts in Japan, when , peasants in the heavily Catholic area of northern Kyūshū revolt.

Introduction of a new Scottish Prayer Book is met with widespread demonstrations, notably that of Jenny Geddes at St Giles' Cathedral, Edinburgh, who is said to have thrown a stool at the Dean's head.
Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan and his sons capture the city of Kandahar from the Safavids.

March 
Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan and his sons capture the city of Kandahar from the Safavids. 
Anne Hutchinson is banished from the Massachusetts Bay Colony for heresy and goes to Rhode Island.

The Peking Gazette makes an official switch in its production process of newspapers, from woodblock printing to movable type printing (private newspapers in Ming dynasty China were first mentioned in ).

January  – Shimabara Rebellion: The siege of Shimabara Castle ends after  days in Japan's Tokugawa shogunate (part of modern-day Nagasaki prefecture) as the rebel peasants flee reinforcements sent by the shogun Tokugawa Iemitsu.
November  – New Haven, the first planned city in America, is founded when local Indians make a deed of Quinnipiac to Theophilus Eaton and other English settlers.
April – Following the Battle of Chemnitz Swedish forces under command of Johan Banér invades Bohemia with great success

June 
The Treaty of Berwick is signed between Charles I and the Scots.
On the same day, the first battle of the Bishops' Wars is fought by Earl Marischal and the Marquess of Montrose when they lead a Covenanter army of , men past Muchalls Castle over the Causey Mounth to fight at the Bridge of Dee in Scotland.

The Casiquiare canal, a river forming a natural channel between the Amazon River and Orinoco River basins, is first encountered by Europeans, an expedition led by Pedro Teixeira and Cristóbal Diatristán de Acuña.

November  – In Normandy, the revolt of the va-nu-pieds is crushed by the troops of French Army Colonel Jean de Gassion under orders of Armand Jean du Plessis, Cardinal Richelieu, with  of the rebels killed.
December  – English astronomer Jeremiah Horrocks makes the first successful prediction and observation of a transit of Venus.
Frederick William, Elector of Brandenburg begins to rule.
May  – The Short Parliament is dissolved.
July   – The first university of Finland, the Royal Academy of Turku, is inaugurated in Turku.
The first known European coffeehouse opens in Venice.

January  – A naval battle over control of what is now Brazil, between ships of the Dutch Republic and those of the Kingdom of Portugal, ends after five days of fighting with the Dutch driving the Portuguese away from the port of Recife.
Moses Amyraut's De l'elevation de la foy et de l'abaissement de la raison en la creance des mysteres de la religion is published.
August  – Charles I of England signs the Treaty of London ending the Bishops' Wars between England and Scotland.
The Norwegian city of Kristiansand is founded by King Christian IV of Denmark-Norway.

September 
In Germany, the Siege of Dorsten by the Holy Roman Empire ends after nine weeks with the surrender of the Landgraviate of Hesse-Kassel after the Hessians suffer , casualties.
In France, the siege of Bapaume ends with the surrender of the fortress by its Spanish occupiers.
December  – Pope Urban VIII announces the creation of  new cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church.
February  – The Treaty of The Hague (), between the Dutch Republic and the Kingdom of Portugal, is ratified by the Republic's States-General.

May  – In a Catholic synod at Kilkenny, bishops draft the Confederate Oath of Association, calling on Catholics to swear allegiance to King Charles I and to obey orders and decrees made by a "Supreme Council of the Confederate Catholics", hence the Irish rebels of  become known as Confederate Ireland.
August  – Irish Confederate Wars: Lord Forbes relieves Forthill, and besieges Galway.
May  – Ville-Marie (later Montreal) is founded as a permanent settlement.
August  – First English Civil War begins when King Charles I raises the royal battle standard over Nottingham Castle, so declaring war on his own Parliament.
April  – Åmål, Sweden, is granted its city charter.

May  – Louis XIV succeeds his father Louis XIII as King of France at age . His rule will last until his death at age  in , a total of  years, which will be the longest reign of any European monarch in recorded history.
The New England Confederation is formed as a military alliance between Massachusetts Bay Colony, Plymouth Colony, Saybrook Colony (Connecticut), and New Haven Colony.
November  – Thirty Years' War: Battle of Tuttlingen – France is defeated by forces of the Holy Roman Empire.
Miyamoto Musashi begins to dictate The Book of Five Rings (Go Rin No Sho) to his student; he will complete it in , just before his death.
June  – The invading Qing army, with the help of Ming general Wu Sangui, captures Beijing in China, marking the beginning of Manchu rule over China proper.

November 
Battle of Jüterbog (December  New Style): Sweden's forces defeat those of the Holy Roman Empire.
Areopagitica, an appeal for freedom of speech written by John Milton, is published in London.
January  – The Royalist Oxford Parliament is first assembled by King Charles I of England.
November – The Castle of Elvas in Portugal resists a -day siege by the Spanish during the Portuguese Restoration War.
Philosopher René Descartes publishes Principia Philosophiae (Principles of Philosophy) in Amsterdam.
June  – English Civil War: The Royalists lose Carlisle.

August  (August  Old Style) – The Treaty of Brömsebro is signed between Sweden and Denmark–Norway, ending the Torstenson War and ceding Jemtland, Herjedalen, Gotland and Ösel (Saaremaa) to Sweden, which also holds the province of Halland for a period of  years, as a guarantee.

May  – Thirty Years' War – Battle of Herbsthausen (or Mergentheim): The Bavarian army, led by Franz von Mercy, catches French forces led by Marshal Henri de la Tour d'Auvergne, Vicomte de Turenne unawares, and heavily defeats them.
July  – Qing dynasty regent Dorgon issues a queue order ordering all Han Chinese men to shave their forehead, and braid the rest of their hair into a queue, identical to those of the Manchus.
February  – Battle of Inverlochy: The Scottish Covenanters are defeated by Montrose.

The Westminster Assembly of Divines, meeting in London, approves a resolution to begin the drawing up of the Westminster Confession of Faith, declaring that "These heads of Faith, Repentance, and Good Works shall be referred to the three Committees in their order to prepare something upon them for the Confession of Faith."; the draft is printed and sent to the Parliament of England in December.

January  – Sir Richard Grenville, 1st Baronet, a Royalist fighting for Prince Charles against Oliver Cromwell's Commonwealth, is imprisoned for insubordination after proposing to make Cornwall self-governing in order to win Cornish support for the Royalists.  After being incarcerated at the tidal island of St Michael's Mount off of the coast of Cornwall, he is allowed to escape in March to avoid capture by Cromwell's troops.
February  – Roger Scott is tried in Massachusetts for sleeping in church.
September  – The new Orange College of Breda opens at Breda in the Dutch Republic.

August 
The Westminster Assembly of Divines, meeting in London, approves a resolution to begin the drawing up of the Westminster Confession of Faith, declaring that "These heads of Faith, Repentance, and Good Works shall be referred to the three Committees in their order to prepare something upon them for the Confession of Faith."; the draft is printed and sent to the Parliament of England in December.
First English Civil War: Raglan Castle in Wales surrenders to General Fairfax after a -month siege; it is later destroyed.
February  – The Yongli era is proclaimed as Zhu Youlang is declared the Yongli Emperor of the Southern Ming.
August  – Battle of Dungan's Hill: Irish forces are defeated by English Parliamentary forces.
Dutch artist Salomon van Ruysdael completes the oil painting, The Crossing at Nijmegen.

June  – The Puritan rulers of England's Long Parliament pass the "Ordinance for abolishing all Holidays, and appointing other Days for Sports and Recreations for Scholars, Apprentices, and Servants, in their Room", confirming abolition of the feasts of Christmas, Easter and Whitsun, though making the second Tuesday in each month a secular holiday.  The Act declares "Forasmuch as the Feasts of the Nativity of Christ, Easter, and Whitsuntide, and other Festivals, commonly called Holidays, have heretofore been superstitiously used and observed; be it ordained, That the said Feasts and Festivals be no loner observed within England and Wales."
January  – Posten Norge is founded as Postvesenet.
May  – England's Commonwealth Army massacres  Cornish royalists at Penzance, leading to a rebellion against England's Parliamentarians.
January  – France's Royal Council votes to create the Académie royale after accepting the proposal of Martin de Charmois.
May  – Construction of the Kaunghmudaw Pagoda is completed in the Kingdom of Burma on the 6th waning of Kason, , near the end of the reign of King Thalun. Hmannan Yazawin
August – The Cambridge Platform, a new, localized system of Christian church governance, is agreed upon and written down in New England.

February  – England's parliament passes stricter laws against performance of stage plays, providing for demolition of seats in theatres, imprisonment for actors and fines for spectators.  The vote comes six days after the King's Men Players are arrested at the Cockpit Theatre during an illegal performance of Rollo Duke of Normandy.
May  – "An act declaring England to be a Commonwealth" is passed by the Rump Parliament.

May   – The Wyandot people Indian tribe complete the burning of  of their own villages, to prevent their stores from being taken by the Haudenasaunee Iroquois.  Almost all the remaining people (approximately ,) become refugees, on a path that eventually brings them to Wendake.
March  – The rebel Frondeurs and the French government sign the Peace of Rueil.

January  – Serfdom in Russia begins legally as the Sobornoye Ulozheniye (Соборное уложение, "Code of Law") is signed by members of the Zemsky Sobor, the parliament of the estates of the realm in the Tsardom of Russia.  Slaves and free peasants are consolidated by law into the new hereditary class of "serfs", and the Russian nobility are given the exclusive privilege of owning the serfs.
Qing armies reconquer Jiangxi province during the Manchu conquest of China.
June  – The Harvard Corporation, the more powerful of the two administrative boards of Harvard, is established (the first legal corporation in the Americas).

November  – William III of Orange becomes Prince of the House of Orange at the moment of his birth, succeeding his father, who had died a few days earlier. He does not become stadtholder, so the United Provinces becomes a true republic.
June  – Claimant King Charles II of England, Scotland and Ireland arrives in Scotland (at Garmouth), the only one of the three kingdoms that has accepted him as ruler.
July  – William II, Prince of Orange, stadtholder of Holland, attempts to conquer the rest of the Netherlands and attempts a coup d'état against the Dutch Republic.
The first modern Palio di Siena horserace is held in Italy.
Second Intermediate Period starts in Ancient Egypt (other date is ).
The Rhind Mathematical Papyrus is produced.
Middle Kingdom ends in Ancient Egypt (other date is ).
Egypt—Start of Seventeenth Dynasty.
Tan-Uli, the ruler of the Elamite Empire, dies.
January  – Parliament of Boroa in Chile: Spanish and Mapuche authorities meet at Boroa, renewing the fragile peace established at the parliaments of Quillín, in  and .
March  – St. Peter's Flood: Another storm tide in the North Sea strikes the Netherlands, flooding Amsterdam.
September  – The siege of Dundee ends with the English Parliamentarian army, under General Monck, decisively defeating Covenanters in the last battle of the Wars of the Three Kingdoms in Scotland.
October – An English diplomatic team, headed by Oliver St John, goes to The Hague to negotiate an alliance between the Commonwealth of England and the Dutch Republic.

May  – The Sovereign Military Order of Malta purchases the Caribbean islands of Saint Barthélemy, Saint Christopher, Saint Croix and Saint Martin from the France's Compagnie des Îles de l'Amérique.  The Order will sell the islands in  to the French West India Company.

July  – The Battle of the Faubourg St Antoine is fought east of Paris between French Parliamentarians (led by Louis, Grand Condé) against the army of King Louis XIV, commanded by the Viscount of Turenne, with neither side prevailing.

October  – First Anglo-Dutch War: Battle of the Kentish Knock – In a battle fought near the shoal called the Kentish Knock in the North Sea, about  km ( mi) from the mouth of the River Thames, the Dutch are forced to withdraw.
January  – Michiel de Ruyter marries the widow Anna van Gelder and plans retirement, but months later becomes a vice-commodore in the First Anglo-Dutch War.

February  – Oliver Cromwell, England's Lord Protector, announces that his Council of Scotland will regulate church affairs as part of the Terms of Incorporation of Scotland into England, and eliminates Presbyterianism as Scotland's state religion.
March  (April  New Style) – Total solar eclipse of April ,  ("Black Monday").
Marcello Malpighi, an Italian pioneer of microscopical anatomy becomes a doctor of medicine.
January – The Swiss Peasant War begins after magistrates meeting at Lucerne refuse to hear from a group of peasants who have been financially hurt by the devaluation of the currency issued from Bern.

December  – The Moti Masjid, an Islamic mosque made completely of white marble and within the walls of the Agra Fort in what is now the city of Agra in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, is dedicated by the Mughal Emperor, Shah Jahan, on  Muharram .
July  – John Thurloe becomes Cromwell's head of intelligence.
March  – A Dutch fleet defeats the English in the Battle of Leghorn in the Mediterranean but the Dutch commander, Johan van Galen, later dies of his wounds.

August  – The Battle of Shklow, one of the first clashes of the Russo-Polish War, takes place at the modern-day Belarusan town of Škłoŭ during a total eclipse of the Sun visible over Eastern Europe. The Russian troops retreat.

December  – An English Navy fleet of  warships and  transports, carrying  cannons, , seamen, and , troops, under the command of Admiral William Penn departs from Portsmouth to begin Oliver Cromwell's planned surprise attack on Spain's colonies in the New World.
December  – Sir William Petty wins the contract from the Commonwealth of England to make a survey of Ireland.

January  – Portugal recaptures the South American city of Recife from the Netherlands after a siege of more than two years during the Dutch-Portuguese War, bringing an end to Dutch rule of what is now Brazil. The Dutch West India Company has held the city (which they call Mauritsstad) for more than  years.
April  – The Treaty of Westminster, ending the First Anglo-Dutch War, is signed.

July 
The Jews in New Amsterdam petition for a separate Jewish cemetery.
The Netherlands and Brandenburg sign a military treaty.
April  – The Dutch West India Company denies Peter Stuyvesant's request to exclude Jews from New Amsterdam (Manhattan).
September  – Peter Stuyvesant recaptures the Dutch Fory Casimir, and defeats the New Sweden (Delaware) colony.
October  – The Jews of Lublin are massacred.
The Bibliotheca Thysiana is erected, the only surviving  example in the Netherlands, of a building designed as a library.

March  – Fyodor Baykov, the Russian Empire's first envoy to China, is admitted to the Forbidden City within Beijing, after being sent by Tsar Alexis to negotiate a trade agreement with the Emperor Shunzi.

December  – The Treaty of Radnot is signed between Sweden, the Electorate of Brandenburg, Transylvania (now Romania), and two rebels groups within Poland on how to divide the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth in the event of a victory in the Second Northern War.

December  – King Frederick III of Denmark and Norway decrees that loan repayments and payments of interest to lenders will be made on two specific days, May  and June , each one nicknamed the Fandens fødselsdag or "Devil's Birthday",

February  – London's Lord Mayor Christopher Packe suggests to Oliver Cromwell, the Lord Protector and chief executive of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland and Ireland, that the monarchy should be restored with Cromwell as its King.  Cromwell declines to become King Oliver, but his right to name his successor becomes effective on May ,  with the commencement of the Humble Petition and Advice.
June  – Bertuccio Valier is elected as the new Doge of the Venetian Republic in Venice.
The Jews of New Amsterdam (later New York City) are granted freedom of religion, as full citizens.

April 
Anglo-Spanish War – Battle of Santa Cruz de Tenerife: English Admiral Robert Blake attempts to seize a Spanish treasure fleet.
The Jews of New Amsterdam (later New York City) are granted freedom of religion, as full citizens.
The first eleven Quaker settlers arrive in New Amsterdam (later New York City), and are allowed to practice their faith.
October  – French troops occupy Mardyck.
March  – The Great Fire of Meireki in Edo, Japan, destroys most of the city and damages Edo Castle, killing an estimated , people.
November  – The Mexican Inquisition carries out the execution, by public burning, of  men convicted of homosexuality, while another  arrested are either released or given less harsh sentences.
May  – Hydriotaphia, Urn Burial and The Garden of Cyrus are published by Thomas Browne in England.
May  – Aurangzeb wins the Battle of Samugarh as Indian Mughal regent Dara Shikoh makes a last effort to defend the Mughal capital Agra.
June  – Pope Alexander VII appoints François de Laval vicar apostolic of New France.
October  – The Netherlands enters the Dano-Swedish War to come to the rescue of Denmark, sending a -ship fleet from Vlie.

June  – Dara Shikoh, at one time the heir apparent for the Mughal Empire, is betrayed by an Afghan chieftain, Junaid Khan Barozai, who had initially given him refuge from pursuit from the new emperor, Aurangzeb. Turned over to Aurangzeb's men, Dara Shikoh is killed on August .

July  – Five women are executed by hanging at Rome after being convicted of murder in the Spana Prosecution by distributing the powerful Aqua Tofana poison, sold primarily to women wishing to get rid of their husbands. Put to death on the same day are Gironima Spana, Giovanna De Grandis, Maria Spinola, Graziosa Farina and Laura Crispoldi, in the public square at the Campo de' Fiori.

November  – The Treaty of the Pyrenees is signed by representatives of King Louis XIV of France and King Philip IV of Spain. Spain agrees to French acquisition of the counties of Roussillon and Upper Cerdanya (Principality of Catalonia) and most of Artois, formally ending the -year-long Franco-Spanish War.
February  – The Assault on Copenhagen by Swedish forces is beaten back, with heavy losses.

March  – In exile in the Netherlands while plotting the restoration of the monarchy to England, Scotland and Ireland, Charles, son of the late King Charles I appoints seven royalists (including six from the "Sealed Knot" group) to a "Great Trust and Commission" to make plans for a post-restoration government. The Great Trust is led by Charles's trusted advisor, Edward Hyde.

Samuel Pepys, a -year-old member of the Parliament of England, begins keeping a diary that later provides a detailed insight into daily life and events in  England.  He continues until May , , when worsening eyesight leads him to quit.  .  Pepys starts with a preliminary note, "Blessed be God, at the end of the last year I was in very good health, without any sense of my old pain but upon taking of cold. I lived in Axe-yard, having my wife and servant Jane, and no more in family than us three."  For his first note on "January . / Lords-day", he notes "This morning (we lying lately in the garret) I rose, put on my suit with great skirts, having not lately worn any other clothes but them," followed by recounting his attendance at the Exeter-house church in London.
May  – The Desormeaux caravan and  Iroquois die in explosion at Long Sault.

February  – The Rump Parliament, under pressure from General Monck, votes to call back all of the surviving members of the group of  MPs who had been removed from the House of Commons in  so that the Long Parliament can be reassembled long enough for a full Parliament to approve elections for a new legislative body.
January  – The Rump Parliament confirms the promotion of Colonel George Monck to the rank of General and he receives the commission of rank while at St Albans.

December  – Andres Malong, a native chieftain of the town of Binalatongan (now San Carlos) in the Philippines, leads a successful revolt against the Spanish colonial administrators to liberate Pangasinan. He is proclaimed the King of Pangasinan, but the rebellion is suppressed on January , , and Pangasinan is reconquered by February.

August  – Portugal and the Dutch Republic sign the Treaty of The Hague, whereby the Dutch Republic's South American colony of Nieuw-Holland is sold to Portugal for the equivalent of roughly , kilograms (, lb) of gold, and incorporated into Brazil.  The territory includes much of what will later become the Brazilian states of Ceará, Maranhão, Paraíba, Pernambuco and Rio Grande do Norte.  Among the major Dutch settlements lost are Mauritsstad (Recife), Fort Schoonenborch (Fortaleza), Nieuw-Amsterdam (Natal), and Frederikstadt (João Pessoa).

December  – General Wu Sangui of China arrives in Burma with , troops and demands that the Burmese surrender Yongli, the last of the Ming dynasty rulers of Southern China before the Qing dynasty consolidated its rule.   Burma's King Pye Min hands Yongli over to General Wu on January , and Yongli is subsequently executed.
October  – Guru Har Krishan becomes eighth of the ten Sikh gurus, and at age  the youngest, following the death of his father Guru Har Rai.
Great Clearance in China: evacuation of Guangdong is required.
December  – The Indian city of Quilon (now Kollam in the Kerala state), ruled by Portugal since , is captured by the Dutch East India Company.

February  – The survivors of the wreck of the Dutch freighter Arnhem strike reefs but are able to make their way to an uninhabited island, probably the Ile D'Ambre or Ilot Fourneau  both islands within the territory of Mauritius. During more than two months while shipwrecked, the survivors kill and eat the local wildlife, including the last surviving dodo. They are rescued by the English ship Truroe in May.

August  – The Act of Uniformity goes into effect on St Bartholomew's Day, making mandatory in the Church of England the forms of worship prescribed in the new edition of the Book of Common Prayer the deadline having been set for "every clergyman and every schoolmaster... to express, by August , his unfeigned consent to everything contained in the Book of Common Prayer. This is followed by the resignation of over , clergy who resign "for conscience sake". Those who refuse to take the required oath of conformity to the established church are subject to the Great Ejection from their jobs.
January  – Dziaddin Mukarram Shah becomes the new Sultan of Kedah, an independent kingdom on the Malay Peninsula, upon the death of his father, Sultan Muhyiddin Mansur.
September  – The first payments under England's hearth tax law, enacted on May , become due.

May – The last credible report of a sighting of the dodo bird, now extinct, is made by Volkert Evertsz, a survivor of the shipwreck of the Dutch ship Arnhem, which struck reefs on February . The survivors had made their way in a small boat to Ile d'Ambre, an island in the Indian Ocean  kilometres ( mi) northeast of Mauritius. When rescued by the English ship Truroe in May, Evertsz reports that he and his group had survived by eating the local wildlife, including the dodo.
March  – King Charles II of England issues the Charter of Carolina, establishing the Province of Carolina, and dividing it between eight Lords Proprietors.
February  – An earthquake estimated at least . magnitude strikes Canada's Quebec Province.

Publication at Cambridge in the Massachusetts Bay Colony of the "Eliot Indian Bible" (Mamusse Wunneetupanatamwe Up-Biblum God), which becomes the first complete Bible published in the Americas, a translation by English-born Puritan missionary John Eliot of the Geneva Bible, from English into the Massachusett language (Natic or Wômpanâak) variety of the Algonquian languages.

June  – Under the pretext of working out a treaty with Dutch settlers in the colony of New Netherland, the Esopus tribe of the Delaware people enter the fortress at Wiltwijck (now the U.S. city of Kingston, New York) and stage a surprise attack.  Unbeknownst to the Wiltwijck residents, another group of Esopus warriors had destroyed the village of Nieu Dorp (now Hurley, New York) earlier in the day.  The episode begins the Second Esopus War.

October  – With , men under his command, Petar Zrinski, the Viceroy of Croatia within the Holy Roman Empire, defeats a much larger force of , Ottoman soldiers in the Battle at Jurjeve Stijene, near the modern town of Otočac.  The Croatians lose  soldiers killed; the Ottoman invasion force suffers over , deaths.

January  – Indian entrepreneur Virji Vora, described in the  by the English East India Company as the richest merchant in the world, suffers the loss of a large portion of his wealth when the Maratha troops of Shivaji plunder his residence at Surat and his business warehouses.

April  – Juan Alonso de Cuevas y Dávalos is appointed as the new Roman Catholic Archbishop of Mexico by Pope Alexander VII, to allow Archbishop Mateo de Sagade de Bugueyro to return to Spain.  Archbishop Cuevas is installed on November  upon his arrival in Mexico City.
December  – All but  members of the over -person crew of the Dutch ship Kennemerland are killed when the trade ship sinks in a storm near the Out Skerries islands off of the coast of Scotland.
December  – The English warships HMS Nonsuch and HMS Phoenix are wrecked in a storm at Gibraltar.
May  – Robert Hooke discovers Jupiter's Great Red Spot.
November  – The London Gazette is first published as The Oxford Gazette.
January  – The Journal des sçavans begins publication as the first scientific journal in France.
June  – England installs a municipal government in New York City (the former Dutch settlement of New Amsterdam).
December  – The Royal Netherlands Marine Corps is founded by Michiel de Ruyter.

February  – Molière's comedy Dom Juan ou le Festin de pierre, based on the Spanish legend of the womanizer Don Juan Tenorio and Tirso de Molina's Spanish play El burlador de Sevilla y convidado de piedra, premieres in Paris at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal.

June  (June  Julian calendar) – The Four Days' Battle between the Dutch Republic fleet ( ships under the command of Admiral Michiel de Ruyter) and the English Royal Navy ( ships led by the Duke of Albemarle) in the North Sea, one of the longest naval engagements in history, ends with a retreat by the English after having started on June . A part of the Second Anglo-Dutch War, the battle ends with a Dutch victory, but heavy losses are sustained on both sides: the English lose , men and  ships are sunk, while the Dutch lose four ships and , men. Damaged, but not destroyed, the English fleet sets about repairs and refitting, and meets the Dutch fleet again on July  in the St. James's Day Battle.
Jean Talon completes a census of New France, the first census in North America.

December  – A sobor (church council) of the Russian Orthodox Church deposes Patriarch Nikon of Moscow, but accepts his liturgical reforms. Dissenters from these, known as Old Believers, continue into the .
January  – The Chair of Saint Peter (Cathedra Petri, designed by Bernini) is set above the altar in St. Peter's Basilica in Rome.

Isaac Newton uses a prism to split sunlight, as referenced in his alchemical works as Lux Dei, into the component colours of the optical spectrum, assisting the understanding of the scientific nature of light. He also develops differential calculus simultaneously with Leibniz.  is consequently referred to as his Annus mirabilis or Newton's "Year of the Morning Star".
The first military campaign of Stenka Razin is conducted in Russia.

February  – During the Second Anglo-Dutch War, a Dutch Navy force commanded by Admiral Abraham Crijnssen arrives at the English colony of Surinam in South America and sails up the Suriname River to Fort Willoughby (later Fort Zeelandia at Paramaribo). Bombardment of the fort begins the next day, and its commander, William Byam surrenders, effectively giving control of Surinam to the Dutch Republic. The cession is confirmed with the signing of the Peace of Breda on July .

January  – Aurangzeb, monarch of the Mughal Empire, orders the removal of Rao Karan Singh as Maharaja of the Bikaner State (part of the modern-day Rajasthan state of India) because of Karan's dereliction of duty in battle.
John Dryden's comedy Sir Martin Mar-all, or The Feign'd Innocence is given its first performance, presented by the players of the King's Theatre in London.

March – Louis XIV of France abolishes the livre parisis (Paris pound), in favor of the much more widely used livre tournois (Tours pound). He also designates Gabriel Nicolas de la Reynie as the first chief of "police" of Paris.
July  – The magnitude . Shandong earthquake kills at least , people in China's Shandong province.

July  – Henry Morgan's raid on Porto Bello: Welsh privateer Henry Morgan and  men under his command plunder the city of Portobello on the Isthmus of Panama and spend -days in the attack before withdrawing.
December  – Fritz Cronman arrives in Moscow as the Swedish Empire's ambassador to the Russian Empire, accompanied by a staff of  people.
August  – The magnitude . North Anatolia earthquake causes , deaths in northern Anatolia, Ottoman Empire, and is the most powerful earthquake recorded in Turkey.
January  – The Triple Alliance of  is formed between England, Sweden and the United Provinces of the Netherlands.
September  – The formal coronation of Michał Korybut Wiśniowiecki as King of Poland (and Grand Duke of Lithuania) takes place in Kraków.
Ottoman units burn the eastern part of Kolárovo.
May  – The first people executed in Sweden's Mora witch trial are put to death, with seven women and one man beheaded after being convicted of "abduction of children to Satan."

December  – A papal conclave that will last for four months begins in Rome to select a successor to Pope Clement IX, who had died  days earlier.  At the opening,  of the  members of the College of Cardinals are present.  At least  Cardinals are considered for the papacy before Emilio Altieri is selected on April  to become Pope Clement X.

August  – A group of English settlers, led by Joseph West, departs from The Downs on the ship Carolina with instructions to make the first European settlement in the modern-day U.S. state of South Carolina. After a long voyage with stops in Ireland and Barbados, the Carolina settlers arrive at Port Royal on March  next.

February  – The royal wedding in Poland, between King Michal Wisniowiecki (who is also the Grand Duke of Lithuania) and Eleonore of Austria (daughter of the late Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor), with ceremonies taking place at the Denhoff Palace in Kruszyna.

April  – After more than four months, the papal conclave to elect a successor to the late Pope Clement IX selects Cardinal Emilio Albieri with  of the  votes. Altieri,  years old at the time, remains the oldest person ever to be elected pope. He announces that he will take the name of Pope Clement X in honor of Clement IX, who had made him a cardinal. He serves for six years until his death in  shortly after his 86th birthday.
November  – Louis XIV of France inaugurates the construction of Les Invalides, a veterans' hospital in Paris.
January  – The Muslim emperor Aurangzeb of the Mughal Empire in India issues an order for the destruction of all Hindu temples and schools in the empire, including the Keshvadeva Temple in Mathura.

July  (July , O.S.) – The Treaty of Madrid, also known as the Godolphin Treaty, is signed between England and Spain to formally end hostilities left over from the Anglo-Spanish War, in the Caribbean, that ended ten years earlier. For the first time, Spain acknowledges that it is not entitled to all territory in the Americas west of Brazil, as provided by the  line of demarcation decreed by Pope Alexander VI, and by the  Treaty of Tordesillas between Spain and Portugal. Spain acknowledges that Jamaica and the Cayman Islands are English possessions.
End of Middle Kingdom in Ancient Egypt. Start of the Second intermediate period, the 15th–17th Dynasties.
Egypt—Start of the Fifteenth Dynasty.

December  – The first Seventh Day Baptist church in America is founded with a service on a Saturday at Newport, Rhode Island, by Stephen Mumford and four Sabbatarians who believed that Christian church services should be held on Saturday, the seventh and last day of the week, in keeping with the commandment of remembering the Sabbath.

November  – The Duke of York's Theatre is opened in London by the players of the Duke's Company, rivals to the "King's Company" at the Theatre Royal, which burns down two months later.  The site is now the Dorset Garden Theatre.
August  – Jamaica's Governor Thomas Lynch offers a general pardon to pirates who are willing to come under Jamaican jurisdiction.

May  – Thomas Blood, disguised as a clergyman, attempts to steal the Crown Jewels of the United Kingdom from the Tower of London. He is immediately caught, because he is too drunk to run with the loot. He is later condemned to death, and then mysteriously pardoned and exiled by King Charles II.

March  – The Danish West India Company, a charter ship company whose operations include human trafficking of African slaves to the Western Hemisphere by its Danish Africa Company subsidiary, is founded.

February  (February ,  O.S.) – Isaac Newton sends a paper for publication regarding his experiments on the refraction of light through glass prisms and makes the first identification of the "primary colors" of visible light on the electromagnetic spectrum, reporting that "The Original or primary colours are, Red, Yellow, Green, Blew, and a Violet-purple, together with Orange, Indico, and an indefinite variety of Intermediate gradations."

December  – French astronomer Giovanni Domenico Cassini discovers Rhea, a previously-unknown satellite of the planet Saturn.  Rhea is the second-largest overall, and the third moon of Saturn to be discovered by Earth astronomers, Titan having been found by Christiaan Huygens on March ,  and Iapetus by Cassini on October , .
August  – Johan de Witt, Grand Pensionary of Holland and his brother Cornelis de Witt are killed by an Orangist mob in The Hague.
September  – William III of Orange, Stadtholder of the Dutch Republic, dismisses nine of the regenten who lead cities in the Netherlands, after being granted authority by the States-General.

March  – At the Synod of Jerusalem, presided over by Dositheos II of Jerusalem, the  bishops and representatives from the whole of Eastern Orthodox Christendom close by approving the Orthodox dogma against the challenge of Protestantism, declaring against "the falsehoods of the adversaries which they have devised against the Eastern Church" and making a goal of "reformation of their innovations and for their return to the catholic and apostolic church in which their forefathers also were."
July  – French troops conquer Maastricht.

March  – Test Act: Roman Catholics and others who refuse to receive the sacrament of the Church of England cannot vote, hold public office, preach, teach, attend the universities or assemble for meetings in England. On June , the king's Catholic brother, James, Duke of York, is forced to resign the office of Lord High Admiral because of the Act.
November  – James, Duke of York, marries Mary of Modena; they meet for the first time immediately before the ceremony in Dover.
November  – Christopher Wren is knighted in England.
August  – Dutch forces under Admiral Cornelis Evertsen the Youngest recapture New York from the English; the city is known as New Orange until regained by the English in .
The first Dutch West India Company is dissolved.

April  – In the Netherlands, the jurisdiction  of Willem, Prince of Orange, Stadtholder of Holland (on the west coast, including Amsterdam and Rotterdam) and Zeeland (southwest coast, including Middelburg, Zeeland), increases in the Dutch Republic as his followers in the inland States of Utrecht (Utrecht, Gelderland and Overijssel) designate him as the hereditary stadtholder.   In , he becomes the King of England in addition to his role as the Stadtholder of the Netherlands.

December  – Father Jacques Marquette, along with Pierre Poteret and Jacque Poteret, sails southward along the shore of Lake Michigan, accompanied by nine canoes of Indians from the Potawatomi tribe, and comes ashore at what is now Chicago.  The three missionaries, the first Europeans to explore the area, camp there for the winter.  Marquette notes in his journal "The land bordering it is of now value, except on the prairies," and adds "There are eight to ten quite fine rivers."  A historical marker is now erected on the site of the landing.  Father Marquette founds a mission (which will in time grow into the city of Chicago) on the shores of Lake Michigan, in order to create a Christian ministry to convent Native Americans in the Illinois Confederation.
January  – The tragic opera Alceste, by Jean-Baptiste Lully, is performed for the first time, presented by the Paris Opera company at the Theatre du Palais-Royal in Paris.

July  – Two skeletons of children are discovered by workmen repairing a staircase at the White Tower (Tower of London), and believed at this time to be the remains of the Princes in the Tower. The urns containing the bones are interred in  in Westminster Abbey, with an inscription in Latin that states "Here lie interred the remains of Edward V, King of England, and Richard, Duke of York, whose long desired and much sought after bones, after over a hundred and ninety years, were found interred deep beneath the rubble of the stairs that led up to the Chapel of the White Tower, on the  of July in the Year of Our Lord ."
June  – Brandenburg defeats the Swedish Army in the Battle of Fehrbellin.
Giovanni Cassini discovers the Cassini Division in the rings of Saturn.
January  – Franco-Dutch War – Battle of Turckheim: The French defeat Austria and Brandenburg.
Gottfried Leibniz makes the earliest known use of infinitesimal calculus in the breaking down of a function.
April  – King Charles II of England suspends Parliament after just nine weeks when the members refuse to vote additional funding to him.
The French East India Company founds its principal Indian base at Pondicherry, on the Coromandel Coast.
June  – The Indian coalition attacks Hadley, Massachusetts, but are repelled by Connecticut troops.
January  – Feodor III becomes Tsar of Russia.
April  – Richard Raynsford becomes the new Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales.
December  – Scanian War – Battle of Lund: Sweden defeats the forces of Denmark.
The population of Paris first exceeds ,.
Ice cream becomes popular in Paris.
September  – the Kangxi Emperor of China grants titles and ranks to all of his wives, and names Empress Xiaozhaoren as his consort.

February  – Four members of the English House of Lords embarrass King Charles II at the opening of the latest session of the "Cavalier Parliament" by proclaiming that the session is not legitimate because it had not met in more than a year. The Duke of Buckingham, backed by Lord Shaftesbury, Lord Salisbury  and Baron Wharton, makes an unsuccessful motion to end the session.  When the four Lords refuse to apologize, they are arrested and imprisoned in the Tower of London.

December  – The Siege of Stettin (the modern-day Polish city of Szczecin but, at this time, a possession of Sweden) ends after almost five months with Sweden's surrender of the city to Prussia's Frederick William, Elector of Brandenburg. The siege, part of the Scanian War, had begun on June .
January  – The first fire engine company in North America goes into service in Boston.
September  – The Franco-Dutch War between the Kingdom of France and the Dutch Republic (and its allies) comes to an end after more than six years as the Treaties of Nijmegen bring about a ceasefire.
March  – The nova V529 Orionis is discovered by Polish astronomer Johannes Hevelius (Jan Heweliusz).

June  – French buccaneer Michel de Grammont arrives at Spanish-held Venezuela with six pirate ships,  smaller craft, and , men in a daring raid on the South American territory, then leads half of his force inward toward Maracaibo, which he takes on June . During the rest of the month, he and his soldiers march inland as far as Trujillo. Grammont and his pirates finally depart on December .
December  – The Test Act provides that members of both the House of Lords and House of Commons of England must swear an anti-Catholic oath, before taking office.

February  – The Treaty of Celle is signed between France and Sweden on one side, and the Holy Roman Empire, at the town of Celle in Saxony (in modern-day Germany).  Sweden's sovereignty over Bremen-Verden is confirmed and Sweden cedes control of Thedinghausen and Dörverden to the Germans.

December  (December  O.S.) – Oliver Plunkett, the Roman Catholic Primate of All Ireland and Archbishop of Armagh, is arrested on false charges of plotting to aid a French invasion of the British Isles, the so-called "Popish Plot". Executed in , Plunkett will be canonized as a Roman Catholic saint almost  years later in .

More than  captives on the ship The Crown of London, all Scottish Covenanters arrested after the battle of Bothwell Bridge, are killed when the ship is wrecked on the Orkney Islands while transporting the group to exile in North America.
October  – Bil'arab bin Sultan becomes the new Imam of Oman upon the death of his father, Sultan bin Saif.
French explorer Daniel Greysolon, Sieur du Lhut, explores the Saint Louis River; the city of Duluth, Minnesota, will take its name from him.

March  – The Earl of Shaftesbury informs the Privy Council of England that the Roman Catholics of Ireland were about to launch a rebellion, backed by France.  The investigation leads to the arrest and ultimate execution of the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Armagh, Oliver Plunkett.
A treaty is concluded between the Dutch Republic and the Ottoman Empire for Ottoman Sultan Mehmed IV and his subjects to apply Dutch law to Dutch visitors to Ottoman territory.
September  – Emperor Go-Mizunoo spent his later years in relative seclusion as a retired emperor, continuing to participate in courtly and cultural activities until his passing away.
September  – Spanish troops make a counterattack on Santa Fe in the modern-day U.S. state of New Mexico, allowing the remaining Spanish troops in the besieged city to flee to El Paso (now in Texas).
Johann Pachelbel writes his Canon in D Major
Egypt—Development of leavened bread (date approximate).
Egypt—Start of the Sixteenth Dynasty.

October  – Sir John Child of England becomes the new Governor of Bombay province and, unofficially, Governor-General of all of the settlements of the East India Company in India.  With the exception of a rebellion by Captain Richard Keigwin during the year , Child expands British control until involving the British in a war with the Mughal Empire.
Havertown and Bryn Mawr are founded in Pennsylvania by Welsh Quakers.
July  – The Bombardment of Chios during the French-Tripolitania War (-) is part of a wider campaign by France against the Barbary Pirates in the 1680s.

January  – Prince Muhammad Akbar, son of the Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb, initiates a civil war in India.  With the support of troops from the Rajput states, Akbar declares himself the new Mughal Emperor and prepares to fight his father, but is ultimately defeated.

March  – The "Oxford Parliament" is summoned in England by King Charles II and meets in Oxford rather than in Westminster, but is dissolved seven days later.  No further sessions of parliament are held until after the death of Charles in .
