At the same time, Pontiac authorizes a Shawnee Chief, Nanicksah, to sign a treaty with the British on behalf of the Great Lakes tribes, settling the French and Indian War.
September  – François Antoine announces he has killed the Beast of Gévaudan.
The first true restaurant opens in Paris, where a tavern-keeper named Boulanger sells cooked dishes at an all-night place on the Rue Bailleul.
April  – Three days after getting the news that the Stamp Act has passed, American colonists invade the British Army arsenal near the New York City Hall and sabotage guns inside by spiking them.

November  – A British sloop-of-war is searching all vessels passing near Cape Lookout, North Carolina, and some vessels have been seized, according to an observer in New York City, in the Province of New York, reporting to the Pennsylvania Gazette.
February  – Lorraine and Bar become French again, on the death of Stanisław Leszczyński, King of Poland and last Duke of Lorraine.
February – Ferocious wolf attacks occur in France, such as the Beast of Gévaudan or Wolves of Périgord.
November – Raja Lumu consolidates his claim to the Selangor Sultanate by marriage to the niece of the Sultan of Perak.

January  – Burmese–Siamese War: Outside of the walls of the Thailand capital of Ayutthaya, tens of thousands of invaders from Burma (under the command of General Ne Myo Thihapate and General Maha Nawatra) are confronted by Thai defenders led by General Phya Taksin. The defenders are overwhelmed and the survivors take refuge inside Ayutthaya. The siege continues for  months before the Burmese attackers collapse the walls by digging tunnels and setting fire to debris. The city falls on April , , and King Ekkathat is killed.

November  – The new American Colonies Act , commonly called the "Declaratory Act", goes into effect, virtually providing for Great Britain's Parliament to govern lawmaking in  colonies and exacerbating tensions there.

October  – Surveying of the "Mason–Dixon line", which will later become the traditional division between the northern and southern states of the United States, is completed by Charles Mason and Jeremiah Dixon after four years, initially to settle a boundary dispute between the colonies of Delaware, Pennsylvania and Maryland.  The survey party is halted at Dunkard Creek when a chief of the Mohawk Indians tells them that they are in Native American territory and that the Mohawks guiding the property "would not proceed one step further Westward"; the line, slightly west the 80th meridian west, is now part of the boundary between Pennsylvania and West Virginia.

October  – Šćepan Mali, nicknamed "Stephen the Little", is selected as the legislature at Podgorica to be the Tsar of Montenegro, representing "a short but an important break in the succession of the Petrovic dynasty".

March  – Spain acquires control of what are now called the Falkland Islands from France, compensating French Admiral Louis Antoine de Bougainville for the money spent on the construction of the settlement at Fort Saint Louis. The islands, named les Îles Malouines by the French, are renamed las Islas Malvinas by the Spanish, and Fort Saint Louis is renamed as Puerto Soledad.  In , Argentina declares independence from Spain and takes the Malvinas; and in , Britain's Royal Navy captures the islands from the Argentines and renames them the Falklands, and renames Puerto Soledad as Port Louis.
May  – The Genoese island of Capraia is conquered by the Corsican Army after a ten-week campaign.

March  – Catherine the Great of Russia dispatches troops under General Pyotr Krechetnikov to intervene in a civil war in Poland, at the request of Poland's King Stanisław II Augustus, a move that will ultimately lead to the Partitions of Poland.

May  – Massacre of St George's Fields: John Wilkes is imprisoned for writing an article for The North Briton, severely criticizing King George III. This action provokes protesters to riot; in the Southwark district of London, troops fire on the mob, killing seven.
August  – James Cook departs from Plymouth aboard HMS Endeavour on his first voyage of discovery.

April  – The New York Chamber of Commerce, first of its kind in the American colonies, is founded by  New York merchants at Bolton and Sigel's Tavern at  Pearl Street in New York City. Former New York City mayor John Cruger Jr. is elected the Chamber's first president.

October  – Representatives of the Cherokee nation sign the Treaty of Hard Labour with British representative John Stuart and relinquish all claims to the land between the Ohio River and the Allegheny Mountains, now the United States state of West Virginia.
August  – The party of Gaspar de Portolà becomes the first white group to set foot in the area now known as Santa Monica, California.
May  – France conquers Corsica.
September  – Russo-Turkish War (–): Russian forces take the Ottoman fortress of Chocim in Bukovina.
March  – Mozart departs Italy, after the last of his three tours there.
February  – The British House of Commons votes not to allow MP John Wilkes to take his seat after he wins a by-election, on the grounds that he was an outlaw when standing.

April  – First voyage of James Cook: Captain Cook drops anchor on HMS Endeavour in a wide bay, about  km ( mi) south of the present city of Sydney, Australia. Because the young botanist on board the ship, Joseph Banks, discovers , specimens of plant life in the area, , of them unknown to European science, Cook names the place Botany Bay on May .

April  – The Townshend Acts are repealed by Britain's Parliament by the efforts of Prime Minister Frederick North, with the exception of the increased duties on imported tea. The American colonists, in turn, stop their embargo on British imports.
Joseph Priestley, English chemist, recommends the use of a rubber eraser to remove pencil marks.
January  – The foundation of Fort George, Bombay is laid by Colonel Keating, principal engineer, on the site of the former Dongri Fort.

April  (April  by Cook's log) : – First voyage of James Cook: English explorer Captain James Cook and his crew become the first recorded Europeans to encounter the eastern coastline of the Australian continent. Land is sighted at Point Hicks, and named after Lieutenant Hicks who first observes landform at 6am.
Babylon becomes the largest city in the world, taking the lead from Thebes, Egypt.
Investiture of Zimri-Lim, a painting of Zimri-Lim receiving the ring and staff from the goddess Ishtar, is made at the Royal Palace of Mari, Court , from around  to . It is now at the Louvre, Paris.
October  – The Dutch merchant ship Vrouw Maria sinks off the coast of Finland; Captain Raymund Lourens and his crew escape unharmed.
March – War of the Regulation: North Carolina Governor William Tryon raises a militia to put down the long-running uprising of backcountry militias against North Carolina's colonial government.

Slovene literature: István Küzmics, the Hungarian Slovene writer and evangelical pastor, publishes (in Halle) the Nouvi Zákon, a translation of the New Testament into the Prekmurje Slovene language, with discrete South Slavic artwork.
August  – The first recorded town cricket match is played, at Horsham, England.
July  – The first voyage of James Cook around the world ends as HMS Endeavour returns to England after almost three years.
February  – The First Partition of Poland is agreed to by Russia and Prussia, later including Austria.
November  – American Revolutionary War: Samuel Adams and Joseph Warren form the first Committee of Correspondence.
June – – Russo-Turkish War (–): First of two Russian occupations of Beirut, following a naval bombardment which began on June .
August  – A coup d'état by King Gustav III is completed by adopting a new Constitution, ending half a century of parliamentary rule in Sweden, and making him an enlightened despot.
March  – Biela's Comet is first discovered by French astronomer Jacques Leibax Montaigne, but not proven to be a periodic comet until , when Wilhelm von Biela correctly identifies its return.
July  – Under pressure from the Bourbon courts, Pope Clement XIV suppresses the Society of Jesus (brief Dominus ac Redemptor). Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor, expels the order from his territories.

In China, written work begins on the Complete Library of the Four Treasuries, the largest literary compilation of books in China's history (surpassing the Yongle Encyclopedia of the ). Upon completion in , the books are bound in , volumes (册) with more than , chapters (卷), comprising about . million pages, and approximately  million Chinese characters.
Friedrich Gottlieb Klopstock publishes the last five cantos of his epic poem Der Messias in Hamburg.

Istanbul Technical University is established (under the name of Royal School of Naval Engineering) as the world's first comprehensive institution of higher learning dedicated to engineering education.
March  – The popular (and enduring) comedy She Stoops to Conquer, by Irish playwright Oliver Goldsmith, is performed for the first time, premiering at London's Covent Garden Theatre.
June  (June  O.S.) – Russo-Turkish War (–): Battle of Kozludzha – The Imperial Russian Army, led by Alexander Suvorov, routs numerically superior Ottoman Empire forces.

July  – Russia and the Ottoman Empire sign the Treaty of Küçük Kaynarca with Russian victory, ending six years of war. The treaty gives Russia the right to intervene in Ottoman politics, to protect its Christian subjects.
A revision of the laws of cricket introduces a leg before wicket rule.
Parliament adjourns in Great Britain, but declines to authorize any action against the rebellious American colonies, despite an address the day before by King George III and Prime Minister North.
May  – Louis XVI becomes King of France, following the death of his grandfather, Louis XV.
August  – Tucson is founded.
January  – Second voyage of James Cook: Captain James Cook takes possession of South Georgia for the Kingdom of Great Britain.

November – American Revolution: Colonel Richard Richardson's South Carolina revolutionaries march through Ninety-Six District in what becomes known as the Snow Campaign, effectively ending all major support for the Loyalist cause in the backcountry of South Carolina.
October – The Sayre Plotters attempt to kidnap George III of the United Kingdom.
Catherine the Great decrees a Statute for the Administration of the Provinces of the Russian Empire dividing the country into provinces and districts for efficient government.

July  – Domínguez–Escalante expedition: Francisco Silvestre Vélez de Escalante, Francisco Atanasio Domínguez, and eight other Spaniards set out from Santa Fe, on an eighteen-hundred mile trek through the American Southwest. They are the first Europeans to explore the vast region between the Rockies and the Sierras.

October  – American Revolutionary War – Battle of Valcour Island: On Lake Champlain near Valcour Island, a British fleet led by Sir Guy Carleton defeats  American gunboats, commanded by Brigadier General Benedict Arnold. Although nearly all of Arnold's ships are destroyed, the two-day-long battle will give Patriot forces enough time to prepare the defenses of New York City.
Battle of Nassau: The American Continental Navy and  Marines make a successful assault on Nassau, Bahamas.
November  – American Revolutionary War – Battle of Fort Lee: The invasion of New Jersey, by British and Hessian forces, leads to the subsequent general retreat of the American Continental Army.
September  – American Revolutionary War – Landing at Kip's Bay: British troops land on Manhattan at Kips Bay.
July  – American Revolutionary War – Battle of Hubbardton: British forces capture over  of the American rearguard, from Fort Ticonderoga.
January  – American Revolutionary War – Battle of Princeton: American general George Washington's army defeats British troops.
Det Dramatiske Selskab is founded in Copenhagen (Denmark) as an acting academy.

September  – American Revolutionary War – British troops occupy Philadelphia; members of the Continental Congress flee to Lancaster, Pennsylvania, where they meet and hold a one day session as the Fifth Congress before fleeing again.
Kunsthochschule Kassel is founded in Germany as a fine arts academy.

May  – Heinrich XI, Prince Reuss of Greiz is elevated to Prince of the Principality of Reuss-Greiz by Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor. This year sees the first appearance of the modern-day national colors of Germany on a flag that closely resembles the modern flag of Germany, to occur anywhere within modern-day Germany.
December  – John Jay of New York is chosen as the sixth President of the Continental Congress.
July  – Louis XVI of France declares war on the Kingdom of Great Britain.

October  – The Continental Congress advises the  member states to suppress "theatrical entertainments, horse-racing, gaming, and such other diversions as are productive of idleness, dissipation, and general depravity of principles and manners."

February  – In the United States:
South Carolina becomes the first state to ratify the Articles of Confederation.
General John Cadwalader shoots and seriously wounds Major General Thomas Conway in a duel after a dispute between the two officers over Conway's continued criticism of General George Washington's leadership of the Continental Army.

Industrial Revolution in England:
The Iron Bridge is erected across the River Severn in Shropshire, the world's first bridge built entirely of cast iron. It will open to traffic on January , .
The spinning mule is perfected by Lancashire inventor Samuel Crompton.
Boulton and Watt's  Smethwick Engine, now the oldest working engine in the world, is brought into service (May)).

May  – War of the Bavarian Succession – Russian and French mediators at the Congress of Teschen negotiate an end to the war. In the agreement Austria receives a part of the Bavarian territory (the Innviertel), and relinquishes the rest.
March  – Capture and sack of Vientiane by Siamese forces.
June  – American Revolutionary War – Benedict Arnold is court-martialed for malfeasance, in his treatment of government property.
The Iron Bridge is erected across the River Severn in Shropshire, the world's first bridge built entirely of cast iron. It will open to traffic on January , .
October  –  American Revolutionary War: In Tappan, New York, British spy John André is hanged by American forces.
September  – The Danish ship-of-the-line Printz Friderich runs aground on the Kobbergrund shoal and is a total loss
The Woodford Reserve bourbon whiskey distillery begins operation in Kentucky.
June  – An Anti-Catholic mob led by Lord George Gordon marches on the Parliament of Great Britain, leading to the outbreak of the Gordon Riots in London.
July  – The first bank created in the United States, the Bank of Pennsylvania, is chartered.
The last known population of woolly mammoths on Wrangel Island died out, possibly due to a combination of climate change and hunting.
In Egypt, the Twelfth Dynasty ends, and the Thirteenth and Fourteenth Dynasties begin.
The Amorite civilization conquers Uruk and Isin.
August  – American Revolution: A French fleet under Comte de Grasse enters Chesapeake Bay, cutting British General Charles Cornwallis off from escape by sea.

February  – Fourth Anglo-Dutch War – Capture of Sint Eustatius: British forces take the Dutch Caribbean island of Sint Eustatius, with only a few shots fired. On November  it is retaken by Dutch-allied French forces.

December  – American Revolutionary War – Second Battle of Ushant: The British Royal Navy, commanded by Rear Admiral Richard Kempenfelt in HMS Victory, decisively defeats the French fleet in the Bay of Biscay.
September  – American Revolution – Battle of Eutaw Springs, South Carolina: The war's last significant battle, in the Southern theatre, ends in a narrow British tactical victory.

October  – American Revolution: Following the Siege of Yorktown, General Charles Cornwallis surrenders to General George Washington at Yorktown, Virginia, ending the armed struggle of the American Revolution.
April  – Battle of the Saintes: A British fleet under Admiral Sir George Rodney defeats a French fleet under the Comte de Grasse, in the West Indies.
February  – Singu Min is overthrown as king of Myanmar by his cousin Phaungka Min and  days later will be executed by his uncle Bodawpayar.
Princess Yekaterina Vorontsova-Dashkova is the first woman in the world to direct a scientific academy, the Imperial Academy of Arts and Sciences.

April  – A Lak Mueang (city pillar) is erected on Rattanakosin Island, located on the eastern bank of the Chao Phraya River, by order of King Rama I, an act considered the founding of the capital city of Bangkok.

George Washington orders the creation of the Badge of Military Merit (or the Order of the Purple Heart) to honor soldiers' merit in battle (reinstated later by Franklin D. Roosevelt, and renamed to the more poetic "Purple Heart", to honor soldiers wounded in action).
February  – The United States Continental Army's Corps of Engineers is disbanded.
December  – Jacques Charles and Nicolas-Louis Robert make the first manned flight in a hydrogen-filled gas balloon in Paris.
March  – The last celebration of Massacre Day is held in Boston, Massachusetts.
November  – American Revolutionary War: The last British troops leave New York City and George Washington triumphantly returns, three months after the signing of the Treaty of Paris.
November  –  New Jersey earthquake: An earthquake of . magnitude strikes New Jersey.
Foundation of the first theater in Estonia, the Tallinna saksa teater.
December  – The Methodist Episcopal Church in the United States is officially formed at the "Christmas Conference", led by Thomas Coke and Francis Asbury.
The North Carolina General Assembly changes the name of Kingston, North Carolina, originally named for King George III of Great Britain, to Kinston.
January  – The Congress of the United States ratifies the Treaty of Paris with Great Britain to end the American Revolution, with the signature of President of Congress Thomas Mifflin.
October  – "Kettle War", a -day action on the Scheldt in which a ship of the Dutch Republic repels forces of the Holy Roman Empire.
Mozart's "Haydn" String Quartets are published, as is his collaboration with Salieri and Cornetti, Per la ricuperata salute di Ofelia.
Cabinet des Modes, the first fashion magazine, is published in France.
The University of New Brunswick is founded in Fredericton, New Brunswick.
September  – The United States and the Kingdom of Prussia sign a Treaty of Amity and Commerce.
The British government establishes a permanent land force in the Eastern Caribbean, based in Barbados.

October  – King George III of the United Kingdom appoints Captain Arthur Phillip as the first Governor of New Holland, which comprises the area of modern Australia from the 135th meridian east to the east coast and all adjacent islands in the Pacific Ocean.
April  – British astronomer William Herschel publishes his first list of his discoveries, Catalogue of One Thousand New Nebulae and Clusters of Stars; two additional books are published in  and .
November  – The oldest musical organization in the United States, the Stoughton Musical Society, is founded.
August  – Shays' Rebellion begins in Massachusetts.

October 
The  AH begins on the Islamic calendar on the 1st of Muharram  AH
The settlement of Östersund is established in Sweden.
February  – Arthur St. Clair of Pennsylvania is chosen as the new President of the Congress of the Confederation.

March  – Biblical theology becomes a separate discipline from biblical studies, as Johann Philipp Gabler delivers his speech "On the proper distinction between biblical and dogmatic theology and the specific objectives of each" upon his inauguration as the professor of theology at the University of Altdorf in Germany.
December  – La Purisima Mission is founded by Padre Fermín Lasuén as the eleventh of the Spanish missions in California.
December  – James Rumsey demonstrates his water-jet propelled boat on the Potomac River.
June  – Oliver Ellsworth moves at the Federal Convention that the government be called the United States.
August  – Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, in Vienna, completes his final symphony, now called the Symphony No.  in C Major, and nicknamed (after his death) The Jupiter.
May  – The Australian frontier wars begins. With the placement of a cournerstone.
October – King George III of the United Kingdom becomes deranged; the Regency Crisis of  starts.
January  – Henry Benedict Stuart becomes the new Stuart claimant to the throne of Great Britain, as King Henry IX and the figurehead of Jacobitism.
January  – The leading ship (armed tender HMS Supply) in Captain Arthur Phillip's First Fleet arrives at Botany Bay, to colonise Australia.
December  – The University of North Carolina, the  oldest public university in the United States, is founded.

September  – The United States Congress proposes a set of  amendments to the U.S. Constitution, for ratification by the states. Ratification for  of these proposals is completed on December , , creating the United States Bill of Rights.
German chemist Martin Heinrich Klaproth discovers the element uranium, while studying the mineral pitchblende.

October  – Brabant Revolution: Brabant revolutionaries cross the border from the Dutch Republic into the Austrian Netherlands; the first public reading of the Manifesto of the People of Brabant declares the independence of the Austrian Netherlands.
September  – The Judiciary Act of  establishes the federal judiciary, and the United States Marshals Service.
July  – French Revolution: Citizens of Paris celebrate the unity of the French people and the national reconciliation, in the Fête de la Fédération.
May – – Battle of Andros: An Ottoman–Algerian fleet destroys the fleet of the Greek privateer Lambros Katsonis.

June  – Compromise of : Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, and Alexander Hamilton come to an agreement: Madison agrees to not be "strenuous" in opposition for the assumption of state debts by the federal government; Hamilton agrees to support the capital site being above the Potomac.
July – Louis XVI accepts a constitutional monarchy in France.

July  – U.S. President George Washington signs the Residence Act into law, establishing a site along the Potomac River as the District of Columbia and the future site of the capital of the United States. The move comes after the bill is narrowly approved on July  by the Senate,  to , and on July  by the House,  to . At the same time, plans are made to move the national capital from New York to Philadelphia until the Potomac River site can be completed.

December  – Ratification by the states of the first ten amendments to the United States Constitution is completed, creating the United States Bill of Rights. Two additional amendments remain pending, and one of these is finally ratified in , becoming the Twenty-seventh Amendment.
December  – The first issue of The Observer, the world's first Sunday newspaper, is published in London.
February  – The United States opens diplomatic relations with Portugal.
April –May  – The first American ships reach Japan, brigantine Lady Washington captained by John Kendrick of Boston, and the brig Grace.
July  – French Revolution: The Champ de Mars massacre occurs in Paris.

June 
Vancouver becomes the first European to enter Burrard Inlet.
Prussia declares war against France.

War of the First Coalition: Battle of Jemappes – Austrian armies under the command of Duke Albert of Saxe-Teschen are defeated in Belgium (at this time part of the Austrian Netherlands) by the French Army led by General Charles François Dumouriez.

March  – Assassination of Gustav III: King Gustav III of Sweden is shot in the back by Jacob Johan Anckarström, at a midnight masquerade at the Royal Opera in Stockholm; he lives until March , and is then succeeded by his -year-old son, Gustav IV Adolf.
November  – France's National Convention passes a resolution pledging French support for the overthrow of the governments of other nations.
The first written examinations in Europe are held at the University of Cambridge in England.
September  – The cornerstone to the future United States Capitol is dedicated by U.S. President Washington at the site of the new Federal City on the Potomac River.
April  – Edmond-Charles Genêt, France's new Minister to the United States, arrives at Charleston, South Carolina.
Second Battle of Neerwinden: A coalition army of Habsburg monarchy and Dutch Republic troops repulses attacks from French Republican forces, near Neerwinden, Flemish Brabant.
January  – Second Partition of Poland: The Russian Empire and the Kingdom of Prussia partition the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
December  – New York City's first daily newspaper, the American Minerva, is established by Noah Webster.
September  – The University of Tennessee is established at Knoxville.
July  – Battle of Trippstadt between French forces and those of Prussia and Austria (First Coalition).
April  – Sardinian Vespers: The people of Cagliari in Sardinia oust the viceroy and his Piedmontese functionaries.
August  – Aristocrats in Sweden gather to mourn the demise of coffee after the beverage is forbidden by royal decree.
December  – St. Louis Cathedral, New Orleans is dedicated.
March  – Ludwig van Beethoven makes his public debut in Vienna performing his Second Piano Concerto under the baton of his teacher Antonio Salieri.
May  – French Revolution: Revolutionary Tribunal suppressed.
The harvest fails in Munich.

June – – War of the First Coalition: Cornwallis's Retreat – A British Royal Navy battle squadron commanded by William Cornwallis fends off a numerically superior French Navy fleet, off the coast of Brittany.
August  – British forces capture Trincomalee, Ceylon.
August  – Second Treaty of San Ildefonso: Spain and France form an alliance against Great Britain.
February  – The capital of Upper Canada is moved from Newark to York.
March  – Napoleon Bonaparte arrives at Nice to take command of the Army of Italy (, men and  guns), which is scattered in detachments as far as Genoa.
May  – Edward Jenner administers the first smallpox vaccination, in England.
The Spanish government lifts the restrictions against neutrals trading with the colonies, thus acknowledging Spain's inability to supply the colonies with needed goods and markets.
May  – The first ship of the United States Navy, the frigate USS United States, is commissioned.

April 
Battle of San Juan: Sir Ralph Abercromby unsuccessfully invades San Juan, Puerto Rico in what will be one of the largest British attacks on Spanish territories in the western hemisphere, and one of the worst defeats of the British Royal Navy for years to come.
Veronese Easter: Citizens of Verona, Italy, began an unsuccessful eight-day rebellion against the French occupying forces.

The secret Lautaro Lodge as the Logia de los Caballeros Racionales ("Lodge of Rational Knights") is founded, perhaps in Cádiz; membership will include many leaders of the Spanish American wars of independence such as Francisco de Miranda, Bernardo O'Higgins and José de San Martín.
March  – Médée, an opera by Luigi Cherubini, is premiered in Paris.
September  –  France's new government decrees that citizens who left the country without authorization are subject to the death penalty if they return.
Nathan Mayer Rothschild moves from Frankfurt in the Holy Roman Empire to England, settling up in business as a textile trader and financier in Manchester.
April  – The Helvetic Republic, a French client republic, is proclaimed following the collapse of the Old Swiss Confederacy after the French invasion; Aarau becomes the republic's temporary capital.
January – Eli Whitney contracts with the U.S. federal government for , muskets, which he produces with interchangeable parts.
The Piedmontese Republic is declared in the territory of Piedmont.
March  – French troops enter Bern.
January  – Maltese patriot Dun Mikiel Xerri, along with a number of other patriots, is executed.
August  – Pope Pius VI, at this time the longest reigning Pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church, dies as a prisoner of war in the citadel of the French city of Valence, after 24½ years of rule.
May  – The Siege of Acre ends after two months; Napoleon's attempt to widen his Middle Eastern campaign into Syria is frustrated by Ottoman forces, and he withdraws to Egypt.
May  – Battle of Seringapatam: Tipu Sultan is defeated and killed by the British, ending the captivity of Mangalorean Catholics at Seringapatam ends and concluding the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War.
December  – France adopts the metre as its official unit of length.

April 
Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No.  premieres at the Burgtheater, in Vienna.
The Treaty of Constantinople establishes the Septinsular Republic, the first autonomous Greek state since the Fall of the Byzantine Empire.
November  – War of the Second Coalition: Hostilities resume.
June  – War of the Second Coalition: Battle of Neuburg – General Claude Lecourbe leads French forces to victory, securing control of the Danube from Austria.
February  – Infrared radiation is discovered by astronomer Sir William Herschel.

April  – The first voting, albeit indirect, begins in the  United States presidential election as voters in the state of New York make their selections for the New York state legislature, which in turn will vote on October  for the state's  presidential electors. A majority of state legislature members are from the Democratic-Republican Party, rather than the Federalist Party. At the time, only  of the  U.S. states (Kentucky, Maryland, North Carolina and Virginia) have a popular vote for the presidential electors and the President. The other , including New York, have a popular vote for the state legislature, but not for the president. At the time, neither of the major parties have picked their nominees for president and vice president. The result will not be certified until February, .

April  – War of the Second Coalition: First Battle of Copenhagen – The  British Royal Navy, under Admiral Sir Hyde Parker, forces the Royal Dano-Norwegian Navy to accept an armistice. Vice-Admiral Horatio Nelson leads the main attack, deliberately disregarding his commander's signal to withdraw. He is created a Viscount on May ; Denmark-Norway is forced to withdraw from the Second League of Armed Neutrality.
July  – Toussaint Louverture promulgates a reforming constitution for Santo Domingo, declaring himself emperor for life of the entire island of Hispaniola, and nominally abolishing slavery.

February  – An electoral tie between Thomas Jefferson and Aaron Burr is resolved, when Jefferson is elected President of the United States and Burr Vice President by the United States House of Representatives.
November  – The first edition of the New-York Evening Post is printed.
September  – Alexander I of Russia confirms the privileges of the Baltic provinces.
: Pharaoh Senwosret II dies (other date is ).
: Senwosret III (Twelfth Dynasty) died.
: Senwosret III (Twelfth Dynasty) started to rule.
: Senwosret II (Twelfth Dynasty) started to rule. He built Kahun near his pyramid tomb complex at el-Lahun.
: Minoan Old Palace (Protopalatial) period starts in Crete.

December  – The Health and Morals of Apprentices Act in the United Kingdom comes into effect, regulating conditions for child labour in factories. Although poorly enforced, it pioneers a series of Factory Acts.

January  – Thomas Bruce, 7th Earl of Elgin, British ambassador to the Ottoman Empire, begins removal of the Elgin Marbles from the Parthenon in Athens, claiming they are at risk of destruction during the Ottoman occupation of Greece; the first shipment departs Piraeus on board Elgin's ship, the Mentor, "with many boxes of moulds and sculptures", including three marble torsos from the Parthenon.

November  – The newly elected British Parliament is inaugurated by King George III, who tells the members, "In my intercourse with foreign powers, I have been actuated by a sincere disposition of the maintenance of peace," but adds that "My conduct will be invariably regulated by a due consideration of the actual situation of Europe, and by a watchful solicitude for the permanent welfare of my people."

June 
The United States Patent and Trademark Office is established within the Department of State.
At Huế, shortly before his conquest of Tonkin, Nguyen Anh is crowned as the Emperor Gia Long, the first ruler of the Nguyễn dynasty in Vietnam.
October  – French Army General Michel Ney enters Switzerland with , troops, on orders of Napoleon Bonaparte.
October  – The Senate ratifies the Louisiana Purchase Treaty, doubling the size of the United States.
September  – Irish rebel Robert Emmet is executed.
February  – A major redistribution of territorial sovereignty within the Holy Roman Empire is enacted, via an act known as the Reichsdeputationshauptschluss.
February  – Marbury v. Madison: The Supreme Court of the United States establishes the principle of judicial review.

October  – Orissa, an area of India along the Bay of Bengal that comprises the modern-day Indian state of Odisha, is occupied by the British under the British East India Company, after the Second Anglo-Maratha War.  The Maratha Empire formally cedes the area in the Treaty of Deogaon, signed on December .

February  – The First Serbian uprising begins the Serbian Revolution. By , the Principality of Serbia will have proclaimed self-rule from the Ottoman Empire, the first nation-state in Europe to do so.

June  – Smithson Tennant announces the discovery of the elements iridium and osmium; three days later, William Hyde Wollaston reveals to the Royal Society that he is the formerly anonymous discoverer of palladium.
April  – Samuel Taylor Coleridge sets sail on The Speedwell for the Mediterranean. In Malta, he obtains employment as a public official.
April  – Henry Addington resigns as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
February  – Hobart is established in its permanent location in Van Diemen's Land (modern-day Tasmania) as a British penal colony.
August  – Lewis and Clark Expedition: U.S. Army Captain Meriwether Lewis reaches the Continental Divide of the Americas, crossing to the west at Lemhi Pass.

June 
The First Barbary War ends between Tripoli and the United States of America.
The first Trooping the Colour ceremony is held at the Horse Guards Parade in London.
Detroit burns to the ground; most of the city is destroyed.
August  – British Army General David Baird departs from Cork, leading an expedition to capture the Cape of Good Hope.  Their ship arrives on January .
March  –  The New Brunswick Legislature passes a bill to advance literacy in the province, which eventually leads to the creation of public education in Canada.
British troopship Aeneas is wrecked off Newfoundland with the loss of  lives.
Noah Webster publishes his first dictionary, A Compendious Dictionary of the English Language, recording distinctive American spellings.
July  – British invasions of the River Plate: A British expeditionary force of , men lands on the left bank of the Río de la Plata and invades Buenos Aires.
October  – Napoleon responds to the September  ultimatum from Prussia, and begins the War of the Fourth Coalition; Prussia is joined by Saxony and other minor German states.
The French Republican Calendar is abolished.

January 
Following the death of William Pitt the Younger, his cousin Lord Grenville succeeds him as wartime Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
Invasion of Naples: Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies flees to the Kingdom of Sicily under British protection.

January  – The Sierra Leone Company, faced with bankruptcy because of the imminent abolition of the slave trade in British colonies, petitions the British government for purchase and transfer of its property to the Crown; Parliament approves the transfer on July , and it takes effect on January , .
July  – A disastrous British attack is mounted against Buenos Aires, during the second failed invasion of the Río de la Plata.
February  – Battle of Eylau: Napoleon fights a hard but inconclusive battle against the Russians under Bennigsen.
February  – Napoleon leads the forces of the French Empire in an invasion of the Russian Empire, and begins fighting at the Battle of Eylau against Russian and Prussian forces.
April  – African Institution holds its first meeting in London; it is intended to improve social conditions in Sierra Leone.
February  – French troops take Rome as part of the Napoleonic Wars.

A volcano erupts from an unknown location in the western Pacific. This causes a localized drop in marine air temperatures during this year and a worldwide drop in marine air temperature for the following decade.
September  – Finnish War: A truce is declared between Swedish and Russian troops in Finland.
Russia issues an ultimatum to Sweden, to join Napoleon's Continental System against the United Kingdom.
March  – Upon the death of Christian VII, Frederick VI becomes king of Denmark. The next day (March ), Denmark declares war on Sweden.
September  – A new theatre for the Royal Opera House opens in London to replace the first, burnt down in a fire in . The price increases lead to the Old Price Riots, which last for  days.

July  – French troops arrest Pope Pius VII, and take him to Liguria.
Napoleon defeats the Austrians at the Battle of Wagram.
May  – Battle of Aspern-Essling begins.
Jean-Baptiste Lamarck publishes Philosophie Zoologique, outlining a (wrong) concept of evolution, by acquisition or loss of inherited characteristics, through use or disuse.
July  – Battle of Wagram begins.
January  – Major-General Lachlan Macquarie officially becomes Governor of New South Wales.
April  – Napoleon Bonaparte marries Marie Louise of Austria, Duchess of Parma, in person, in Paris.
October – King George III of the United Kingdom is deemed permanently insane.
August – – Battle of Grand Port: The French defeat a Royal Navy frigate squadron attempting to blockade a harbour on Isle de France (Mauritius).
Napoleon dissolves the Kingdom of Holland, ruled by his younger brother Louis, and annexes the country into the French Empire.
July  – The Great Podil fire breaks out in Kiev, Ukraine.
March  – Peninsular War – Battle of Barrosa: A French attack fails, on a larger Anglo-Portuguese-Spanish force attempting to lift the Siege of Cádiz in Spain.
The first novel by Jane Austen, Sense and Sensibility, was published.
March  – The Great Comet of  is discovered by Honoré Flaugergues.
May  – Paraguay declares independence from the Spanish Empire (recognised May ).
July  – Beethoven and Goethe meet each other in Teplice, Bohemia.
June  – New York State charters the City Bank of New York (later Citibank).
April  – U.S. President James Madison enacts a -day embargo on trade with the United Kingdom.
February  – The first Chilean newspaper Aurora de Chile deals with political philosophy, and stands in favor of the new national government.
April  – The capital of Finland is moved from Turku to Helsinki, when Russia's Tsar Alexander I signs an edict moving the Government Council of the Grand Duchy of Finland.
August  – Napoleonic Wars – Battle of Großbeeren: Napoleon is defeated by Prussia and Sweden.
September  – War of  – Battle of Lake Erie: An American squadron under Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry defeats a British squadron, capturing  ships.
Napoleonic Wars: The French garrison evacuates Berlin, leaving Russian troops able to reach and take the city without a fight.
July  – Sir Thomas Maitland is appointed as the first Governor of Malta, transforming the island from a British protectorate to a de facto colony.
May – – Napoleonic Wars: Battle of Bautzen – Napoleon again defeats his combined enemies.

April 
The Count of Artois arrives in Paris, acting as Lieutenant General of the realm before the arrival of his brother, Louis XVIII.
The Royal Norwegian Navy is re-established.
Hadži-Prodan's rebellion against the Ottoman Empire begins.
The Constitution of Norway is signed and the Danish Crown Prince Christian Frederik is elected King of Norway, by the Norwegian Constituent Assembly.

May  – Duke of Wellington arrives in Madrid from Paris in an attempt to avert civil war between supporters of Ferdinand VII and the opposition Liberals, including many troops who fought under him during the Peninsular War
A fire destroys the Custom House in the City of London.
October  – Napoleonic Wars: Napoleon begins his exile on Saint Helena in the Atlantic Ocean.

January  – Battle of New Orleans: American forces led by Andrew Jackson defeat British forces led by Sir Edward Pakenham. American forces suffer around  casualties and the British lose about , (the battle lasts for about  minutes).
January  – Lord Byron marries Anna Isabella Milbanke in Seaham, county of Durham, England.
February  – The Spanish reconquest of Spanish America begins.
February  – The War of  between the United States and the United Kingdom (including Canada) officially ends, following ratification of the Treaty of Ghent () in Washington, D.C.

March –April  – In Philadelphia, the African Methodist Episcopal Church is established by Richard Allen and other African-American Methodists, the first such denomination in the U.S. completely independent of White churches.
Sir Humphry Davy's Davy lamp is first tested underground as a coal mining safety lamp, at Hebburn Colliery in northeast England;
September  – King Louis XVIII dissolves the Chambre introuvable, the legislature that had been elected after the Second Bourbon Restoration re-established the old monarchy.
Robert Stirling patents his Stirling engine, at this time known as "Stirling's air engine", in the United Kingdom.
November  – The Bank of Montreal opens in Montreal.

April 
The American School for the Deaf opens in Hartford, Connecticut.
An earthquake strikes Palermo in the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies.

April  – The Rush–Bagot Treaty is signed between the United States and the British Empire, limiting the number of warships on the Great Lakes between the U.S. and Canada in the aftermath of settling the War of .
The American School for the Deaf opens in Hartford, Connecticut.

July 
At Rome, New York, construction on the Erie Canal begins in the U.S. to link the Hudson River to Lake Erie, with the long-range goal of making the first navigable waterway between the Atlantic Ocean and the Great Lakes, and reducing the amount of time and costs for transporting goods westward past the Appalachian mountains.
 Santiago del Estero earthquake. A . magnitude earthquake hits Argentina's Santiago del Estero Province.

December  – The Christmas carol "Silent Night" (Stille Nacht), with words by the priest Josef Mohr, set to music by organist Franz Xaver Gruber, is first performed at St. Nikolaus Parish Church, in Oberndorf bei Salzburg, Austria.
Catholic–Orthodox clash in Aleppo.

July  – The first newspaper in Cleveland, Ohio is issued by publisher Andrew Logan. Using the original name of the small settlement (population ), Logan names the weekly paper The Cleaveland Gazette & Commercial Register.
February  – Writer Walter Scott finds the Honours of Scotland in Edinburgh Castle.
October  – Claudine Thévenet (known as Mary of St. Ignatius) founds the Roman Catholic order Religieuses de Jésus-Marie ("Religious of Jesus And Mary") in Lyon, France.

May  –  The SS Savannah leaves port at Savannah, Georgia, on a voyage to become the first steamship to cross the Atlantic Ocean, although only a fraction of the trip will be made under steam. The ship arrives at Liverpool, England, nearly a month later, on June .
January  – The Panic of , the first major peacetime financial crisis in the United States, begins.

July  – Explorer William Parry, sailing in the Arctic in a quest for the Northwest Passage through North America, guides the ships HMS Hecla and HMS Griper through an iceberg-laden passage that will later be named the Parry Channel.
October  – Desolation Island, in the South Shetland Islands of the Antarctic, is discovered by Captain William Smith.

A British Arctic expedition under William Parry, comprising HMS Hecla and HMS Griper, reaches longitude °' W in the Northwest Passage, the furthest west which will be attained by any single-season voyage for  years.
January  – A constitutionalist military insurrection at Cádiz leads to the summoning of the Spanish Parliament to meet on March , becoming the nominal beginning of the "Trienio Liberal" in Spain.
July  – Saint Cronan's Boys' National School opens in Bray, County Wicklow, Ireland under the title Bray Male School. Its notable pupils will include President of Ireland Cearbhall Ó Dálaigh.

June  – Caroline of Brunswick, the estranged wife of King George IV of the United Kingdom, returns to England after six years abroad in Italy, where she has been carrying on an affair. Since ascending the throne in January, the King had sought to receive his government's approval for a divorce.
March  – The Astronomical Society of London is founded.
A group of  free African American colonists sail from New York City to Freetown, Sierra Leone, with a goal of creating a home for freed American slaves, to be called "Liberia".
June  – Battle of Carabobo: Simón Bolívar wins Venezuela's independence from Spain.

April  (O.S.)/April  (N.S.) – Ecumenical Patriarch Gregory V of Constantinople is blamed by the Ottoman government for being unable to suppress Greek independence, and is hanged outside the main gate of the Patriarchal Cathedral immediately after the celebration of Pascha.
August  (O.S.)/August  (N.S.) – Navarino massacre: Greek rebels massacre , inhabitants of the city of Navarino.
September  (O.S.)/September  (N.S.) – Ukase of : Russia proclaims territorial sovereignty over Northwestern North America, modern-day Alaska.
February  – In Mexico, the Embrace of Acatempan takes place between Agustín de Iturbide and Vicente Guerrero, which seals the peace between the viceroyalty troops and the insurgents.
Over the middle of the year Franz Schubert begins writing his Symphony No. , but leaves it unfinished.

August  — The body of British poet Percy Bysse Shelley, who died on July  in the sinking of his boat Don Juan, is cremated at the beach,  days after his decomposed remains had washed ashore in Italy near Viareggio, in the presence of Lord Byron and Edward John Trelawny, who claims to have seized Shelley's heart from the flames.

August 
Lord Castlereagh, the British Foreign Secretary,  commits suicide at his house in Kent. He is judged to have been insane at the time.
St David's College (the modern-day University of Wales, Lampeter) is founded in Wales by Thomas Burgess, Bishop of St David's.
September  – Portugal approves its first Constitution.
September  – The Roman Catholic Church first  permits the publication of Galileo Galilei's  treatise, Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems.)
The first Anglo-Ashanti War begins.
July  – The Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls in Rome is almost completely destroyed by fire.
September  – Pamplona surrenders to French forces after a five-month siege.
British expedition up the St. Clair River; site of Corunna surveyed as a potential capital for Upper Canada.
Gioachino Rossini's opera Semiramide is first performed, at La Fenice in Venice.

September  – The earliest reference by the British government to an official renaming of its South Pacific Ocean territory as "Australia" comes in a dispatch titled "Taking Possession of Melville and Bathurst Islands", as the Admiral Sir Gordon Bremer refers to "the North Coast of New Holland or Australia".

April  – The first permanent settlers arrive to construct the new city of Tallahassee, Florida, selected to be the capital of the Florida Territory newly acquired from the Kingdom of Spain; the area has been selected because it is roughly equidistant from the territory's main cities, Pensacola and St. Augustine.
February  — William Buckland formally announces the name Megalosaurus, the first scientifically validly named non-avian dinosaur species.

December  – Peruvian War of Independence: Battle of Ayacucho – Colombian and Peruvian forces led by Antonio José de Sucre defeat the Spanish. The commander, Viceroy de la Serna, surrenders, ending Spain's domination of South America.
March  – The First Anglo-Burmese War begins in much of what is now Bangladesh, and lasts for almost two years until the a surrender of territories by the Kingdom of Burma on February , .
Minh Mạng outlaws the teaching of Christianity in Vietnam.
May  – The Coronation of Charles X takes place at the historic site of Reims Cathedral, the last coronation of a French monarch.
The U.S. Senate ratifies treaties with the Mandan, Belantae, Eloa and Minnetaree tribes.
July  – The U.S. Senate ratifies treaties with the Hunkpapa tribe.

February  – After no presidential candidate receives a majority of United States Electoral College votes following the  United States presidential election, the United States House of Representatives elects John Quincy Adams President of the United States in a contingent election.
The Eggnog Riot breaks out at the United States Military Academy in West Point, New York during the early morning hours.
April  – The Third Siege of Missolonghi ends and is followed by the massacre of thousands of Greek defenders by the Ottoman besiegers.
Mahmud II's council orders the janissaries to drill in the European manner.

March  – Dom João VI, King of Portugal and former Emperor of Brazil, dies six days after he had been served dinner while visiting Jerónimos Monastery. An investigative autopsy  years later will discover that he had been killed by arsenic poisoning. King João's, Emperor Pedro I of Brazil, sails back to Portugal and briefly reigns as King Pedro IV of Portugal, before turning over the Portuguese throne to his daughter, Maria.

July  (O.S.: July ) – Five leaders of the Decembrist revolt of  in Russia (Pyotr Kakhovsky, Pavel Pestel, poet Kondraty Ryleyev, Sergey Muravyov-Apostol and Mikhail Bestuzhev-Ryumin) are hanged in Senate Square, Saint Petersburg, where they had launched their attempted coup d'état. Other conspirators begin their journey into exile in Siberia.

May  – The Royal Netherlands Navy's British-built paddle steamer Curaçao completes the first transatlantic crossing by steam, arriving in Paramaribo in Dutch Guiana (now Suriname) four weeks after its April  departure from the Netherlands.

The missionary ship Messenger of Peace is built on Rarotonga by English Congregationalist John Williams to spread Christianity to Samoa and the Society Islands on behalf of the London Missionary Society.
January  – The first public theatre in Norway, the Christiania Offentlige Theater, is inaugurated in Christiania (modern-day Oslo).
April  – Battle of Monte Santiago: A squadron of the Brazilian Imperial Navy defeats Argentine vessels after a two-day naval battle.

January  – Furman University, founded in , begins its first classes with  students, as the Furman Academy and Theological Institution, located in Edgefield, South Carolina. By the end of , it will have , students at its main campus in Greenville, South Carolina.
January  – The Democratic Party of the United States is organized.
August  – Russian forces succeed in the Battle of Akhaltsikhe against the Ottomans, capturing the fortress after an -day siege.

December  – The U.S. State of Georgia legislature charters the Medical Academy of Georgia, which becomes the Medical College of Georgia, and authorizes it to award a Bachelor of Medicine degree, making it the 13th oldest U.S. medical school and the sixth public medical school to be established.
Friedrich Wöhler synthesizes urea, possibly discrediting a cornerstone of vitalism.
May  – The Sacramental Test Act in the United Kingdom removes most prohibitions on nonconformists and Catholics holding public office.
April  – The Catholic Relief Act is passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom, granting a substantial measure of Catholic emancipation in Britain and Ireland.
July  – Russo-Turkish War (–): Russian Field-Marshal Hans Karl von Diebitsch launches the Trans-Balkan Offensive, which brings the Russian army within  kilometres ( mi) of Istanbul.
February  – Battle of Tarqui: Troops of Gran Colombia and Peru battle to a draw.
October  – Stephenson's Rocket wins the Rainhill trials to determine the practicality of steam locomotives to operate the Liverpool and Manchester Railway in England.

April – Popular German conductor Felix Mendelssohn begins his first of  visits to Britain, touring the island until November . This includes the first London performance of his concert overture to A Midsummer Night's Dream, and his trip to Fingal's Cave.
January  – LaGrange College (later the University of North Alabama) begins operation, becoming the first publicly chartered college in Alabama.
November  – Ferdinand II becomes King of the Two Sicilies.
June  – William IV succeeds his brother George IV, as King of the United Kingdom.
July  – Uruguay adopts its first constitution.
July  – Barthélemy Thimonnier is granted a French patent (#) for a sewing machine; it chains stitches at /minute.
January  – William Lloyd Garrison begins publishing The Liberator, an anti-slavery newspaper, in Boston, Massachusetts.
New York University in New York City
July  – The volcanic Graham Island briefly emerges in the Mediterranean.
February  – The Belgian Constitution of  is approved by the National Congress.
August  – The Dutch Ten Days' Campaign against Belgium is halted by a French army.

January  – The Christmas Rebellion of slaves is brought to an end in Jamaica, after the island's white planters organize militias and the British Army sends companies of the 84th regiment to enforce martial law.  More than  of the slave rebels will be publicly hanged for their part in the destruction.
May  – Greece is recognized as a sovereign nation; the Treaty of Constantinople ends the Greek War of Independence in July.
September  – Qasim al-Ahmad is appointed as the new Ottoman Governor (mutasallim) of Jerusalem (Kudüs), after Sultan Mahmud II dismisses Muhammad Said Agha.
July  – Durham University is founded in the north of England by an act of Parliament given royal assent by King William IV.
February  – The Florida Legislative Council grants a city charter for Jacksonville, Florida.
The Ottoman Empire promulgates a firman ratifying the Peace Agreement of Kütahya, bringing an end to the Egyptian-Ottoman War.
September  – At least , people are killed when an . magnitude earthquake shakes the Chinese province of Yunnan destroying buildings, homes and temples.
Greece recaptures the Acropolis of Athens.
February  (January  on the Greek calendar) – Prince Otto Friedrich Ludwig of Bavaria arrives at the port of Nafplio to assume the title King Othon the First of Greece
January  – The United Kingdom reasserts British sovereignty over the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic Ocean.
June  – Greek independence: General Theodoros Kolokotronis is sentenced to death for treason, for resisting the rule of Otto of Greece (he is released the following year).
August  –  The Poor Law Amendment Act in the United Kingdom states that no able-bodied British man can receive assistance, unless he enters a workhouse (a kind of poorhouse).
April  – Spain, France, Portugal and the United Kingdom sign the Quadruple Alliance.
May  – The Peasants' Revolt in Egyptian-ruled Palestine begins; it is suppressed in August.
Statue of Jean-Jacques Rousseau is erected in his birthplace of Geneva.

July  – An assassination attempt against King Louis Philippe I of France is attempted by Giuseppe Marco Fieschi, who uses a home-made volley gun and kills  people. The King escapes with a minor wound.
September  – Charles Darwin arrives at the Galápagos Islands, aboard HMS Beagle.
The French word for their language changes to français, from françois.
May  – The Mexican State of Aguascalientes is formed, by decree of President Antonio López de Santa Anna.
Fort Cass is established, the military headquarters and site of the largest internment camps during the  Trail of Tears.

January 
HMS Beagle, with Charles Darwin on board, reaches Sydney.
Will County, Illinois, is formed.
The United States Survey of the Coast is returned to the U.S. Treasury Department, and renamed the U.S. Coast Survey.

December 
Spain recognizes the independence of Mexico.
The Colony of South Australia is founded by Captain John Hindmarsh.
October  – Theodor Fliedner, a Lutheran minister, and Friederike, his wife, open the Deaconess Home and Hospital at Kaiserswerth, Germany, as an institute to train women in nursing.
Spain recognizes the independence of Mexico.
September  – First Carlist War: Battle of Aranzueque – The liberal forces loyal to Queen Isabel II of Spain are victorious, ending the Carlist campaign known as the Expedición Real.
December  – The Caroline Affair, on the Niagara River, becomes the basis for the Caroline test for anticipatory self-defence in international relations.

October  – The Tsarskoye Selo Railway, the first in the Russian Empire, opens between Saint Petersburg Tsarskoselsky station and Zarskoje Selo (modern-day Pushkin), engineered by Franz Anton von Gerstner.
November  – American abolitionist and newspaper editor Elijah Lovejoy is killed by a pro-slavery mob, at his warehouse in Alton, Illinois.
January  – The destructive Galilee earthquake causes thousands of deaths in Ottoman Syria.
An insurrection breaks out in Tizimín, beginning the campaign for the independence of Yucatán from Mexico.
September  – Grace Darling and her father rescue  survivors from the Forfarshire, off the Farne Islands.
September  – The Anti-Corn Law League is established in Britain by Richard Cobden.
November  – The Bombay Times and Journal of Commerce is founded (renamed  The Times of India in ).
Sylvain Charles Valée founds Skikda, Algeria.

The United Kingdom, backed by the Russian Empire and the Austrian Empire, compels July Monarchy France to abandon Muhammad Ali of Egypt, and forces him to return Syria and Arabia to the Ottoman Empire.
In the United States, the first state law permitting women to own property is passed in Jackson, Mississippi.

May  – Socialist activist Louis Auguste Blanqui and the Société des Saisons begin an uprising against the government of France. The insurrection is suppressed, but not before  people are killed and  wounded. Blanqui is imprisoned until .
Tanzimat starts in the Ottoman Empire.
July  – First Anglo-Afghan War: Battle of Ghazni – British forces capture the fortress city of Ghazni in Afghanistan.
January  – British colonists reach New Zealand, officially founding the settlement of Wellington.
The Province of Canada is created by the Act of Union, but not proclaimed until  February .
November  –  United States presidential election: William Henry Harrison defeats Martin Van Buren in a landslide.
September  – Ottoman and British troops bombard Beirut, and land troops on the coast, to pressure Egyptian Muhammad Ali to retreat from the country.
December  – The body of Napoleon is laid to rest in Les Invalides in Paris.
February  – The first ongoing filibuster in the United States Senate begins, and lasts until March .
January  – The active volcano Mount Erebus in Antarctica is discovered, and named by James Clark Ross.
El Salvador proclaims itself an independent republic, bringing an end to the  Federal Republic of Central America.
May – The Sino-Sikh War begins.
January  – Charles Elliot of the United Kingdom and Qishan of the Qing dynasty agree to the Convention of Chuenpi.

February  – The modern-day Willamette University, the oldest institution of higher learning in the western United States, is established in Salem, Oregon as "The Oregon Institute". The first students begin classes begin on August , .
April  – First Anglo-Afghan War: Battle of Jellalabad – British troops are victorious.
May  – Dorr Rebellion: Militiamen supporting Thomas Wilson Dorr attack the arsenal in Providence, Rhode Island, but are repulsed.
January  – Antarctic explorer James Clark Ross, charting the eastern side of James Ross Island, reaches a Farthest South of °'"S.
Indiana University Maurer School of Law at Indiana University Bloomington.
May  – Chile takes possession of the Strait of Magellan.
Serial publication of Charles Dickens's novel Martin Chuzzlewit begins in London; in the July chapters, he lands his hero in the United States.
December  – Basutoland becomes a British protectorate.
May  – In Edinburgh, the Free Church of Scotland is disrupted from the Church of Scotland.
Søren Kierkegaard's philosophical book Fear and Trembling is first published, in Denmark.
In Tibet, the Temple of Guardians burns down.
Robert Chambers' anonymous Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation, which paves the way for acceptance of Darwin's The Origin of Species, is published in Britain.
December  –  United States presidential election: James K. Polk defeats Henry Clay.
September – – The first ever international cricket match is played in New York City, United States v Canadian Provinces.

October  – This second date predicted by the Millerites for the Second Coming of Jesus (and said to be , years from creation, relating them to the  days of creation, using a day-for-a-year bible principle, with which they proved that the , years of rest in heaven with God would total to , years, indicating the completion of creation in the beginning, which make  days, but the 7th day is for rest, same as the ,000th year is for rest in heaven), leads to the Great Disappointment. The Seventh-day Adventist Church believes this date to be the starting point of the Investigative judgment, just prior to the Second Coming of Jesus, as declared in the 26th of  fundamental doctrines of Seventh-day Adventists.
Friedrich Engels' treatise The Condition of the Working Class in England is published in Leipzig as Die Lage der arbeitenden Klasse in England.

November  – Anglo-French blockade of the Río de la Plata – Battle of Vuelta de Obligado: The Argentine Confederation is narrowly defeated by an Anglo–French fleet on the waters of the Paraná River, but the victors suffer serious damage to their ships, and Argentina attracts political support in South America.

March  – President John Tyler signs a bill authorizing the United States to annex the Republic of Texas, subject to approval by the voters in the Republic. The territory claimed includes all of the future U.S. state of Texas, as well as portions of New Mexico, Oklahoma, Kansas, Colorado and Wyoming.
Anesthesia is used for childbirth for the first time, by Dr. Crawford Long in Jefferson, Georgia.
For the first time, both houses of the United States Congress vote, by a two-thirds majority, to override a presidential veto in order to pass legislation.
September  – Jang Bahadur and his brothers massacre about  members of the Nepalese palace court.
February  – First Anglo-Sikh war: Battle of Sobraon – British forces in India defeat the Sikhs.
February  – The Galician Peasant Uprising of  begins in Austria.
The first higher school of academic learning for women in Denmark, Den højere Dannelsesanstalt for Damer, is founded in Copenhagen.

September  – Discovery of Neptune: The planet is observed for the first time by German astronomers Johann Gottfried Galle and Heinrich Louis d'Arrest, as predicted by British astronomer John Couch Adams and French astronomer Urbain Le Verrier.
February  – State University of Iowa is founded in Iowa City, Iowa.
April  – The Exmouth, carrying Irish emigrants from Derry bound for Quebec, is wrecked off Islay, with only three survivors from more than  on board.
October  – Theta Delta Chi is founded as a social fraternity at Union College, Schenectady, New York.
August  – Mexican–American War: U.S. troops of General Winfield Scott begin to advance along the aqueduct around Lakes Chalco and Xochimilco in Mexico.

May 
The Nagano earthquake leaves more than , people dead in Japan.
Bahrain's ruler, Shaikh Mohamed bin Khalifa Al Khalifa, signs a treaty with the British to prevent and combat the slave trade in the Arabian Gulf.
May  – Wisconsin is admitted as the 30th U.S. state.
Richard Wagner begins writing the libretto that will become Der Ring des Nibelungen ("The Ring of the Nibelung").
Slavery is abolished in Réunion (this day is celebrated every year from ).

April 
A Chartist 'Monster Rally' is held in Kennington Park London, headed by Feargus O'Connor. A petition demanding the franchise is presented to the Parliament of the United Kingdom.
The Illinois and Michigan Canal is completed.
July  – Young Irelander Rebellion: A nationalist revolt in County Tipperary, against British rule, is put down by the Irish Constabulary.

March 
The Second Anglo-Sikh War ends, with the United Kingdom annexing the Punjab.
Maharaja Duleep Singh is exiled to England.

April 
The German revolutions of – end in failure, as King Frederick William IV of Prussia refuses to accept the offer of the Frankfurt National Assembly, to be crowned as German emperor.
Hungarian Revolution of  – Battle of Hatvan: The Hungarian revolutionary army, under the command of András Gáspár, defeats the Austrians, led by general Franz Schlik.

April  – Hungarian Revolution of  – Battle of Isaszeg: The main Hungarian forces, led by Arthur Görgey, defeat the main imperial forces, led by Alfred I, Prince of Windisch-Grätz, forcing them to retreat westward.

February  – Regular steamboat service from the west to the east coast of the United States begins, with the arrival of the SS California in San Francisco Bay. The California leaves New York Harbor on October , , rounds Cape Horn at the tip of South America, and arrives at San Francisco after the -month, -day journey.
The Austrian government asks Russian help against the Hungarian Revolution. Tsar Nicholas I of Russia agrees to send troops against Hungary.
The New Mexico Territory is organized by order of the United States Congress.
March  – The paddle steamer RMS Royal Adelaide, bound from Cork to London, is wrecked in the English Channel with the loss of all  on board.
June  – Kansas City, Missouri, is incorporated by Jackson County, Missouri, as the Town of Kansas (traditional date of its founding).
April  – Los Angeles is incorporated as a city in California.
The Fugitive Slave Law is passed by the United States Congress.
Mid-May to mid-July – Great Flood of : Extensive flooding sweeps across the Midwestern United States. The town of Des Moines is virtually washed away, and many rainfall records hold for  years.
Nian Rebellion in China, –.
March  – Victor Hugo uses the phrase United States of Europe, in a speech to the French National Assembly.
The first Australian gold rush is proclaimed, although the discovery had been made three months earlier.
October  – The first Parsi-Muslim riot begins in Bombay, India.
July  – American statesman Henry Clay is the first to receive the honor of lying in state in the United States Capitol rotunda.
February  – The Helsinki Cathedral (known as St. Nicholas' Church at time) is officially inaugurated in Helsinki, Finland.
September  – French engineer Henri Giffard makes the first airship trip, from Paris to Trappes.

February  – Battle of Caseros, Argentina: The Argentine provinces of Entre Rios and Corrientes, allied with Brazil and members of Colorado Party of Uruguay, defeat Buenos Aires troops under Juan Manuel de Rosas.
The Devil's Island penal colony opens in the colony of French Guiana.
March  – Giuseppe Verdi's opera La traviata premieres at La Fenice in Venice, but is poorly received at this time.
March  – Manchester is granted city status in the United Kingdom.
August  – The first true International Meteorological Organization is established in Brussels, Belgium.
February  – The city of Puerto Montt is founded in the Reloncaví Sound, Chile.

May
The world's first public aquarium opens, as a feature of the London Zoo.
An outbreak of yellow fever kills , people in New Orleans.
Isambard Kingdom Brunel accepts John Scott Russell's tender for construction of the SS Great Eastern passenger steamer.
October – – United States diplomats in Europe meet and draft the Ostend Manifesto, setting out a rationale for the U.S. to acquire Cuba from Spain.
May  – Taiping Rebellion: United States diplomatic minister Robert McLane arrives at the Heavenly Capital aboard the USS Susquehanna.
January  – The Teutonia Männerchor in Pittsburgh is founded to promote German culture.
A Russian fort is established at the modern-day site of Almaty.

June  – Battle of Bomarsund in Åland off the coast of Finland: British Royal Navy seaman's mate Charles Davis Lucas throws a live Russian artillery shell overboard by hand before it explodes, for which he is awarded the first Victoria Cross in .
July – Bank of Toronto incorporated in Canada (in  it will merge with The Dominion Bank to become Toronto-Dominion Bank).

July 
Thomas Cook escorts his first party of excursionists from England to tour the European continent, travelling via Belgium and enabling the tourists to visit the Paris Exposition.
Walt Whitman's poetry collection Leaves of Grass is published in Brooklyn.
March  – Taiping Rebellion: A Taiping army of , invades Anhui.
July  – The Australian Colonies  are granted self-governing status by the United Kingdom.
January  – Ramón Castilla begins his third term as President of Peru.
October  – The Second Opium War between several Western powers and China begins with the Arrow Incident on the Pearl River.
June  – Taiping Rebellion: Shi Dakai arrives at Nanjing.
The -mile North Carolina Railroad is completed from Goldsboro through Raleigh and Salisbury to Charlotte.
January  – The American sidewheel steamer SS Pacific leaves Liverpool (England) for a transatlantic voyage on which she will be lost with all  on board.
Legal protection of widow remarriage is extended in India.
September  – The SS Central America sinks off the coast of North Carolina with the loss of  lives.
December  – U.S. Consul in Japan Townsend Harris meets the Shogun in Edo in a diplomatic reception, the first ever meeting between the Shogun and a foreign diplomat.
December  – Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria issues a decree, Es ist Mein Wille, which leads to the demolition of the city walls of Vienna, allowing the construction of the Ringstraße.
August  – The Dunbar wrecks near the entrance to Sydney Harbour, Australia, with the loss of  lives.
September  – The Mountain Meadows massacre occurs in Utah.
August  – The first of the Lincoln–Douglas debates is held in Illinois.
March  – Felice Orsini is executed by guillotine for the attempted assassination of Napoleon III of France.

July
Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour goads Austria into attacking Sardinia.
Pike's Peak Gold Rush: Fifty-Niners stream into the Rocky Mountains of the western United States.

April –May  – Battle of Grahovac: The Ottomans are decisively defeated by  Montenegrin forces. The Bawani Imli massacre, (April ) where  Indian freedom fighters were hanged to death on a tamarind tree by British colonial forces.
The city of Denver, Colorado, is founded.
July  – Grand Combin, one of the highest summits in the Alps, is first ascended.

May , June  – Geologist Joseph Prestwich and amateur archaeologist John Evans report (to the Royal Society and Society of Antiquaries of London, respectively) the results of their investigations of gravel-pits in the Somme valley and elsewhere, extending human history back to what will become known as the Paleolithic Era.
November  – The first Zappas Olympics open in Greece.
John Stuart Mill publishes On Liberty.
Karl Marx publishes A Contribution to the Critique of Political Economy.

May  – In New Granada (modern-day Colombia) the southern state of Cauca secedes from the central government, in protest at the suggestion of increase of presidential powers; Magdalena and Bolívar join it; civil war erupts.
December  – After a fiercely contested campaign, Monier Monier-Williams is elected as the new Boden Professor of Sanskrit, at Oxford University.
Christians and Druzes clash in Damascus, Syria.
December  – Mexico's interim president Miguel Miramón flees the country after being defeated in battle.
TAG Heuer watchmaker founded in Bern Canton, Switzerland.
March  – Confederate Arizona: A convention in modern-day Tucson ratifies the ordinance of secession of the southern part of New Mexico Territory.

American Civil War:
November  –  Battle of Round Mountain in Indian Territory (modern-day Oklahoma).
November  –  Confederate President Jefferson Davis appoints Judah P. Benjamin Secretary of War.
August  – First description of Archaeopteryx, based on a feather found in Bavaria; in September the first complete identified skeleton is found near Langenaltheim in Germany.
June  – Benito Juárez is formally elected President of Mexico; he temporarily stops the payments of foreign debt.
February  – In Britain, storms damage the Crystal Palace and cause the collapse of the steeple of Chichester Cathedral.
August  – The Dakota War of  begins in Minnesota, as Dakota Sioux attack white settlements along the Minnesota River. They are overwhelmed by the U.S. Army six weeks later.
April  – Battle of Yorktown – The battle begins when Union Army forces under General George B. McClellan close in on the Confederate capital of Richmond, Virginia.
March  – Victor Hugo's epic French historical novel Les Misérables begins publication in Brussels.
April  – Siege of Fort Macon – The besieged Confederate garrison at Fort Macon, North Carolina surrenders.
June  – Confederate troops evacuate Fort Pillow on the Mississippi River, leaving the way clear for Union Army troops to capture Memphis, Tennessee.
The U.S. National Conscription Act is signed, leading to the New York City draft riots in July.

August  – American Civil War: Following his defeat in the Battle of Gettysburg, General Robert E. Lee sends a letter of resignation to Confederate President Jefferson Davis (Davis refuses the request upon receipt).
October  – U.S. President Abraham Lincoln proclaims a national Thanksgiving Day, to be celebrated on the final Thursday in November.

January  – Abraham Lincoln signs the Emancipation Proclamation during the third year of the American Civil War, making the abolition of slavery in the Confederate States of America an official war goal. The signing proclaimed the freedom of . million of the nation's four million slaves and immediately frees , of them, with the rest freed as the Union Army advances. This event marks the start of America's Reconstruction Era.

November  – King Christian IX of Denmark signs the November Constitution, which declares Schleswig to be part of Denmark, regarded by the German Confederation as a violation of the London Protocol of , leading to the German–Danish war of .
& May  –  Battle of New Market – Cadets from the Virginia Military Institute fight alongside the Confederate Army, forcing Union General Franz Sigel out of the Shenandoah Valley.
October  – American Civil War: Battle of Tom's Brook – Union cavalrymen in the Shenandoah Valley defeat Confederate forces at Tom's Brook, Virginia.

November  – American Indian Wars: Sand Creek massacre – Colorado volunteers, led by Colonel John Chivington, massacre at least  Cheyenne and Arapaho noncombatants at Sand Creek, Colorado (where they had been given permission to camp); many of the dead are subsequently mutilated.
November  – A group of Confederate operatives, calling themselves the Confederate Army of Manhattan, starts fires in more than  locations, in an unsuccessful attempt to burn down New York City.
American Civil War: The Army of the Potomac, under General Ulysses S. Grant, breaks off from the Battle of the Wilderness and moves southwards.
July  – The steamer Brother Jonathan sinks off the California coast, killing  passengers and crew.
February  – John Deere receives a United States patent for ploughs.

May – – American Civil War – Battle of Palmito Ranch: In far south Texas, more than a month after Confederate General Lee's surrender, the last land battle of the civil war with casualties, ends with a Confederate victory.
December  – The Kappa Alpha Order is founded at Washington College, Lexington, Virginia.
October  – Florida drafts its constitution in Tallahassee.
July  – Princess Helena, third daughter of Queen Victoria, marries Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein.
June – – Battle of Langensalza: The Prussians defeat the Hanoverian army.
May  – Student Ferdinand Cohen-Blind makes a failed attempt to assassinate Otto von Bismarck in Unter den Linden in Berlin.
July  – Austro-Prussian War: Battle of Blumenau – Austrians defend Bratislava against the Prussian army, concluding the fighting in the war.
The Royal Aeronautical Society is formed as The Aeronautical Society of Great Britain in London, the world's oldest such society.
September  – Emperor Meiji of Japan marries Empress Shōken (née Masako Ichijō). The Empress consort is thereafter known as Lady Haruko.
At Fountain Point, Michigan, an artesian water spring, begins to gush continuously.
January  – Emperor Kōmei of Japan dies suddenly, age , leaving his son Mutsuhito to succeed him.
July  – Queen's Park F.C., the oldest association football league team in Scotland, is founded.
November  – The last shōgun of Japan, Tokugawa Yoshinobu, tenders his resignation to Emperor Meiji.
September  – Grito de Lares: Rebels (some – led by Ramón Emeterio Betances) in the town of Lares declare Puerto Rico independent; the local militia easily defeats them a week later.

July 
Wyoming becomes a United States territory.
Paraguayan War: The Allies, in an amphibious operation, capture the fortress of Humaitá.
Herrenhäuser Brewery is established in Hanover, Germany.
May – – Boshin War – Battle of Utsunomiya Castle, Japan: Forces of the Emperor Meiji resist the retreating troops of the Tokugawa shogunate.
The Académie Julian, a major art school in Paris, France, that admits women, is established.

French missionary and naturalist Père Armand David receives the skin of a giant panda from a hunter, the first time this species becomes known to a Westerner; he also first describes a specimen of the "pocket handkerchief tree", which will be named in his honor as Davidia involucrata.
November  – In Egypt, the Suez Canal, linking the Mediterranean Sea with the Red Sea, is inaugurated in an elaborate ceremony.
November  – The first issue of the scientific journal Nature is published in London, edited by Norman Lockyer.
January  – Scotland's second oldest professional football team, Kilmarnock F.C., is founded.
Gamma Sigma becomes the first high school fraternity in North America at Brockport Normal School, Brockport, New York.
November  – The Spanish Cortes Generales proclaims Amadeo de Saboya as King Amadeo I of Spain.

December 
Sir Henry Barkly is appointed Governor of the Cape of Good Hope and High Commissioner for Southern Africa.
The . km (. mi) Fréjus Rail Tunnel through the Alps is completed.

March 
The Fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, giving African American men the right to vote, is ratified.
Reconstruction: Texas is readmitted to the Union.
The first edition of The Northern Echo newspaper is published in Priestgate, Darlington, England.
Just one of the  members of the Indian Civil Service is Indian.
August  – Adolphe Thiers becomes President of the French Republic.
