November – The South Improvement Company is formed in Pennsylvania by John D. Rockefeller and a group of major United States railroad interests, in an early effort to organize and control the American petroleum industry.
The United States Army issues an order for the abandonment of Fort Kearny, Nebraska.
April  – Murder of Jane Clouson, a servant girl, in Eltham, England; her probable murderer is acquitted.
July  – The first cat show is held at the Crystal Palace of London.
George Westinghouse receives a United States patent for the "failsafe" automatic railway air brake.
February  – The government of the United Kingdom buys a number of forts on the Gold Coast, from the Netherlands.
June  – Thomas Hardy anonymously publishes his novel Under the Greenwood Tree in England.

May – Rangers F.C., founded in March as an Association football club in Glasgow (Scotland) by brothers Moses and Peter McNeil, Peter Campbell and William McBeath, play their first ever game on the public pitches of Glasgow Green, a  to  draw against Callander.
December   – President Ulysses S. Grant establishes the San Carlos Apache Reservation, in southeastern Arizona.
July  – New Rush in Griqualand West, South Africa, is renamed Kimberley.
July  – At Adair, Iowa, Jesse James and the James–Younger Gang pull off the first successful train robbery in the American Old West (US$, from the Rock Island Express).
September  – The New York stock market crashes as the Jay Cooke & Company investment firm declares bankruptcy, triggering the Panic of , part of the Long Depression.

December  – Third Carlist War: Battle of Bocairente – Campaigning in Valenica, Spanish Republican General Valeriano Weyler is attacked at Bocairente, northwest of Alcoy, by a greatly superior Carlist force under General José Santés. Weyler is initially driven back, losing some of his guns, but in a brilliant counter-attack he turns defeat into victory, and Santés is heavily repulsed and forced to withdraw.

May 
Levi Strauss and Jacob Davis receive United States patent 139121, for using copper rivets to strengthen the pockets of denim work pants. Levi Strauss & Co. begins manufacturing the famous Levi's brand of jeans, using fabric from the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company in Manchester, New Hampshire.
In Chipping Norton, England, rioters attempt to free the Ascott Martyrs – women sentenced to imprisonment, for attempting to dissuade strikebreakers in an agricultural labor dispute.
November  – Sailing ship Cospatrick carrying emigrants from England bound for New Zealand, catches fire and sinks in the South Atlantic with the loss of all but three of the  persons on board.

August  – Third Carlist War: Battle of Oteiza – Two months after Government forces were repulsed from Carlist-held Estella, in Navarre, Republican General Domingo Moriones makes a fresh diversionary attack a few miles to the southeast at Oteiza. In heavy fighting Moriones secures a costly tactical victory over Carlist General Torcuato Mendíri, but the war continues another  months, before Estella finally falls.

September  – Battle of Liberty Place: In New Orleans, former Confederate Army members of the White League temporarily drive Republican Governor William P. Kellogg from office, replacing him with former Democratic Governor John McEnery. U.S. Army troops restore Kellogg to office five days later.
September  – Captain Lyman's wagon train besieged by Indians in Hemphill County, Texas.
May  – Third Carlist War: The siege of Bilbao is lifted.
January  – The Palais Garnier, one of the most famous opera houses in the world, is inaugurated as the home of the Paris Opera.
September  – American merchant sailing ship Ellen Southard is wrecked off Liverpool in England;  crew and life-boatmen are lost.
October  – The Theosophical Society is founded in New York by Helena Blavatsky, Henry Steel Olcott, William Quan Judge, and others.

Third Carlist War in Spain: Two government armies under General Quesada and Martínez Campos start encroaching on Carlist territory. Both they and their Carlist opponent (Mendiri) drive opposing sympathisers from their homes, and burn crops in areas they can not hold. Several Carlist generals (Dorregaray, Savalls, and others) are unjustly put on trial for disloyalty. Mendiri is also removed from his command, and replaced by the Count of Caserta. Despite having  infantry battalions,  cavalry regiments,  engineer battalions, and  pieces of artillery at his disposal, Caserta is heavily outnumbered by the government forces opposing him.

February  – The majority of the Yavapai (Wipukyipai) and Tonto Apache (Dil Zhéé) tribes are forced by the United States Cavalry, under command of Brigadier General George Crook, to walk at gunpoint from Arizona's Verde Valley, to the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation,  miles to the southeast. The two tribes are not allowed to return to the Verde Valley until .
March  – United States Secretary of War William W. Belknap resigns his office in the wake of the trader post scandal.

February  – Third Carlist War: The Carlist forces do not succeed, and the promises are never fulfilled. The Carlist pretender Carlos, Duke of Madrid, goes into exile in France, bringing the conflict to an end after four years.
October  – The American Library Association is founded in Philadelphia.
March  – Alexander Graham Bell makes the first successful telephone call, saying "Mr. Watson, come here, I want to see you".
The Conchological Society of Great Britain & Ireland is founded.
September  – The Battle of Lovcha, third battle in the siege of Plevna, is fought. Russian forces successfully reduce the Ottoman fortress at Lovcha.
August  – Asaph Hall discovers Phobos, the inner moon of Mars.
April  – Russo-Turkish War (–): Russia declares war on the Ottoman Empire.
Russo-Turkish War: The Turkish army and its allies destroy the Bulgarian city of Stara Zagora and massacre the inhabitants.
June  – Henry Ossian Flipper becomes the first African American cadet to graduate from the U.S. Military Academy.

The following English Association football clubs:
Everton F.C., formed as St Domingo.
Grimsby Town F.C., formed as Grimsby Pelham.
Ipswich Town Football Club, formed as amateur club Ipswich A.F.C. They will not turn professional until .
Newton Heath Lancashire and Yorkshire Railway Football Club, the team that will become Manchester United.
West Bromwich Albion F.C., formed as West Bromwich Strollers F.C.
West Bromwich Albion F.C., formed as West Bromwich Strollers F.C.
June  – The United States Coast Survey is renamed the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey.
April  – The Stawell Gift sprint is run for the first time in Australia.

December  – The United States territory of New Mexico is linked to the rest of the nation by railroad for the first time, as the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway inaugurates a newly completed line through the Raton Pass.
September  – A fire in The Octagon, Dunedin (New Zealand), claims  victims.
April – Postman Ferdinand Cheval begins to build his Palais Idéal at Hauterives in France.
August  – Tokio Marine (insurer) is founded in Japan, as Tokio Marine Holdings.
Brahms' Violin Concerto is premiered in Leipzig with Joseph Joachim as soloist and the composer conducting.
November  – Thomas Edison applies for a patent for his invention of the incandescent light bulb (U.S. Patent , will be granted on January , ).
February  – The Black Donnelly Massacre takes the lives of five members of one family in Biddulph Township, Middlesex County, Ontario, Canada.

February  – The SS Columbia, which will be the first outside usage of Thomas Edison's incandescent light bulb, is launched at the Delaware River Iron Ship Building and Engine Works of John Roach & Sons in Chester, Pennsylvania.
The first successful shipment of frozen mutton from Australia arrives in London, aboard the SS Strathleven.

February 
The first electric streetlight is installed in Wabash, Indiana.
The first successful shipment of frozen mutton from Australia arrives in London, aboard the SS Strathleven.
The Department of Scientific Temperance Instruction, of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, is established in the United States.

April 
Temuco, Chile, is founded.
Anti-Semitic pogroms in Southern Russia begin.
February  – Kansas becomes the first U.S. state to prohibit all alcoholic beverages.

September  – Francis Howell High School (Howell Institute) in St. Charles, Missouri, and Stephen F. Austin High School in Austin, Texas, open on the same day, putting them in a tie for the title of the oldest public high school west of the Mississippi River.
February  – Carlos Finlay introduces his discovery of the transmission of Yellow Fever by mosquitoes Aedes aegypti, in the Fifth International Sanitary Conference held in Washington, D.C.
July  – The first episode of Carlo Collodi's The Adventures of Pinocchio is published in Italy.
March  – Roderick Maclean fails in an attempt to assassinate Queen Victoria, at Windsor.
November  – Franklyn Leslie shoots Billy Claiborne dead in the streets of Tombstone, Arizona.
Boers establish the republic of Stellaland in southern Africa.
Nikola Tesla claims this is when he conceives the rotating magnetic field principle, which he later uses to invent his induction motor.
Richard Wagner's opera Parsifal debuts, at the Bayreuth Festspielhaus in Bavaria.
Bernard Kroger establishes the first Kroger grocery store, in Cincinnati, Ohio.

October 
The Boys' Brigade (the first uniformed youth organization in existence) is founded in Glasgow, Scotland.
The Orient Express train begins to run through from Paris Gare de l'Est to Giurgiu in Romania, with onward ferry and train connections to Istanbul (the train has been running since June  as far as Vienna).
November  – Whitman College is chartered as a -year college in Walla Walla, Washington.
June  – In Milan, Italy, the first central European electricity power station is inaugurated.
November  – Chile's National Library of Congress is founded.

December 
American Old West: Near Frisco, New Mexico, deputy sheriff Elfego Baca holds off a gang of  Texan cowboys, who want to kill him for arresting cowboy Charles McCarthy (the cowboys have been terrorizing the area's Hispanos, and Baca is working against them).
Porfirio Díaz returns as President of Mexico, an office he will hold until .
June  (N.S.) (May  O.S.) – The future flag of Estonia is consecrated as the flag of the Estonian Students' Society.
January  – The Fabian Society is founded in London to promote gradualist social progress.
June  – LaMarcus Adna Thompson opens the "Gravity Pleasure Switchback Railway" at Coney Island, New York City.
February  – Derby County Football Club is founded in England.
The union of Eastern Rumelia with Bulgaria is proclaimed at Plovdiv.
The Home Insurance Building in Chicago, designed by William Le Baron Jenney, is completed. With ten floors and a fireproof weight-bearing metal frame, it is regarded as the first skyscraper.
July  – The Reservation at Niagara Falls opens, enabling access to all for free. Thomas V. Welch is the first Superintendent of the Park.
August  – S Andromedae, the only supernova seen in the Andromeda Galaxy so far by astronomers, and the first ever noted outside the Milky Way, is discovered.

October  – The largest ever explosion for a non-military purpose is set off in the East River of New York City as part of a scheme for the removal of Hell Gate rocks by the United States Army Corps of Engineers.
May  – American pharmacist Dr. John Pemberton invents a carbonated beverage that will be named 'Coca-Cola'.
May  – A general strike begins in the United States, which escalates on May  into the Haymarket affair in Chicago, and eventually wins the eight-hour day for workers.
March  – A law establishing the Kiel Canal is adopted in the German Empire.
Johnson & Johnson, which becomes a multinational brand, begins manufacturing healthcare products in New Jersey, United States.
August  – A massive hurricane demolishes the town of Indianola, Texas.
July  – Odense Boldklub, the Danish football team, is founded as the Odense Cricket Club.
British emigrant ship Kapunda sinks after a collision off the coast of Brazil, killing  with only  survivors.
January  – Louis Pasteur's anti-rabies treatment is defended in the Académie Nationale de Médecine, by Dr. Joseph Grancher.
American financial services company A. G. Edwards is founded by General Albert Gallatin Edwards in St. Louis, Missouri.

July 
L. L. Zamenhof publishes "Unua Libro" (Dr. Esperanto's International Language), the first description of Esperanto, the constructed international auxiliary language.
Blackpool F.C. is created in England, U.K.
Stanley Park is officially opened by Vancouver (B.C.) mayor David Oppenheimer.
June  – The Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom opens its laboratory, on Plymouth Hoe.
March  – The Great Blizzard of  begins along the East Coast of the United States, shutting down commerce and killing more than .
April  – Kahisakan (可否茶館), the first coffee shop in Japan, opens in Tokyo.
May  – In Glasgow (Scotland), Celtic F.C. plays its first official match, winning – against Rangers F.C.
August  – The Royal Mail Mount Pleasant Sorting Office officially opens in London.
January  – The Coca-Cola Company is originally incorporated as the Pemberton Medicine Company in Atlanta, Georgia.
March  – Claiming to be the Promised Messiah and Mahdi, Mirza Ghulam Ahmad founds the Ahmadiyya Muslim community in Punjab Province (British India).
April – British chemists Frederick Abel and James Dewar file their first patent for the smokeless propellant cordite.
August  –  The Great Fire of Spokane, Washington, destroys some  blocks of the city, prompting a mass rebuilding project.
September  — President Wilford Woodruff of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints issues the  Manifesto ending the official practice of polygamy.
The Ouija board is first released by Elijah Bond.
September  – The University of North Texas is founded, as the Texas Normal College and Teacher Training Institute.
April  – At the First International Conference of American States, in Washington D.C., The Commercial Bureau of the American Republics is founded.
November  – Edward King, Anglican bishop of Lincoln, is convicted of using ritualistic practices.
March  – The London–Paris telephone system officially opens.
January –May  – The Jamaica International Exhibition is held.
The London–Paris telephone system is opened to the general public.

January 
General Nelson A. Miles' forces surround the Lakota in the Pine Ridge Reservation.
The Inter-American Monetary Commission meets in Washington, D.C.
St. Mary's Cathedral is dedicated in San Francisco.
Diplomat Henry Galway secures a treaty by which Ovonramwen, Oba of Benin, ostensibly accepts British protection for his kingdom.
July  – Queen Victoria meets with Martha Ann Ricks.
February  – Rudolf Diesel applies for a patent, on his compression ignition engine (the Diesel engine).
July  – A hidden lake bursts out of a glacier on the side of Mont Blanc, flooding the valley below and killing around  villagers and holidaymakers in Saint-Gervais-les-Bains.

March  – The first basketball game is played in public, between students and faculty at the Springfield YMCA before  spectators. The final score is – in favor of the students, with the only goal for the faculty being scored by Amos Alonzo Stagg.
Belgian general strike of : Riots erupt in Mons; the day after, the Belgian Parliament approves universal male suffrage.

December
Mark Twain's Pudd'nhead Wilson begins serialization in The Century Magazine (U.S.)
Carl Anton Larsen becomes the first man to ski in Antarctica.

October  – A devastating levee collapse, flash flood and landslide hit and damage around Kyushu Island, Shikoku Island and western Honshū in Japan, due to a strong typhoon wind; an official document reports that , people perish.
March  – The Liverpool Overhead Railway opens with -car electric multiple units, the first to operate in the world.

January 
The Independent Labour Party of the United Kingdom has its first meeting.
U.S. Marines from the USS Boston land in Honolulu, Hawaii, to prevent the queen from abrogating the Bayonet Constitution.
July  – The Paris–Rouen Competition for Horseless Carriages, the first automobile competition, is held.
October  – Domenico Menegatti obtains a patent for a procedure to be applied in producing pandoro industrially.

July 
The short-lived Republic of Hawaii is proclaimed by Sanford B. Dole.
The football club FC La Chaux-de-Fonds is founded in Switzerland.
The May Day Riots (against unemployment) break out in Cleveland, Ohio.
July  – A fire at the site of the  World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago destroys most of the remaining buildings.
April  – Gongche Shangshu movement:  candidates sign a ,-word petition against the Treaty of Shimonoseki.
August  – American frontier murderer and outlaw John Wesley Hardin is killed by an off-duty policeman in a saloon in El Paso, Texas.
August  – The first ever indoor promenade concert, origin of The Proms, is held at the Queen's Hall in London, opening a series conducted by Henry Wood.

January  – The sinking of the German ocean liner SS Elbe kills  people on board,  minutes after the ship had collided with the British steamer SS Crathie in the North Sea. Only two lifeboats are able to evacuate before the Elbe goes down, and the first lifeboat capsizes when too many passengers attempt to get onboard. A second lifeboat, with  members of the crew, four men and a woman, carries the only survivors.
The Paris–Bordeaux–Paris automobile trial is held.
The shortest war in recorded history, the Anglo-Zanzibar War, starts at : in the morning, and lasts for  minutes of shelling.
September  – Pathé Frères, a French film company and one of the oldest film companies, is founded by the brothers Charles Pathé, Théophile Pathé, Émile Pathé and Jacques Pathé.

July  – Atlantic City rail crash: Shortly after : pm, at a crossing just west of Atlantic City, New Jersey, two trains collide, crushing five loaded passenger coaches, killing  and seriously injuring approximately sixty.
September  – Clarkson University holds its first classes, with  students attending in Potsdam, New York.
August  – The Park Seung-jik shop, predecessor of South Korean conglomerate Doosan Group, is founded in Joseon (the kingdom of Korea).

May  – Irish-born theatrical manager Bram Stoker's contemporary Gothic horror novel Dracula is first published (in London); it will influence the direction of vampire literature for the following century.
July  – S. A. Andrée's Arctic Balloon Expedition of  begins. The ill-fated expedition to fly over the Arctic results in the death of the entire team within months.
The comic strip The Katzenjammer Kids debuts in the New York Journal.
January  – A cyclone destroys Darwin, Australia.

May  – On Decoration Day (later Memorial Day) the Robert Gould Shaw Memorial is dedicated in Boston. The bronze bas relief by Augustus St. Gaudens depicts the 54th Massachusetts Infantry Regiment of black Civil War soldiers.
December  – The Republic of Nicaragua issues a decree announcing its return to sovereignty as a separate nation after its union with El Salvador and Honduras collapses.
October  – The Sinfonia Club, later to become the Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia fraternity, is founded at the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston by Ossian Everett Mills.
April  – An explosion in Santa Cruz, California, kills  workers, at the California Powder Works.
June  – William Ramsay and Morris Travers discover neon at their laboratory at University College London, after extracting it from liquid nitrogen.
American adventurer Joshua Slocum completes a -year solo circumnavigation of the world.
January  – The leaders of six Australian colonies meet in Melbourne, to discuss the confederation of Australia as a whole.
March  – The cabinet of Spain's Prime Minister Silvestri approves the ratification of the treaty to end the Spanish–American War. The Queen Regent of Spain signs the treaty two days later.
The natural gas companies of New York City cut prices by % from $. to  cents per , cubic feet.

In Samoa, followers of Mataafa, claimant to the rule of the island's subjects, burn the town of Upolu in an ambush of followers of other claimants, Malietoa Tanus and Tamasese, who are evacuated by the British warship HMS Porpoise.
March  – The Frankfurter Fußball-Club Victoria von  (predecessor of Eintracht Frankfurt) is founded.
The U.S. Senate accepts the British-German Treaty of , in which the United Kingdom renounces its claims to the American Samoa portion of the Samoan Islands.
September  – The  Galveston hurricane, killing around , people. It is the deadliest hurricane in U.S. history.

November  –  Canadian federal election: Liberal incumbent Sir Wilfrid Laurier is reelected by defeating Conservative leader Sir Charles Tupper again after having done that in the  Canadian federal election.
June  – Second Boer War: British soldiers take Pretoria.
July  – Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria makes a morganatic marriage with Sophie, Duchess of Hohenberg.
: Shamshi-Adad I conquers Assur and emerges as the first Amorite king of Assyria.
: Senusret III inspects the Nubian frontier, he leads four punitive campaigns against the Nubians.
: Senwosret III (Twelfth Dynasty) died.
: Amenemhat III starts to rule
: Late Harappan phase of the Indus Valley civilization begins
June  – British peace campaigner Emily Hobhouse reports on the high mortality and cruel conditions in the Second Boer War concentration camps.

January  – Lord Kitchener reports that Christiaan de Wet has shot one of the "peace" envoys, and flogged two more, who had gone to his commando to ask the Burgher citizens of South Africa to halt fighting.
A . Mw Black Sea earthquake occurs off the northeast coast of Bulgaria, with a maximum intensity of X (Extreme). A destructive tsunami affects the province of Dobrich.

January 
The British colonies of New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria and Western Australia federate as the Commonwealth of Australia; Edmund Barton becomes the first Prime Minister of Australia.
Nigeria becomes a British protectorate.

February 
Chi-hsui and Hsu-cheng-yu, Boxer Rebellion leaders, are executed in Peking.
The Middelburg peace conference fails in South Africa, as Boers continue to demand autonomy.
April  – A new land speed record of  mph ( km/h) is set in Nice, France, by Léon Serpollet driving a steam car.
May  – The London School of Economics is opened by Lord Rosebery.
St Mark's Campanile in Venice collapses.
December  – Newfoundland - Guglielmo Marconi sends messages across Atlantic wireless
May  – Mount Pelée in Martinique erupts, destroying the town of Saint-Pierre and killing over ,.
July –August  (July –August , O.S.) – The Second Congress of the All-Russian Social Democratic Labour Party is held in exile in Brussels, transferring to London.

February  – Venezuelan crisis: After agreeing to arbitration in Washington, the United Kingdom, Germany and Italy reach a settlement with Venezuela resulting in the Washington Protocols. The naval blockade that began in  ends.
September – Texas State University in San Marcos, Texas opens as Southwest Texas Normal School.
December  – The National Association for Women's Suffrage (Sweden) is founded.
December  – The Iroquois Theatre fire in Chicago kills .

The original "Bloomsday", the day James Joyce first walks out with his future wife Nora Barnacle (whom he first met on June ), to the Dublin suburb of Ringsend. He sets the action of his novel Ulysses () on this date.
October  – The first underground line of the New York City Subway opens.
October  – Theta Tau, a professional engineering fraternity, is founded at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis.
November  –  United States presidential election: Republican incumbent Theodore Roosevelt defeats Democrat Alton B. Parker.
June  – A fire aboard the steamboat General Slocum in New York City's East River kills ,.
Da-Qing Bank, predecessor of Bank of China, is founded in Peiping.

A Czech worker, František Pavlík, is bayoneted to death during a demonstration for a Czech university in Brno. This event is the motivation for a piano sonata, . X. , by Leoš Janáček, which premieres on  January .
January  – A series of three  metres ( ft) high tsunamis kill  people in Norway, after a rockslide sweeps down Mount Ramnefjell and crashes into Lake Lovatnet.
June  – The Lewis and Clark Centennial Exposition opens in Portland, Oregon.
September  – The millennia-old imperial examination system for the civil service is abolished in Qing dynasty China.

May 
The first inmates are moved to the Culion leper colony by the American Insular Government of the Philippine Islands.
Gustav Mahler's Symphony No.  receives its premiere at the Saalbau Essen in Germany conducted by the composer.
Aleutian Islands earthquake: An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of . occurs off the Rat Islands in Alaska.
October  – The Grand Duchy of Finland becomes the first nation to include the right of women to stand as candidates when it adopts universal suffrage.
March  – In France, Romanian inventor Traian Vuia becomes the first person to achieve an unassisted takeoff in a heavier-than-air powered monoplane, but it is incapable of sustained flight.
December  – The world's first feature film, The Story of the Kelly Gang, is first shown, at the Melbourne Athenaeum in Australia.
March  – The Prime Minister of Bulgaria, Dimitar Petkov, is assassinated by an anarchist in Sofia.
June  – Tiflis bank robbery: Bolsheviks attack a cash-filled bank coach in the centre of Tiflis, Georgia, killing  people.

March – – Elections to the new Parliament of Finland are the first in the world for a national assembly with woman candidates, as well as the first elections in Europe where universal suffrage is applied;  women are elected.
The Diamond Sūtra, a woodblock printed Buddhist scripture dated , is discovered by Aurel Stein in the Mogao Caves in China; it is "the earliest complete survival of a dated printed book".
October  – The Hague Convention is revised by the (second) Hague Peace Conference (effective  January ), focussing on naval warfare.

November  – Western bandits Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid are supposedly killed in Bolivia, after being surrounded by a large group of soldiers. There are many rumors to the contrary however, and their grave sites are unmarked.

November  – King Leopold II of Belgium formally relinquishes his personal control of the Congo Free State (becoming Belgian Congo) to Belgium, following evidence collected by Roger Casement of maladministration.
September  – Classes begin at Benjamin Franklin Institute of Technology in Boston, Massachusetts, established under the terms of Franklin's will.
July  – Feyenoord, the first Dutch football club to win the UEFA Champions League, is founded at Rotterdam, Netherlands
July  – SOS comes into force internationally as a distress signal (originally for ship-to-shore wireless telegraphy).
November  – In Nicaragua,  revolutionaries (including  Americans) are executed by order of dictator José Santos Zelaya. The United States responds by sending  warships.
July  – Blue Anchor Line passenger/cargo liner SS Waratah, on her second voyage from Australia to Britain, leaves Durban and is lost without trace with all  aboard.

December  – New South Wales Premier Charles Wade signs the Seat of Government Surrender Act , formally completing the transfer of State land to the Commonwealth, to create the Australian Capital Territory.

January  – The British Nimrod Expedition to the South Pole, led by Ernest Shackleton, arrives at the farthest south reached by any prior expedition, at °' S, prior to turning back due to diminishing supplies.
Karl Landsteiner, Constantin Levaditi and Erwin Popper first isolate the poliovirus.
A coal mine explosion at the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company in Primero, Colorado, kills  miners.
The Philadelphia Athletics defeat the Chicago Cubs, –, to win the  World Series in baseball in Game  (Jack Coombs has been the winning pitcher in three of the Athletics' four wins).
Infrared photographs are first published by Professor Robert Williams Wood, in the Royal Photographic Society's journal.
July – First Girl Guide troops registered in the United Kingdom, under the supervision of Agnes Baden-Powell.

March  – Progressive Republicans in the United States House of Representatives rebel against Speaker Joseph Gurney Cannon, removing him from the Rules Committee and stripping him of his power to appoint committee chairmen.
October  – China adopts "Cup of Solid Gold" as its first national anthem. However, it is never performed publicly and is replaced a few months later with a new composition.

December  – Amundsen and Scott expeditions: Roald Amundsen's Norwegian expedition reaches the geographical South Pole,  days ahead of Capt. Scott. News of Amundsen's success will not reach the outside world until next March.

April  – Huanghuagang Uprising: In China, rebels take five villages in an attempt to create a power base to fight Imperial rule; those who die are remembered as "The  Martyrs" (the event is also called the "Second Guangzhou Uprising" and the "Yellow Flower Mound Revolt").
November  – Chevrolet officially enters the automobile market in the United States, in competition with the Ford Model T.

January  – Amundsen and Scott expeditions: Roald Amundsen's Norwegian South Pole expedition arrives in the Antarctic and establishes a base camp at the Bay of Whales on the eastern edge of the Ross Ice Shelf.
January  – The First International Opium Convention is signed at The Hague to restrict exports.
March  (probable date) – Robert Falcon Scott and the remaining members of his South Pole expedition die.
January  – Raymond Poincaré forms a coalition government in France, beginning his first term of office as Prime Minister on  January.
October  – The First Balkan War begins: Montenegro declares war against the Ottoman Empire.
January  – The Republic of China is established.
Prada is established as a leather goods dealer in Milan, by Mario Prada and his brother.
America Cultural Center is inaugurated in Salta, Argentina.

Battle of Bud Bagsak: Armed with guns and heavy artillery, U.S. and Philippine troops under General John J. "Black Jack" Pershing fight a four-day battle against  Moro rebels, who are armed mostly with kampilan swords. The rebels are killed in a final desperate charge on June .
March  – King George I of Greece is assassinated after  years on the throne; he is succeeded by his son Constantine I.

October –December  – The Ford Motor Company adopts a moving assembly line for chassis production of the Model T at its Highland Park Plant in Highland Park, Michigan (Detroit), reducing assembly time from 12½ hours to  hours  minutes, a landmark in mass production. Between  and  the retail price of a Model T drops by US$.
September  – World War I: The first Battle of Albert begins as part of the Race to the Sea.
December  – World War I: An unofficial and temporary Christmas truce begins between British and German soldiers on the Western Front.
August – – Battle of Liège: The German Army overruns and defeats the Belgians with the first operational use of Big Bertha.
December  – Egypt becomes a British protectorate.

August 
German troops occupy Luxembourg, in accordance with the Schlieffen Plan.
A secret treaty between the Ottoman Empire and German Empires secures Ottoman neutrality.
At : (local time) Germany issues a -hour ultimatum to neutral Belgium, to allow German passage into France.

April  – WWI: Start of the Gallipoli Campaign by land forces (lasting until January ) – A landing at Anzac Cove is conducted by Australian and New Zealand Army Corps, and a landing at Cape Helles by British and French troops, to begin the Allied invasion of the Gallipoli peninsula in the Ottoman Empire.
April  – Armenian genocide: deportation of Armenian notables from Istanbul begins.
May  – International Congress of Women meets at the Hague as a major peace initiative.
January  – WWI: Battle of Dogger Bank – The British Grand Fleet defeats the German High Seas Fleet, sinking the armoured cruiser SMS Blücher.

WWI: South West Africa Campaign – The Union of South Africa occupies German South West Africa with assistance from Canada, the United Kingdom, the Portuguese Republic and Portuguese Angola. South Africa will occupy South West Africa until March .
March  – United States President Woodrow Wilson sends , United States troops over the U.S.–Mexico border to pursue Pancho Villa; the 13th Cavalry regiment enters Mexican territory.

February 
Emma Goldman is arrested for lecturing on birth control in the United States.
The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra presents its first concert in the United States.
The Romanian Association football club Sportul Studențesc is founded in Bucharest.
The first -hour work week officially begins, in the Endicott-Johnson factories of Western New York.
Germany declares war on Romania.
February  – WWI: Battle of Salaita Hill (East African Campaign) – South African and other British Empire troops fail to take a German East African defensive position.
The People's Dispensary for Sick Animals is founded in the United Kingdom.
Dallas Love Field Airport is opened in Texas.
April –May  – WWI: Battle of Arras – British Empire troops make a significant advance on the Western Front but are unable to achieve a breakthrough.
June  – King Constantine I of Greece abdicates for the first time, being succeeded by his son Alexander.
September  – WW1: On the Eastern Front, German troops enter Riga after a successful offensive against the city's Russian defenders.
February  – Deposed Sultan of the Ottoman Empire Abdul Hamid II dies in Istanbul.

March 
The Finnish Army Corps of Aviation is founded as a forerunner of the Finnish Air Force (established on  May ). The blue swastika is adopted as its symbol, as a tribute to the Swedish explorer and aviator Eric von Rosen, who donated the first plane. Von Rosen had painted the Viking symbol on the plane as his personal lucky insignia.
The first pilotless drone, the Hewitt-Sperry Automatic Airplane developed by Elmer Ambrose Sperry and Peter Cooper Hewitt, is test-flown in Long Island, New York, but development is scrapped in , after its guidance system proves unreliable.
Capture of Afulah and Beisan by the 4th Cavalry Division (British Indian Army);
November  – WWI: The Armistice of Villa Giusti comes into effect, ending warfare between Italy and Austria-Hungary on the Italian Front.
October  – WWI – Charge at Haritan: Units of the Desert Mounted Corps battle with Ottoman forces for the last time in WWI.
February – – Estonian War of Independence: Uniformed peasants in Saaremaa rebel against the government of Estonia; the rebellion is crushed by government forces, leaving more than  dead.
January – – Russian Civil War: The Red Army's Caspian-Caucasian Front begins the Northern Caucasus Operation against the White Army, but fails to make progress.
German federal election, first under the Weimar Republic and the first in Germany with female suffrage.

October  – Prohibition in the United States: The United States Congress passes the Volstead Act, over President Woodrow Wilson's veto. Prohibition goes into effect on January , , under the provisions of the Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

May 
Greek landing at Smyrna: The Hellenic Army lands at Smyrna assisted by ships of the British Royal Navy.
A law providing for full women's suffrage in the Netherlands is introduced.
Winnipeg general strike: Workers in Winnipeg, Canada, begin a strike for better wages and working conditions; the strike lasts for six weeks.
Estonian War of Independence: The Tartu Peace Treaty is signed, ending the war and recognizing the independence of both the Republic of Estonia and the Russian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic.
August  – Ottoman Sultan Mehmed VI's representatives sign the Treaty of Sèvres with the Allied Powers, confirming arrangements for the partitioning of the Ottoman Empire.

May 
French and Belgian troops leave the cities they have occupied in Germany.
The first flight of Dutch air company KLM, from Amsterdam to London, takes place.
March  – Admiral Miklós Horthy declares that Hungary is a monarchy, without anyone on the throne.
July  – Arthur Meighen becomes Canada's ninth prime minister.
May  – The Communist Party of Czechoslovakia is founded.
September  – White Castle hamburger restaurant opens in Wichita, Kansas, foundation of the world's first fast food chain.
December  – In the Four-Power Treaty on Insular Possessions, the Empire of Japan, United States, United Kingdom, and French Third Republic agree to recognize the status quo in the Pacific.
Rising prices cause major riots in Munich.
January  – The Marxist Left in Slovakia and the Transcarpathian Ukraine holds its founding congress in Ľubochňa.

August
Hyperinflation in Germany sees the value of the Papiermark against the dollar rise to ,.
The last hunted California grizzly bear is shot.
December  – Japanese aircraft carrier Hōshō becomes the first purpose-designed aircraft carrier to be commissioned.
A broadcast receiving licence with a fee of ten shillings is introduced in the United Kingdom.
October  – Greco-Turkish War of - ends in Turkish victory.
April  – South African Railways takes control of all railway operations in South West Africa.
September  – Struggling for a foothold in southern China, Sun Yat-sen decides to ally his Nationalist Kuomintang party with the Comintern and the Chinese Communist Party.

February  – Billy Hughes, having resigned as Prime Minister of Australia, after the Country Party refuses to govern in coalition with him as the leader of the Nationalist Party, is succeeded by Stanley Bruce. A Liberal–National Coalition will persist in the politics of Australia for at least  years.
August  – The first British Track & Field championships for women are held in London.

October  – In Germany, General Hans von Seeckt orders the Reichswehr to dissolve the Social Democratic-Communist government of Saxony, which is refusing to accept the authority of the Reich government.

April 
Hjalmar Branting leaves office as Prime Minister of Sweden, after the Swedish Riksdag has rejected a government proposal regarding unemployment benefits. Right-wing academic and jurist Ernst Trygger succeeds him.
The Egyptian Constitution of  is adopted, introducing a parliamentary system of democracy in the country.
October  – The first Surrealist Manifesto is published, in which André Breton defines the movement as "pure psychic automatism".
The International Union of Official Organizations for Tourist Propaganda is established.
Nellie Tayloe Ross of Wyoming is elected as the first woman governor in the United States.

December  – American astronomer Edwin Hubble announces that Andromeda, previously believed to be a nebula, is actually another galaxy, and that the Milky Way is only one of many such galaxies in the universe.
October  – The Geneva Protocol is adopted by the League of Nations Assembly as a means to strengthen the League, but later fails to be ratified.

August  – Anthropologist Margaret Mead lands in American Samoa to begin nine months of field work that will culminate in her  book Coming of Age in Samoa. The bestselling book will become the first popular anthropological study and will change many attitudes towards tribal peoples.
January  – The Syrian Federation is officially dissolved, the State of Aleppo and the State of Damascus having been replaced by the State of Syria.

November 
 Australian federal election: Stanley Bruce's Nationalist/Country Coalition Government is re-elected with an increased majority, defeating the Labor Party led by Matthew Charlton.
The first Surrealist art exhibition opens in Paris.

June  – The . Mw  Santa Barbara earthquake affects the central coast of California with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent), destroying much of downtown Santa Barbara, California and leaving  people dead.
May  – African-American Tom Lee rescues  people from the sinking steamboat M.E. Norman on the Mississippi River.
April  – Treaty of Berlin: Germany and the Soviet Union each pledge neutrality in the event of an attack on the other by a third party, for the next five years.
April  – Reza Khan is crowned Shah of Iran, under the name "Pahlevi".
May  – The United States Congress passes the Air Commerce Act, licensing pilots and planes.
October  – The  Imperial Conference opens in London.
December  – British prime minister Stanley Baldwin ends the state of emergency that had been declared due to the miners' strike.

August  – Paul Redfern leaves Brunswick, Georgia, flying his Stinson Detroiter "Port of Brunswick", to attempt a solo nonstop flight to Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. He later crashes in the Venezuelan jungle, but the crash site is never found.
July  (Wednesday, Tamuz , ): : – Rebbe Yosef Yitzchak Schneersohn is freed from the imprisonment which began on June  (Wednesday, Sivan , ) at : in exile, in the Russian town of Kostroma.
October – Niels Bohr presents his theoretical principle of complementarity at the Fifth Solvay Conference on Physics.
December  – Gamma Sigma Fraternity becomes the first high school fraternity to become international with Alpha Zeta chapter in Niagara Falls, Ontario, Canada.
May  – Bath School disaster: A series of violent attacks by a school official results in  deaths, mostly of children, in Bath Township, Michigan, United States.
February  – Scottish-born inventor John Logie Baird broadcasts a transatlantic television signal from London to Hartsdale, New York.
October  – Haile Selassie is crowned king (not yet emperor) of Abyssinia.

October 
Josemaría Escrivá founds Opus Dei.
Arvid Lindman returns as Prime Minister of Sweden, with his right-wing rival Ernst Trygger as Foreign Minister of Sweden.
October  – The Phi Sigma Alpha fraternity is founded at the University of Puerto Rico, Río Piedras Campus.
September  – The Okeechobee hurricane hits Guadeloupe, killing , people.
September  – Aristide Briand presents his plan for the United States of Europe.

January 
 January Dictatorship: King Alexander of the Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes suspends his country's constitution.
Albanian missionary sister Agnes Gonxha Bojaxhiu, later known as Mother Teresa, arrives in Calcutta from Ireland to begin her work in India.
January Dictatorship: King Alexander of the Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes suspends his country's constitution.
September  – A coup ousts Augustinas Voldemaras from his prime minister position in Lithuania; he is replaced by the brother-in-law of President Antanas Smetona, Juozas Tūbelis.
February  – "Saint Valentine's Day Massacre": Five gangsters (rivals of Al Capone), plus a civilian, are shot dead in Chicago.
October – The Indochinese Communist Party is formed.

November 
An earthquake in the Izu Peninsula of Japan kills  people and destroys  buildings.
Cecil George Paine, a pathologist at the Sheffield Royal Infirmary in England, achieves the first recorded cure (of an eye infection) using penicillin.
The International Left Opposition (ILO) is founded in Paris, France.
Cecil George Paine, a pathologist at the Sheffield Royal Infirmary in England, achieves the first recorded cure (of an eye infection) using penicillin.
September  –  Argentine coup d'état: José Félix Uriburu carries out a military coup, overthrowing Hipólito Yrigoyen, President of Argentina.

April  – After the negotiations between the republican ministers of Spain and Catalonia, the Catalan Republic becomes the Generalitat of Catalonia, a Catalan autonomous government inside the Spanish Republic.
March  – Indian revolutionary leaders Bhagat Singh, Shivaram Rajguru and Sukhdev Thapar are hanged for conspiracy to murder in the British Raj.
The Panama Canal is closed for a couple of weeks, due to damage caused by earthquakes.
July  – The rebuilt Milano Centrale railway station officially opens in Italy.
January  – German pilot Elly Beinhorn begins her flight to Africa.
November  – Buck Rogers in the  debuts on American radio. It is the first science fiction program on radio.

February  – League of Blood Incident: Junnosuke Inoue, prominent Japanese businessman, banker and former governor of the Bank of Japan is assassinated by the right-wing extremist group the League of Blood.

May 
There are violent scenes in the German Reichstag building in Berlin as Hermann Göring and other Nazi MRDs attack the Defense Minister General Wilhelm Groener for his lack of belief in a supposed Social Democratic putsch. After the debate, General Schleicher tells Groener that he has lost the confidence of the Army and must resign at once.
Albert Lebrun becomes the new president of France.
James Chadwick, working at the Cavendish Laboratory in the University of Cambridge, reports the existence of the neutron.

July 
Norway annexes northern Greenland.
Hedley Verity establishes a new first-class cricket record by taking all ten wickets for only ten runs against Nottinghamshire on a pitch affected by a storm.
March  – Éamon de Valera is elected President of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State, the first change of government in the country since its foundation  years previously.
April  – In Germany, the Law for the Restoration of the Professional Civil Service is passed, the first law of the new regime directed against Jews (as well as political opponents).
June  – The U.S. Congress abrogates the United States use of the gold standard, by enacting a joint resolution nullifying the right of creditors to demand payment in gold.
April  – American airship Akron crashes off the coast of New Jersey, killing  of its  crewmen. It is the worst aviation accident in history up to this date (and until ).
March  –  Sanriku earthquake: A powerful earthquake and tsunami hit Honshū, Japan, killing approximately , people.

Montevideo Convention on the Rights and Duties of States is signed by participants in the 7th International Conference of American States; it is significant in the development of the declarative theory of statehood.
The sonoluminescence effect is discovered, at the University of Cologne.
July  – The Hays Code begins to be strictly enforced in the Hollywood film industry, lasting until .
February  – King Leopold III of Belgium succeeds to the throne, following the death (February ) of his father King Albert I.
March  – Manchukuo, the Japanese puppet state in Manchuria established in , proclaimed a monarchy under Puyi.
June  – The Nazi Party SA camp Oranienburg becomes a national camp, taken over by the Schutzstaffel (SS).
June  – The Chaco War between Paraguay and Bolivia ends.
October  – Grant v Australian Knitting Mills, a landmark case in consumer law, is decided on appeal in the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in the U.K.

September 
U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt dedicates the Hoover Dam.
The London and North Eastern Railway commences the Silver Jubilee, Britain's first streamline train service.
September  – The Nuremberg Laws go into effect in Germany, removing citizenship from Jews.

April  – Dust Bowl: "Black Sunday", the great dust storm in the United States hits eastern New Mexico and Colorado, and western Oklahoma the hardest (it will be made famous by Woody Guthrie, in his "dust bowl ballads").
November  – Cover date of the first issue of Life, a weekly news magazine launched in the United States under the management of Henry Luce.
September – – English-born aviator Beryl Markham becomes the first woman to make an east-to-west solo transatlantic flight, from Abingdon-on-Thames, England, to Baleine, Nova Scotia.
December  – Xi'an Incident: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China is kidnapped by Marshal Zhang Xueliang.

Taking the opportunity to free itself further from ties to the United Kingdom, the Oireachtas of the Irish Free State passes the Constitution (Amendment No. ) Act , removing most powers from the office of Governor-General of the Irish Free State, and the Executive Authority (External Relations) Act  (signed into law December ), assenting to the abdication and restricting the power of the monarch in relation to Ireland to international affairs.
March  – Pro-democratic militarist Keisuke Okada steps down as Prime Minister of Japan and is replaced by radical militarist Kōki Hirota.
The Vibora Luviminda sugar plantation trade unions strike on Maui island, Hawaii.
Roberto Ortiz is elected president of Argentina.
February  – Spanish Civil War: Falangist troops take Málaga.
August  – The Polish Operation of the NKVD (–) is signed by Nikolai Yezhov as a continuation of the Great Purge.
August  – Spanish Civil War: Falangist artillery bombards Madrid.

September 
Sir Eric Phipps, British Ambassador to France, reports to London, "all that is best in France is against war, almost at any price", being opposed only by a "small, but noisy and corrupt, war group". Phipps's report creates major doubts about the ability and willingness of France to go to war.
At : AM, Adolf Hitler and Neville Chamberlain conclude their talks on the Sudetenland. Chamberlain agrees to take Hitler's demands, codified in the Godesberg Memorandum, personally to the Czech Government. The Czech Government rejects the demands, as does Chamberlain's own cabinet. The French Government also initially rejects the terms and orders a partial mobilization of the French army.

February 
Carol II of Romania takes dictatorial powers.
Second Sino-Japanese War: Bombing of Chongqing begins.
March  – Poland presents an ultimatum to Lithuania, to establish normal diplomatic relations that were severed over the Vilnius Region.
Edvard Beneš, president of Czechoslovakia, resigns.

September 
During a meeting between Neville Chamberlain, the recently elected Premier of France, Édouard Daladier, and Daladier's Foreign Minister, Georges Bonnet, it becomes apparent that neither the British nor the French governments are prepared to go to war over the Sudetenland. The Soviet Union declares it will come to the defence of Czechoslovakia only if France honours her commitment to defend Czechoslovak independence.
Mussolini makes a speech in Trieste, Italy, where he indicates that Italy is supporting Germany in the Sudeten crisis.

October 
WWII: Germany annexes Western Poland.
The Holocaust: Piotrków Trybunalski Ghetto, the first Jewish ghetto in Nazi-occupied Europe, is proclaimed in German-occupied Poland.
Following the invasion of Poland, the Free City of Danzig (modern-day Gdańsk, Poland) is annexed to Nazi Germany.
Hedda Hopper's Hollywood debuts on radio in the United States with gossip columnist Hedda Hopper as host (the show runs until , making Hopper a powerful figure among the Hollywood elite).

January 
Coming into effect in Nazi Germany of:
The Protection of Young Persons Act, passed on April , , the Working Hours Regulations.
The small businesses obligation to maintain adequate accounting.
The Jews name change decree.
With his traditional call to the New Year in Nazi Germany, Führer and Reich Chancellor Adolf Hitler addresses the members of the National Socialist German Workers' Party (NSDAP).
The Hewlett-Packard technology and scientific instruments manufacturing company is founded by Bill Hewlett and David Packard, in a garage in Palo Alto, California, considered the birthplace of Silicon Valley.
Philipp Etter takes over as President of the Swiss Confederation.
The Third Soviet Five Year Plan is launched.
September  – WWII: South Africa declares war on Germany.
British film stars Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh are married at the San Ysidro Ranch in California.

April  – WWII: Germany invades the neutral countries of Denmark and Norway in Operation Weserübung, opening the Norwegian campaign. The British Royal Navy attempts to attack elements of the German fleet off Norway. Vidkun Quisling proclaims a new collaborationist regime in Norway. The German invasion of Denmark lasts for about six hours, before that country capitulates.

December  – WWII: German auxiliary cruiser Komet shells and heavily damages the phosphate production facilities on the Pacific island of Nauru (under Australian protection at this time) while flying the Japanese flag. The bombardment lasts an hour and causes the loss of , tons of oil.
WWII: The Blitz – Nazi Germany begins to rain bombs on London (the first of  consecutive nights of strategic bombing).

December  – The German cruiser Admiral Hipper attacks a British shipping convoy (WS 5A) en route to Sierra Leone  miles (, km) west of Cape Finisterre in Spain. Admiral Hipper sinks one ship but has to withdraw with engine trouble.
January  – WWII: British troops attack Italian-held Eritrea in Africa.
The United States seizes the French liner SS Normandie.
A group of young men stop traffic on U.S. Highway  south of Yreka, California, handing out fliers proclaiming the establishment of the State of Jefferson.

WWII: The Government of National Salvation, a Serb puppet state of the Axis powers, is established by General Milan Nedić in Nazi-occupied Serbia in Belgrade, under military commander Heinrich Danckelmann; the regime includes  Ministers.
German forces capture Riga.
September  – WWII: A Japanese floatplane drops incendiary devices at Mount Emily, near Brookings, Oregon, in the first of two "Lookout Air Raids", the first bombing of the continental United States.
September  – WWII: The RMS Laconia, carrying civilians, Allied soldiers, and Italian prisoners of war, is torpedoed off the coast of West Africa and sinks, killing , people.

February  – WWII:
Japanese occupation of Singapore: Sook Ching – Japanese forces begin the systematic extermination of perceived hostile elements among Chinese Singaporeans.
More than  American sailors die in Newfoundland when USS Truxtun runs aground near Chambers Cove and USS Pollux runs aground at Lawn Point.
May  – The first African-American seamen are taken into the United States Navy.
WWII: Battle of Singapore: Japanese forces of the 5th Division and 18th Division (some , men) begin to cross the Johor Strait and attack the Australian 22nd Brigade (some , men) at Singapore.
The Order of Bogdan Khmelnitsky is instituted in the Soviet Union.
March  – WWII: British submarine HMS Thunderbolt is sunk off Sicily by an Italian corvette, the second time this vessel has been lost with all hands.
March – – WWII: North Atlantic convoy SC  is attacked by U-boats sinking seven ships.

November – – The Holocaust: Aktion Erntefest ("Operation Harvest Festival") – The largest single day massacre of Jews in the entire war takes place when over , Jews are murdered by the SS, the Ordnungspolizei and the "Trawniki men" in Sonderdienst formations at the Majdanek, Trawniki and Poniatowa concentration camps in the General Government territory of occupied Poland.
July  – Benito Mussolini, Fascist Prime Minister of Italy since , is arrested after the Grand Council of Fascism withdraws its support. "Il Duce" is replaced by General Pietro Badoglio.
Battle of Leyte Gulf: The Japanese battleship Musashi is sunk by United States aircraft.
, drown when British submarine HMS Sportsman torpedoes German-captured Petrella carrying Italian prisoners of war.
September  – WWII: Allied forces from Operation Overlord (in northern France) and Operation Dragoon (in the south) link up near Dijon.
July–October – WWII: Germans are driven out of Lithuania leading to reimposition of the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic.
May  – WWII: Battle of Wakde: American forces of the 163rd Regimental Combat Team (some , men) under Brigadier General Jens Doe take the Japanese-held Wakde island (Dutch New Guinea).
February  – WWII: German troopship SS General von Steuben is sunk by the Soviet submarine S-; , drown.
The Trinity Test, the first of an atomic bomb, using about six kilograms of plutonium, succeeds in unleashing an explosion equivalent to that of  kilotons of TNT.
March – – WWII: The Soviet Red Army carries out the Upper Silesian Offensive.
The Batu Lintang camp in Sarawak, Borneo is liberated by Australian forces.
Chenogne massacre: German prisoners are allegedly killed by American forces near the village of Chenogne, Belgium.
January  – The United Nations Security Council holds its first session, at Church House, Westminster in London.

December 
The United Nations severs relations with Francoist Spain and recommends that member countries sever diplomatic relations.
Léon Blum founds a government of socialist parties in France.
Iran crisis of : Iranian troops recapture the Azerbaijan province.
The Chinese Civil War intensifies between the Kuomintang and the Chinese Communist Party.
January  – Enver Hoxha declares the People's Republic of Albania, with himself as prime minister.
June  – Interpol is re-founded; the telegraphic address "Interpol" is adopted.
The U.S. Army Ordnance Corps Hermes program V- rocket Blossom I is launched into space, carrying plant material and fruitflies, the first living things to enter space.

April 
Multiple tornadoes strike Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas, killing  and injuring .
The Journey of Reconciliation in the Southern United States begins, organized by the Congress of Racial Equality.

July  – Cold War: U.S. President Harry S. Truman signs the National Security Act of  into law to create the Central Intelligence Agency, the Department of Defense, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the National Security Council.
An explosion at the O'Connor Electro-Plating Company in Los Angeles leaves  dead,  buildings damaged, and a -foot-deep (. m) crater in the ground.
The new Pakistan Army and Pashtun mercenaries overrun Mirpur in Kashmir, resulting in the death of , Hindus and Sikhs.
June  – The Palomar Observatory telescope is finished in California.
April  – The Finno-Soviet Treaty is signed in Moscow.
February  – The United States stock car racing organization NASCAR is founded by Bill France Sr. with other drivers.
April  – – Civil War in Mandatory Palestine: Haganah launches Operation Nachshon, provoking the  Palestinian expulsion and flight.

October  –  Arab–Israeli War: Massacres of Palestinian Arab villagers by the Israel Defense Forces:
Al-Dawayima massacre: Between  and  are killed.
Safsaf massacre: At least  are killed.
June  – Thailand elects Orapin Chaiyakan, the first Thai female member of Thailand's Parliament.

Second Red Scare in the United States: Celebrities including Helen Keller, Dorothy Parker, Danny Kaye, Fredric March, John Garfield, Paul Muni and Edward G. Robinson are named as Communist Party members in a Federal Bureau of Investigation report.

December  – The Treaty of The Hague ends the Indonesian National Revolution by recognizing transfer of the sovereignty of the Dutch East Indies from Queen Juliana of the Netherlands to the United States of Indonesia; the Susanto Cabinet takes office in the Republic of Indonesia.
February  – António Óscar Carmona is re-elected president of Portugal, for lack of an opposing candidate.
Retreat of the government of the Republic of China to Taiwan finishes, and it declares Taipei its temporary capital city, a status it will retain more than  years later.
June  – The Korean War begins: Troops and T- tanks of the North Korean People's Army cross the 38th parallel into South Korea.
Apartheid: In South Africa, the Group Areas Act is passed, formally segregating the races.

January  – Cold War: Klaus Fuchs, German émigré physicist, confesses to a British MI5 interrogator that he is a Soviet spy: for seven years, he passed top secret data on U.S. and British nuclear weapons research to the Soviet Union. Fuchs is formally charged on February .
September  – Rede Tupi, the first television broadcast network in South America, is founded in Brazil.
Bodo League massacre begins: South Korean armed forces and police summarily execute at least , suspected North Korean sympathizers.
April  – Sakuragichō train fire: in Yokohama, Japan, a fire on a train kills more than .
February  – Jean Lee becomes the last woman hanged in Australia, when she and her two pimps are hanged for the murder and torture of a -year-old bookmaker.
March  – The trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg for conspiracy to commit espionage begins in the United States.
The 23rd Academy Awards Ceremony is held; All About Eve wins the Best Picture award and five others.
May  – Operation Greenhouse: The first thermonuclear weapon is tested in the "George" test on Enewetok Atoll in the Marshall Islands by the United States.
February – – The Winter Olympics are held in Oslo, Norway.

April 
Bolivia National Revolution: A universal vote enables indigenous peoples and women to vote, nationalizes mines and enacts agrarian reform.
West Germany and Japan form diplomatic relations.
West Ice accidents: During a severe storm in the West Ice, east of Greenland,  seal hunters on  Norwegian seal hunting vessels vanish without a trace.
February  – Greece and Turkey join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

April 
Battle of Nanri Island: The Republic of China seizes the island from the People's Republic of China.
Bolivian National Revolution: Rebels take over Palacio Quemado.
Fearing communist influence in British Guiana, the British Government suspends the constitution, declares a state of emergency, and militarily occupies the colony.
July  – The first ascent of Nanga Parbat in the Pakistan Himalayas, the world's ninth highest mountain, is made by Austrian climber Hermann Buhl alone on a German–Austrian expedition.
July  – The greatest recorded loss of United States midshipmen in a single event results from an aircraft crash near NAS Whiting Field.
West German federal election, : Konrad Adenauer is re-elected as German chancellor.

June 
Egypt declares itself a republic.
Tachikawa air disaster: A United States Air Force Douglas C- Globemaster II crashes just after takeoff from Tachikawa Airfield near Tokyo, Japan, killing all  people on board in the worst air crash in history up to this time, and the first with a confirmed death toll exceeding .

March 
U.S. officials announce that a hydrogen bomb test (Castle Bravo) has been conducted, on Bikini Atoll in the Pacific Ocean.
U.S. Capitol shooting incident: Four Puerto Rican nationalists open fire in the United States House of Representatives chamber and wound ; they are apprehended by security guards.
January  – The Italian broadcaster RAI officially begins transmitting.
New Zealand engineer Sir William Hamilton develops the first pump-jet engine (the "Hamilton Jet") capable of propelling a jetboat.

July  – First Indochina War: The Geneva Conference sends French forces to the south, and Vietnamese forces to the north, of a ceasefire line, and calls for elections to decide the government for all of Vietnam by July . Failure to abide by the terms of the agreement leads to the establishment of the de facto regimes of North Vietnam and South Vietnam, and the Vietnam War.
Food rationing in Great Britain ends, with the lifting of restrictions on sale and purchase of meat,  years after it began early in World War II, and nearly a decade after the war's end.
June  – Le Mans disaster: Eighty-three people are killed and at least  are injured after two race cars collide in the   Hours of Le Mans.
December  – Adnan Menderes of DP forms the new government of Turkey (22nd government).
November  – The Rimutaka Tunnel opens on the New Zealand Railways, at . mi (. km), the longest in the Southern Hemisphere at this time.
July  – Ruth Ellis is hanged for murder in London, becoming the last woman ever to be executed in the United Kingdom.

Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of the United States, suffers a coronary thrombosis while on vacation in Denver, Colorado. Vice President Nixon assumed administrative duties and presided over Cabinet and National Security Council meetings while Eisenhower recovers.
British diver Lionel (Buster) Crabb (working for MI6) dives into Portsmouth Harbour, to investigate a visiting Soviet cruiser, and vanishes.
June  – Vyacheslav Molotov resigns as foreign minister of the Soviet Union; he later becomes ambassador to Mongolia.
June  – Gamal Abdel Nasser becomes the 2nd president of Egypt, a post he holds until his death in .
Khan Yunis massacre (Suez Crisis): Israeli soldiers shoot dead hundreds of Palestinian refugees and local inhabitants in Khan Yunis Camp.
April  – Spain relinquishes its protectorate in Morocco.
France prohibits U.N. involvement in Algeria.

July 
The 6th World Festival of Youth and Students, a high point of the Khrushchev Thaw, opens in Moscow.
Heavy rains and mudslides at Isahaya, western Kyūshū, Japan, kill .
Production of the Citroën Traction Avant automobile, begun in , ceases.
May  – May  incident: Anti-American riots erupt in Taipei, Taiwan.
The last person to be executed in New Zealand, Walter James Bolton, is hanged at Mount Eden Prison for poisoning his wife.

May  – Interviewed in the Chave d'Ouro café, when asked about his rival António de Oliveira Salazar, Humberto Delgado utters one of the most famous comments in Portuguese political history: "Obviamente, demito-o! (Obviously, I'll sack him!)".

December 
The United States launches SCORE, the world's first communications satellite.
The Bell XV- Tiltrotor makes the first true mid-air transition from vertical helicopter-type flight to fully level fixed-wing flight.

February  – Prestonsburg bus disaster: One of the worst school bus accidents in U.S. history occurs in Kentucky when a school bus hits a truck and falls into a river, resulting in  deaths,  of them schoolchildren. Twenty-two others are rescued.
Charles de Gaulle is brought out of retirement at Colombey-les-Deux-Églises to lead France by decree for  months.

March  –  Mars Bluff B- nuclear weapon loss incident: A U.S. B- bomber accidentally drops an atom bomb on Mars Bluff, South Carolina. Without a fissile warhead, its conventional explosives destroy a house and injure six people.
The Roseburg Blast in Oregon, caused when a truck carrying explosives catches fire, kills  and causes $ million worth of damage.

May – In the United Kingdom:
Import tariffs are lifted.
The first Ten Tors event is held on Dartmoor.
Import tariffs are lifted.
March  – The Tibetan uprising erupts in Lhasa when Chinese officials attempt to arrest the Dalai Lama.
April  – National People's Congress elects Liu Shaoqi as Chairman of the People's Republic of China, as a successor of Mao Zedong.
April  – Motown was incorporated as Motown Record Corporation.

Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev demands an apology from President Dwight D. Eisenhower for the U- reconnaissance plane flights over the Soviet Union, thus aborting their summit meeting scheduled for Paris this year.
The short-lived Mali Federation, consisting of the Sudanese Republic (modern-day Republic of Mali) and Senegal, gains independence from France.

March 
Vietnam War: The United States announces that , American soldiers will be sent to Vietnam.
The Canton of Geneva in Switzerland gives women the right to vote.

September 
 Summer Olympic Games: Muhammad Ali (at this time Cassius Clay) of the United States wins the gold medal in light-heavyweight boxing.
Congolese President Joseph Kasa-Vubu dismisses Patrice Lumumba's entire government, and also places Lumumba under house arrest.
Poet Léopold Sédar Senghor is the first elected President of Senegal.
October  – The first edition of Private Eye, the British satirical magazine, is published.
August  – The Six Flags Over Texas theme park officially opens to the public.
A second B- crashes near Yuba City, California, after cabin pressure is lost and the fuel runs out. Two nuclear weapons are found unexploded.
August  – An annular solar eclipse is visible from the Southern Ocean.
September  – During the F1 Italian Grand Prix on the circuit of Monza, German Wolfgang von Trips, driving a Ferrari, crashes into a stand, killing  spectators and himself.
February  – Urho Kekkonen is re-elected president of Finland.
November  – The  Bavarian state election is held.

July 
The first attack helicopter company, Utility Tactical Transport Helicopter Company, of the United States Army is formed on Okinawa Island, Japan.
The International Agreement on the Neutrality of Laos is signed in Geneva.

The first black student, James Meredith, registers at the University of Mississippi, escorted by Federal Marshals to protect him from official obstruction and violent segregationalist protest, the "Ole Miss riot of ".
The last execution by hanging is carried out in Canada.
David H. Frisch and J.H. Smith prove that the radioactive decay of mesons is slowed by their motion (see Einstein's special relativity and general relativity).
Construction company GK Međimurje, one of the largest Croatian construction and civil engineering companies (with more than , employees in 1980s), founded in Čakovec.
January  – France and West Germany sign the Élysée Treaty.
April  – Yugoslavia is proclaimed to be a socialist republic, and Josip Broz Tito is named President for Life.
December  – The Frankfurt Auschwitz Trials begin.
January  – General Nguyễn Khánh leads a bloodless military coup d'état, replacing Dương Văn Minh as Prime Minister of South Vietnam.
August  – The International Telecommunications Satellite Consortium (Intelsat) began to work.
July  – Ranger program: Ranger  sends back the first close-up photographs of the Moon (images are , times clearer than anything ever seen from Earth-bound telescopes).
April  – The Brazilian Congress elects Field Marshal Humberto de Alencar Castelo Branco as President of Brazil.
France performs an underground nuclear test at In Ecker, Algeria.
Ferdinand Marcos becomes President of the Philippines.
September  – Radio Peking announces that Indian troops have dismantled their equipment on the Chinese side of the border.
India opens two additional fronts against Pakistan.

October  – Ian Brady, a -year-old stock clerk from Hyde in Cheshire, is arrested for allegedly hacking to death (with a hatchet) -year-old apprentice electrician Edward Evans at a house on the Hattersley housing estate. He and his girlfriend Myra Hindley are subsequently identified as the perpetrators of the "Moors murders" of four young people aged from  to .

December 
The Second Vatican Council closes.
Rhodesian prime minister Ian Smith warns that Rhodesia will resist a trade embargo by neighboring countries with force.
The Race Relations Act becomes the first legislation to address racial discrimination in the UK.

Gemini  (Charles "Pete" Conrad Jr., Richard F. Gordon Jr) is launched from the United States. The crew performed the first direct-ascent (first orbit) rendezvous with an Agena Target Vehicle, docking with it.
The city of Montreal inaugurates the Montreal Metro system.
Joaquín Balaguer is elected president of the Dominican Republic.

December  – U.K. Prime Minister Harold Wilson withdraws all his previous offers to the Rhodesian government and announces that he will agree to independence for the country only after the establishment of a Black majority government there.
July  – In Chicago, United States, Richard Speck breaks into a nurses' dormitory and murders eight of the nine student nurses who live there.
June  –  million viewers watch Our World, the first live, international, satellite television production. It features the live debut of The Beatles' song "All You Need Is Love".
U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the Public Broadcasting Act of , establishing the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
November  – The first of its many UFO sightings is made at Pudasjärvi, Finland.

St Christopher's Hospice, the world's first purpose-built secular hospice specialising in palliative care of the terminally ill, is established in South London by Dame Cicely Saunders with the support of Albertine Winner.
New Zealand decimalises its currency from pound to dollar at £ to $ ($ = /-).

August  – The last steam passenger train service runs in Britain. A selection of British Rail steam locomotives make the -mile journey from Liverpool to Carlisle and return – the journey is known as the Fifteen Guinea Special.
South African Airways Flight  a Boeing  crashed shortly after take-off killing  people on board.

Late this evening, the U.K. government at the request of the U.S. agrees that the London Gold Pool will be closed from tomorrow. George Brown, the British Foreign Secretary, apparently drunk, is absent from meetings to discuss the crisis and is forced to resign from the government on March .
U.S. Senator Robert F. Kennedy enters the race for the Democratic Party presidential nomination.
February  – The television series Mister Rogers' Neighborhood premieres on National Educational Television in the United States and becomes one of the longest running children's shows ever.

May  – An American teenager known as 'Robert R.' dies in St. Louis, Missouri, United States, of a baffling medical condition. In  it will be identified as the earliest confirmed case of HIV/AIDS in North America.
Apollo program: Apollo  returns to Earth, after a successful -day test of all the components needed for the upcoming first crewed Moon landing.
June  – An international communist conference begins in Moscow.
International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage, a maritime treaty, is adopted.
September  – Ho Chi Minh, the president of Democratic Republic of Vietnam, died at the age of .

April  – Fragments of burnt human remains believed to be those of Adolf Hitler, Eva Braun, Joseph Goebbels, Magda Goebbels and the Goebbels children are crushed and scattered in the Biederitz river at a KGB center in Magdeburg, East Germany.
The Bolivian government releases Régis Debray.
January  – The . Mw Tonghai earthquake shakes Tonghai County, Yunnan province, China, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme). Between , and , are killed and , injured.
December  – An Egyptian delegation leaves for Moscow to ask for economic and military aid.
July  - Three Rivers Stadium opens in Pittsburgh Pennsylvania. Home to NFL Steelers and MLB Pirates.
September –October  – Japanese Emperor Hirohito travels abroad.
The first plane lands at Seychelles International Airport in Victoria, Seychelles (Mahe).
Vietnam War: The New York Times begins to publish the Pentagon Papers.

August  – A bomb made of two hand grenades by alleged communist rebels explodes in the Liberal Party campaign party in Plaza Miranda in Quiapo, Manila the Philippines, injuring several anti-Marcos political candidates.
May  – Mariner program: Mariner  is launched toward Mars.

March 
The 92nd U.S. Congress votes to send the proposed Equal Rights Amendment to the states for ratification.
Eisenstadt v. Baird: The Supreme Court of the U.S. rules that unmarried people have the right to access contraception on the same basis as married couples

December 
The . Mw Nicaragua earthquake kills ,–, people in the capital Managua. President Anastasio Somoza Debayle is later accused of not distributing millions of dollars worth of foreign aid.
Swedish Prime minister Olof Palme compares the American bombings of North Vietnam to Nazi massacres. The U.S. breaks diplomatic contact with Sweden.
Asker accident: Braathens SAFE Flight  crashes during approach to Oslo Airport, Fornebu, Norway; forty people on board are killed.

December 
Apollo  (Gene Cernan, Ronald Evans, Harrison Schmitt), the last crewed Moon mission for more than  years, is launched and The Blue Marble photograph of the Earth is taken. The mission also includes five mice.
Imelda Marcos, First Lady of the Philippines, is stabbed and seriously wounded by an assailant; her bodyguards shoot the assailant.
December  – Apollo program: Apollo  returns to Earth, concluding the program of lunar exploration.
October  – A coup in the Republic of Dahomey (later Benin) led by Mathieu Kérékou removes a civilian government (which has been headed by a triumvirate consisting of Ahomadégbé, Apithy and Maga).
July  – Varig Flight  crashes near Orly, France;  people are killed.
June  – The Ezeiza massacre occurs in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Snipers shoot at left-wing Peronists, killing at least  and injuring more than .
December  – Pioneer program: Pioneer  sends back the first close-up images of Jupiter.
February  – The Republic of Ireland general election is held. Liam Cosgrave becomes the new Taoiseach.

June 
Leonid Brezhnev addresses the American people on television, the first Soviet leader to do so.
UpStairs Lounge arson attack, an as-yet unsolved attack on a gay bar in New Orleans, Louisiana, in which  patrons are killed.

September 
Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia is deposed by the Derg, bringing an end to the Solomonic dynasty's rule since . The Ethiopian Civil War begins.
African Youth Amílcar Cabral is founded in Guinea-Bissau.
End of five-month oil embargo by most OPEC nations against the United States, Europe, and Japan which had caused the  oil crisis.
February  – Zamalek disaster: A soccer stampede occurs in Cairo, killing .
August  – A bomb explodes in a train between Italy and West Germany, killing twelve and wounding .

August 
An express train bound for Germany from Belgrade derails in Zagreb, Yugoslavia (now Croatia), killing more than  passengers.
The Mitsubishi Heavy Industries building in Tokyo is bombed by radical far-left terrorists, killing  and wounding more than .
May  – The South African government announces that it will provide all Black children with free and compulsory education.
May  – The Dibbles Bridge coach crash near Grassington, North Yorkshire, England, results in  deaths (the highest toll in a United Kingdom road accident).
A coup d'état in Chad led by the military overthrows and kills President François Tombalbaye.
April  – Taman Mini Indonesia Indah opens to the public in Jakarta, Indonesia.
September  – General Vasco Gonçalves is ousted as Prime Minister of Portugal.
April  – A violent F5 tornado strikes around Brownwood, Texas, injuring  people. Two people were thrown at least , yards ( m) by the tornado and survived uninjured.
November  –  Çaldıran–Muradiye earthquake: Between , and , are killed in a . Ms earthquake at Van and Muradiye in eastern Turkey.
August  – At Panmunjom, North Korea, two United States soldiers are killed while trying to chop down part of a tree in the Korean Demilitarized Zone which has obscured their view.
The  West Bank local elections were held.

Entebbe Raid: Israeli airborne commandos free  hostages being held by Palestinian hijackers of an Air France plane at Uganda's Entebbe Airport; Yonatan Netanyahu and several Ugandan soldiers are killed in the raid.
March  – Tenerife disaster: A collision between KLM and Pan Am Boeing 747s at Tenerife, Canary Islands, kills  people. This becomes the deadliest accident in aviation history.
Nazi war criminal Herbert Kappler escapes from the Caelian Hill military hospital in Rome.
February  – In northern Japan a blizzard piles snow on rooftops, causing many to collapse killing at least  people.
June  – A bloodless coup installs France-Albert René as President of the Seychelles.

The Big Ear, a radio telescope operated by Ohio State University as part of the SETI project, receives a radio signal from deep space; the event is named the Wow! signal for a notation made by a volunteer on the project.
Abortion is legalized in Italy for the first time.
Sarajevo is selected to host the  Winter Olympics, and Los Angeles is selected to host the  Summer Olympics.
