August  – The Treaty of Peace and Friendship between Japan and the People's Republic of China is concluded.
October  – Thorbjörn Fälldin steps down as Prime Minister of Sweden, and is succeeded by Ola Ullsten, the Leader of the liberal People's Party ("Folkpartiet").
September  – PSA Flight , a Boeing , collides with a small private airplane and crashes in San Diego, California;  are killed.
The United States dollar exchange rate with the Deutsche Mark falls to . DM, the all-time low so far; this record is not broken until November , .
Nazi criminal Josef Mengele suffers a fatal stroke and drowns while swimming in Bertioga, Brazil. His remains are found in .
The Sugarhill Gang release Rapper's Delight in the United States, the first rap single to become a Top  hit on the Billboard Hot .
The first black-led government of Rhodesia in  years takes power, in succession to Ian Smith and under his power-sharing deal, in the unrecognized republic of Zimbabwe Rhodesia.
July  – A car bomb destroys a Renault owned by Nazi hunters Serge and Beate Klarsfeld at their home in France. A note purportedly from ODESSA claims responsibility.

October 
The Elisabeth blast furnace is demolished at Bilston Steelworks, marking the end of iron and steel production in the Black Country region of the U.K.
British Leyland launches its new Metro, a three-door entry-level hatchback which is designed as the eventual replacement for the Mini. It gives BL a long-awaited modern competitor for the likes of the Ford Fiesta and Vauxhall Chevette.
August  – Vigdís Finnbogadóttir becomes the 4th President of Iceland, the world's first democratically directly elected female president.
January  – Andrei Sakharov, Soviet scientist and human rights activist, is arrested in Moscow.
Steven Stayner returned home after being kidnapped for seven years, and brought a  year old, Timothy White (abduction victim), who had been kidnapped after Steven, to a police station to save him.
June  – The first -hour news channel, Cable News Network (CNN), is launched.
February  – Polish Prime Minister Józef Pińkowski resigns and is replaced by General Wojciech Jaruzelski.
December  – An Inex-Adria Aviopromet McDonnell Douglas MD- strikes a mountain peak and crashes while approaching Ajaccio Airport in Corsica, killing all  people on board.
Greece enters the European Economic Community, predecessor of the European Union.
Boxing: Muhammad Ali loses to Trevor Berbick; this proves to be Ali's last-ever fight.

Aer Lingus flight  is hijacked just before landing at London Heathrow airport. The flight continues on to France before the hijacker who reportedly demanded for the releasing of the third secret of Fatima, is subdued.
March  – Argentine scrap metal workers (infiltrated by marines) raise the flag of Argentina on South Georgia and the Falkland Islands, two British overseas territories.
July  – Four Iranian diplomats are kidnapped upon Israel's invasion of Lebanon.
September  – Amine Gemayel, brother of Bachir, is elected president of Lebanon.

March  – Space Shuttle Columbia ends an eight-day mission, STS-, by landing at White Sands Space Harbor near Alamogordo, New Mexico. It was the only time a Space Shuttle has landed at White Sands. The orbiter was forced to land at White Sands due to flooding at its originally planned landing site, Edwards Air Force Base in California.
Lebanese President-elect Bachir Gemayel is assassinated in Beirut.

The Venezuelan bolívar is devalued and exchange controls are established in an event now referred to as Black Friday by many Venezuelans (the Bolívar had been the most stable and internationally accepted currency).
Heavy rain and mudslides in western Shimane Prefecture, Japan, kill .
April  – Spain's Seve Ballesteros won the 47th PGA Masters Tournament.
June – – The  Cricket World Cup is held in England with India defeating West Indies in the final.

February  –  women protest in Lahore, Pakistan, against military dictator Zia-ul-Haq's proposed Law of Evidence. The women are tear-gassed, baton-charged and thrown into lock-up but are successful in repealing the law.
Aboard the Space Shuttle Challenger, astronaut Kathryn D. Sullivan becomes the first American woman to perform a space walk.

Four African-American youths (Barry Allen, Troy Canty, James Ramseur, and Darrell Cabey) board an express train in the Bronx borough of New York City. They demand five dollars from Bernhard Goetz, who shoots them. The event starts a national debate about urban crime in the United States.
June  – -year-old Ricky Kasso murders Gary Lauwers in Northport, New York, contributing to the Satanic panic association of heavy metal music and satanism.
Uruguayan presidential election: Julio María Sanguinetti is democratically elected President of Uruguay after  years of military dictatorship.
June  – Hayim Association is founded by Prof. Rina Zaizov Marx and parents of children with cancer as paediatric oncology department in Israel.

April  – Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation, and Japan Tobacco and Salt Public Corporation, are privatized and change their names to Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, and Japan Tobacco, respectively.
Africa has a population growth of . percent per year.
Soviet–Afghan War: The Soviet Union begins to transfer the burden of fighting the mujahideen to the armed forces of the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan, a cause of the Revolutions of .
The Plaza Accord is signed by five nations.

November 
Palace of Justice siege: Members of the 19th of April Movement (M-) Marxist guerrilla group take over the Palace of Justice of Colombia in Bogotá and hold the Supreme Court hostage. Hours later, after a military raid, the incident leaves almost half of the  Supreme Court Justices dead.
The Argentine tourist village of Villa Epecuén is permanently flooded through the collapse of a dam and dyke.
Hands Across America: At least ,, people form a human chain from New York City to Long Beach, California, to raise money to fight hunger and homelessness.
July  – In London, the then Prince Andrew, Duke of York (later Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor) marries Sarah Ferguson at Westminster Abbey.
January  – The United Kingdom and France announce plans to construct the Channel Tunnel.
April  –  Berlin discotheque bombing: The West Berlin discothèque La Belle, a known hangout for United States soldiers, is bombed, killing three and injuring ; Libya is held responsible.

February 
Anti-Duvalier protest movement: President Jean-Claude Duvalier ("Baby Doc") flees Haiti, ending  years of family rule.
The snap presidential election in the Philippines earlier announced by President Ferdinand Marcos is held amidst controversy, that paves the way for a chain of protests, culminating in the People Power Revolution.
July  – Salvage dives begin on the wreck of the Titanic; survivor Eva Hart likens the salvage teams to "vultures."
July  – Martial law in Taiwan ends after  years.
The Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty is signed in Washington, D.C. by U.S. President Ronald Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. It expired in .
June  – During a visit to Berlin, Germany, U.S. President Ronald Reagan challenges Soviet general secretary Mikhail Gorbachev to tear down the Berlin Wall.
September – – The world's first conference on artificial life is held at Los Alamos National Laboratory in the United States.

November  – The United States Vice-president and Republican nominee George H. W. Bush defeats the Democratic nominee and Governor of Massachusetts, Michael Dukakis, in the  United States Presidential Election.
The first World AIDS Day is held.

February  – Start of Anfal campaign, a genocidal counterinsurgency operation within the Iran–Iraq War carried out by Ba'athist Iraqi forces led by Ali Hassan al-Majid on the orders of President Saddam Hussein that will kill between , and , Kurds in Iraqi Kurdistan.
A cyclone in Bangladesh leaves  million homeless and thousands dead.
June  – NASA scientist James Hansen testifies to the U.S. Senate that human-made global warming has begun, becoming one of the first environmentalists to warn of the problem.

November 
The President of Nicaragua ends a ceasefire with U.S.-backed contras that has been in effect since April .
The border between East Germany and Czechoslovakia is reopened.
Walmart posts revenues and profits triple its  figures and rivals Kmart and Sears in importance in the American market.

February 
The state funeral of Emperor Shōwa (Hirohito) in Tokyo is attended by leaders and representatives of  nations.
The Satanic Verses controversy: Iran places a $,, bounty on the head of The Satanic Verses author Salman Rushdie.
Singing Revolution: After  years, the Estonian flag is raised at the Pikk Hermann tower in Tallinn.
United Airlines Flight , a Boeing , suffers uncontrolled decompression after leaving Honolulu International Airport; nine passengers are blown out of the cabin to their deaths.
The Satanic Verses controversy: Iran places a $,, bounty on the head of The Satanic Verses author Salman Rushdie.
The communist Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party votes to reorganise itself as a socialist party, to be named the Hungarian Socialist Party.
Pope John Paul II begins an eight-day tour of Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mali, Burkina Faso, and Chad.
Somali President Siad Barre's bodyguards massacre anti-government demonstrators during a soccer match;  people are killed, more than  seriously injured.
February/March – , Kashmiri Pandits leave their homeland in Jammu and Kashmir's Valley after being targeted by Islamist extremists.
January  – Four months after their exit from power, the Polish United Workers' Party votes to dissolve and reorganize as the Social Democracy of the Republic of Poland.

December 
Channel Tunnel workers from the United Kingdom and France meet  metres beneath the English Channel seabed, establishing the first land connection between Great Britain and the mainland of Europe for around , years.
President of Chad Hissène Habré is deposed by the Patriotic Salvation Movement and replaced as president by its leader Idriss Déby.
April  – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq declares some of its chemical weapons and materials to the UN, as required by Resolution , and claims that it does not have a biological weapons program.
In the U.S., telephone services go down in Washington, D.C., Pittsburgh, Los Angeles, and San Francisco as a result of a software bug, affecting nearly  million customers.
In the Bangladeshi general election, the Bangladesh Nationalist Party wins  of  seats in the Jatiyo Sangshad, leading BNP leader Khaleda Zia to become the prime minister of Bangladesh on March .
February  – Gulf War: At  a.m. local time ground troops cross the Saudi Arabian border and enter Kuwait, thus starting the ground phase of the war.

Space Shuttle Atlantis leaves an observatory in Earth's orbit to study gamma rays before returning on April . It is followed by Space Shuttle Discovery, which studies instruments related to the Strategic Defense Initiative from April  to May . Space Shuttle Columbia carries the Spacelab into orbit on June .

In a national referendum related to abortion, voters in Ireland reject the proposed Twelfth Amendment of the Constitution Bill  but approve the Thirteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland and the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland.

July 
Georgia becomes the 179th member of the United Nations after seceding from the Soviet Union the previous year.
Thai Airways International Flight , an Airbus A310-, crashes into a mountain north of Kathmandu, Nepal killing all  people on board.
China General Aviation Flight  bound for Xiamen crashes soon after taking off from Nanjing Dajiaochang Airport, killing  of the  people on board.
Georgia becomes the 179th member of the United Nations after seceding from the Soviet Union the previous year.
July  – The Slovak National Council declares Slovakia an independent country, signaling the breakup of Czechoslovakia.

June 
Two German relief workers held since , Thomas Kemptner and Heinrich Struebig, are handed over to the German authorities after their release; they are the last Western hostages in Lebanon.
Violence breaks out between the African National Congress and the Inkatha Freedom Party in Boipatong, South Africa, leaving  dead.
March  – The 65th Academy Awards, hosted by Billy Crystal, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, with Unforgiven winning Best Picture.
November  – Jean Chrétien becomes the 20th Prime Minister of Canada.
April  – Tennis player Monica Seles – at this time the top-ranked player in women's tennis – is stabbed during a match at the  Citizen Cup in Hamburg, Germany.
June  – UK mathematician Andrew Wiles wins worldwide fame after presenting his proof of Fermat's Last Theorem, a problem that had been unsolved for more than three centuries.
The Hungarian Parliament elects Péter Boross Prime Minister of Hungary following the death of József Antall on December .
July  – Rwandan Patriotic Front troops capture Kigali, a major breakthrough in the Rwandan Civil War.
July – – Fragments of Comet Shoemaker–Levy  impact the planet Jupiter.
April  – Kurt Cobain, the lead singer of Nirvana. commits suicide at the age of  at his home in Seattle. His body was found three days later.

November 
"Republican Revolution": Georgia Representative Newt Gingrich leads the United States Republican Party in taking control of both the House of Representatives and the Senate in midterm congressional elections, the first time in  years the Republicans secure control of both houses of Congress. George W. Bush is elected Governor of Texas.
Hurricane Gordon hits Central America, Jamaica, Cuba, the Bahamas, Haiti and the Southeastern United States, causing $ million in damages and , fatalities.
Mascara earthquake: a . earthquake leaves  dead in Algeria.
May  – Jacques Chirac is elected president of France.
February  – The Amazon Cooperation Treaty Organization (ACTO) (Organización del Tratado de Cooperación Amazónica [OTCA]) is formed.

March 
Julio María Sanguinetti is sworn in as President of Uruguay for his second term.
Polish Prime Minister Waldemar Pawlak resigns from Parliament and is replaced by ex-communist Józef Oleksy.
Participants in the Yugoslav Wars begin negotiations at the Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio.
August  – Eduard Shevardnadze, the Georgian head of state, survives an assassination attempt in Tbilisi.
January  – Ryutaro Hashimoto, leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, becomes Prime Minister of Japan.

April  – The Israeli government launches Operation Grapes of Wrath, consisting of massive attacks on Lebanon, in retaliation for "terrorist attacks", and sparking off a violent series of retaliations.
February  – Two suicide bombs in Israel kill  and injure ; Hamas claims responsibility.
Costas Simitis is elected president of the Panhellenic Socialist Movement of Greece.
NASA launches the Mars Global Surveyor.
March  – In Sri Lanka, the Tamil Tigers overrun a military base and kill over  Sri Lankan troops.
October  – Luke Woodham walks into Pearl High School in Pearl, Mississippi and opens fire, killing two girls, after killing his mother earlier that morning.
First Congo War ends when president Mobutu Sese Seko is exiled from Zaire.

June 
Socialist Party-led Centre-left coalition won the second-round in  French legislative elections, began with the third Cohabitation (–).
Hugo Banzer wins the Presidential elections in Bolivia.

September 
Garuda Indonesia Flight  crashes while on approach to Medan, North Sumatra, during the  Southeast Asian haze, killing all  people on board. This becomes the deadliest aviation accident in Indonesian history.
An earthquake strikes the Italian regions of Umbria and Marche, causing part of the Basilica of St. Francis at Assisi to collapse.
June  – Philippine Vice President Joseph Estrada is sworn in as the 13th President of the Philippines.
A second nuclear test, codenamed Chagai-II, is conducted and supervised by the Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission (PAEC).
May  – The United States requests that El Salvador reopen its probe into the  murders of U.S. missionaries.
December  – The U.S. House of Representatives forwards articles of impeachment against President Clinton to the Senate, making him the second president to be impeached in U.S. history.
May  – The Department of Justice files an antitrust lawsuit against Microsoft, alleging its Windows operating system unfairly takes market share from Netscape's Navigator.
July  – MLB Pitcher David Cone of the New York Yankees, throws the 16th perfect game in Major League Baseball history.
Rwandan Hutu rebels kill and dismember eight foreign tourists at the Buhoma homestead, Uganda.
EgyptAir Flight , travelling from New York City to Cairo, crashes off the coast of Nantucket, Massachusetts killing all  on board.
Kargil War: The Indian Air Force launches an attack on intruding Pakistan Army troops and mujahideen militants in Kashmir.

Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif attempts to dismiss Army Chief General Pervez Musharraf, who is out of the country. The generals lead a coup d'état, ousting Sharif's administration, and Musharraf takes control of the government.
September  – The last wholly Swedish-owned arms manufacturer, Bofors, is sold to American arms manufacturer United Defense.
November  – The United States recognizes the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.

August  – The Russian submarine Kursk sinks in the Barents Sea during one of the largest Russian naval exercises since the  dissolution of the Soviet Union, resulting in the deaths of all  men on board.
Soyuz TM- is launched, carrying the first resident crew to the International Space Station. The ISS has been continuously crewed since.
January  – America Online announces an agreement to purchase Time Warner for $ billion (the largest-ever corporate merger).
: Ancient Egypt: Pharaoh Mentuhotep IV died. End of Eleventh Dynasty. Pharaoh Amenemhat I started to rule. Start of Twelfth Dynasty.
The Harappa Torso was sculpted by a member of the Indus Valley culture.
– : "Harvest scene", tempera facsimile by Nina de Garis Davies of wall painting in the tomb of Khnumhotep II, Beni Hasan. Twelfth Dynasty.
"Hippopotamus", from the tomb of Senbi (governor) (Tomb B.) at Meir was made. Twelfth Dynasty. It is now in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
: Pharaoh Mentuhotep II, Eleventh dynasty of Egypt dies.
March  – Despite pleas from the international community to spare them, the Taliban government of Afghanistan begins destroying the Buddhas of Bamiyan, having declared that they are idols.

January 
Taba Summit: Talks between Israel and the Palestinian National Authority begin in Egypt.
Pope John Paul II names  cardinals in one day for a total of .
October  – United States invasion of Afghanistan: In response to the September  attacks, Afghanistan is invaded by a US-led coalition, beginning the War in Afghanistan.
G wireless technology first becomes available when it is adopted by Japanese telecommunications company NTT Docomo.
January  – Wikipedia, which became the world's largest encyclopedia, is launched.
May  – NASA launches the Aqua satellite as part of the Earth Observing System.

May  – Timor-Leste independence: East Timor regains its independence as the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste after . years of United Nations administration and  years of Indonesian occupation since .
The Church of England allows divorcees to remarry.

June  –  FIFA World Cup: Brazil beats Germany – in the  FIFA World Cup Final with Ronaldo scoring the two goals; Brazil's captain Cafu, who becomes the first player to appear in three successive World Cup finals, accepts the trophy on behalf of the team.
May  – United States President George W. Bush and Russian President Vladimir Putin sign the Strategic Offensive Reductions Treaty.
The Beagle  Mars lander deploys, but contact is lost.
February  – At the conclusion of the STS- mission, the Space Shuttle Columbia disintegrates during reentry over Texas, killing all seven astronauts on board.
December  – Trial of Stanislav Galić: The International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia sentences Stanislav Galić to  years in prison for crimes against humanity.
January  – The last signal from NASA's Pioneer  spacecraft is received, some . billion kilometers (. billion mi) from Earth.
October  – Israeli warplanes strike alleged Islamic jihad bases inside Syrian territory, the first Israeli attack on the country since the  Yom Kippur War.
The European Union expands by  new member states: Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia, and Slovenia.
May  –  Adjara crisis: Aslan Abashidze goes into exile in Moscow, leaving Adjara to come under Georgian government control.
October  – A team of explorers reach the bottom of Krubera Cave, the world's deepest cave, with a depth of , meters (, feet).
Mark Zuckerberg launches "TheFacebook", later renamed to Facebook, a social networking website for Harvard University students.
May  – Royal Tongan Airlines ceases operations.
Former Lebanese Prime Minister Rafic Hariri is assassinated, along with  others, by a suicide bomber in Beirut.

February 
Former Lebanese Prime Minister Rafic Hariri is assassinated, along with  others, by a suicide bomber in Beirut.
YouTube, an American online video sharing and social media platform was founded by Steve Chen, Chad Hurley, and Jawed Karim headquartered in San Bruno, California.
Rosa Parks dies of natural causes.
May – – The Eurovision Song Contest  takes place in Kyiv, Ukraine, and is won by Greek entrant Helena Paparizou with the song "My Number One".

November 
Angela Merkel assumes office as the first female Chancellor of Germany.
Microsoft releases the Xbox .
February  – Stephen Harper is sworn in as the Prime Minister of Canada.
September  – The Royal Thai Army overthrows the government of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra in a coup.
August  – News was revealed of a thwarted terrorist plot to detonate liquid explosives disguised as soft drinks, aboard multiple transatlantic air flights.

March 
NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter enters orbit around Mars.
Michelle Bachelet becomes the first female president of Chile.
December  – The Juraj Dobrila University of Pula is established.
October  – Montenegro adopts a new constitution, which among other things changes the country's official name from "Republic of Montenegro" to "Montenegro".
December  – The Treaty of Lisbon is signed by members states of European Union.
May  –  French presidential election: Nicolas Sarkozy is elected President of France in the second round.
June  – Gordon Brown succeeds Tony Blair and becomes Prime Minister of the United Kingdom after a leadership election.
November  –  Australian federal election: The Labor Party led by Kevin Rudd defeats the Liberal/National Coalition government led by Prime Minister John Howard. Rudd would be sworn in on December .
July  – Riots erupt in Mongolia in response to allegations of fraud surrounding the  legislative elections.
March  – An Energy release of a Gamma-ray burst called the GRB 080319B is the brightest event ever recorded in the Universe.
September  – A train collision occurred in Chatsworth, California, when a Metrolink train and Union Pacific local collided head-on.
An earthquake measuring . on the moment magnitude scale strikes Sichuan, China, killing an estimated , people.
European Certification and Qualification Association is founded.
September  – The Dubai Metro, the first urban train network in the Arabian Peninsula, officials opens.
October  – Microsoft releases Windows  to all computers and laptops, including an edition for ATMs.
The first trial at the International Criminal Court opens. Former Union of Congolese Patriots leader Thomas Lubanga Dyilo is accused of training child soldiers to kill, pillage and rape.
June  – Yemenia Flight  crashes off the coast of Moroni, Comoros, killing all but one of the  passengers and crew.

June  – The death of American pop star Michael Jackson triggers an outpouring of worldwide grief. Online, reactions to the event cripple several major websites and services, as the abundance of people accessing the web addresses pushes internet traffic to unprecedented and historic levels.
August  –  Australian federal election: Julia Gillard's Labor government is re-elected, narrowly defeating the Liberal/National Coalition led by Tony Abbott.
November  – Participants of the  NATO Lisbon summit issue the Lisbon Summit Declaration.
December  – The attempted suicide of Mohamed Bouazizi, a street vendor in Tunisia, triggers the Tunisian Revolution and the wider Arab Spring throughout the Arab world.

July  – WikiLeaks, an online publisher of anonymous, covert, and classified material, leaks to the public over , internal reports about the United States-led involvement in the War in Afghanistan from  to .

September  – Anonymous initiates Operation Payback, a coordinated cyberattack on multiple corporations, law firms, and politicians over the banning of file-sharing websites such as LimeWire and The Pirate Bay and also the politicians and financial institutions against WikiLeaks, a whistleblower website.

March 
Egypt’s Ministry of Interior dissolves the widely feared and hated State Security Investigations Service accused of human rights abuses and announced the establishment of the new National Security Agency will replace it and take over its internal security duties.
Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa, King of Bahrain, declares a three-month state of emergency as troops from the Gulf Co-operation Council are sent to quell the civil unrest.
Protests breakout across Syria demanding democratic reforms, resignation of President Bashar al-Assad, and release of those imprisoned for the March  Daraa protest. The government responds by killing hundreds of protesters and laying siege to various cities, beginning the Syrian Civil War, which lasts until Assad’s overthrow in .
July – – Two frontal systems enter south-central Chile causing great snowfalls that leaves thousand of people isolated.
June  – A riot broke out in Vancouver, British Columbia in the aftermath of the Boston Bruins' win over the Vancouver Canucks in game seven of the  Stanley Cup Finals
May  – Grímsvötn, Iceland's most active volcano, erupts and causes disruption to air travel in Northwestern Europe.
September  – Snapchat was launched.
October  – North Kalimantan is established as the 34th province of Indonesia.

December  –  phenomenon: End of 13th b'ak'tun in the Mayan calendar, supposed end of the world according to new age beliefs. Festivities took place to commemorate the event in the countries that were part of the Maya civilization (Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador), with main events at Chichén Itzá in Mexico and Tikal in Guatemala.
June  – The Congress of Paraguay approves the impeachment of president Fernando Lugo.

June  – Shenzhou , a Chinese spacecraft carrying three Chinese astronauts, including the first-ever female, docks manually with orbiting module Tiangong-, making this the third country, after the United States and Russia, successfully to perform the mission.
October  – Seven paintings worth $ million are stolen from the Kunsthal in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.
July – – XIV World Youth Day, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

The largest tornado ever recorded hits El Reno, United States. This rain-wrapped, multiple-vortex tornado was the widest tornado ever recorded, and results in eight deaths, including four storm-chasers. Measurements from mobile weather radars revealed extreme winds up to  mph ( km/h) within the vortex, among the highest observed wind speeds on Earth. As it crosses U.S. , the tornado grows to a record-breaking width of . miles (. km).
September  – Grand Theft Auto V earns more than half a billion dollars on its first day of release.
November  – The uncrewed Mars Orbiter Mission is launched by India from its launch pad in Sriharikota.
January  –  Craig, Alaska earthquake: A Mw . (Ms ., 'Moderate') earthquake shakes Prince of Wales Island.
July  – Germany defeats Argentina - to win the  FIFA World Cup.
February – The West African Ebola virus epidemic begins, infecting at least , people and killing at least , people, the most severe both in terms of numbers of infections and casualties.
Crimean status referendum: A disputed referendum on the status of the Crimean Peninsula is held.
May  – The self-proclaimed Luhansk People's Republic declares its independence from Ukraine.
Boko Haram militants kill approximately  people in a night attack on Gamboru Ngala in Nigeria.
May  – ISIS captures the ancient city of Palmyra in Syria.
September –October  – The  Rugby World Cup is held in England and is won by New Zealand who beat Australia in the final.
January  – After Houthi forces seize the presidential palace, Yemeni President Abd Rabbuh Mansur Hadi resigns after months of unrest.
February –March  – The  Cricket World Cup is held in Australia and New Zealand with Australia defeating New Zealand in the final.
November  – In Mariana, Minas Gerais, Brazil, a tailings dam of iron ore collapses, causing  deaths and releasing a toxic mudflow to pollute the Doce River.
Global CO2 levels exceed  ppm at the time of year normally associated with minimum levels. A  ppm level is believed to be higher than anything experienced in human history.
May  – EgyptAir Flight  crashes into the Mediterranean Sea en route from Paris to Cairo, killing all  people on board.
October  – Hurricane Matthew makes landfall in Haiti as a category  hurricane, killing  and causing $. billion in damages.
October  –  nations meet at the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) summit in Rwanda and agree to phase out hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) as an amendment to the Montreal Protocol.
May  – The 100th Indianapolis  is held and is won by rookie Alexander Rossi.
June  – The Grenfell Tower Fire in West London claims the lives of  residents, making it the worst UK residential fire since World War II.

September – – Just two weeks after Hurricane Irma struck the Caribbean, Hurricane Maria strikes similar areas, making landfall on Dominica as a Category  hurricane, and Puerto Rico as a Category  hurricane. Maria caused over , deaths and damages estimated in excess of $. billion ( USD).
The UN Security Council unanimously approves fresh sanctions on North Korean trade and investment.

June  – Two terrorist attacks are simultaneously carried out by five Islamic State (ISIL) terrorists against the Iranian Parliament building and the Mausoleum of Ruhollah Khomeini, both in Tehran, leaving  civilians dead and  more wounded.
September  – Cassini–Huygens ends its -year mission by plunging into Saturn, becoming the first spacecraft to enter the planet's atmosphere.
September  – Hydrail train enters service on the Buxtehude-Bremervörde-Bremerhaven-Cuxhaven line in Lower Saxony, Germany.
Eleven people are killed during the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting.
July  – France national football team wins the  FIFA World Cup final – against the Croatia national football team
August  –  year old Swedish pupil Greta Thunberg starts to stay out of school in an attempt to give attention to the climate change issue.
December  – The U.N.'s International Telecommunication Union reports that, by the end of , more than half – a full . percent – of the world's population are now using the Internet.
November  –  Fada N'Gourma attack: At least  people are killed and  others injured when gunmen attack a Canadian gold mining company convoy on a road in Burkina Faso.
May  – U.S. President Donald Trump, during an official state visit to Japan, becomes the first foreign leader to meet with Japanese emperor Naruhito.
October  –  soldiers are killed and  missing following attacks on two army camps in Boulkessi and Mondoro, Mali.

November  –  Busy Bee crash: A plane crashes shortly after takeoff in a densely populated area of Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, killing all  people on board and at least  more on the ground.

August  –  Beirut drone crash: According to Lebanese officials, two Israeli drones attack Beirut, Lebanon. One crashed into the roof of the Hezbollah Media Center, about  minutes before the second exploded in the air and damaged the building. It is the first such incident between Israel and Lebanon since the  Lebanon War.
November  – COVID- pandemic: The Sputnik V vaccine is proven to be % effective against COVID- according to interim results.

May  – A team of British and Kenyan scientists announce the discovery of Microsporidia MB, a parasitic microbe in the Microsporidia fungi group that blocks mosquitos from carrying malaria, potentially paving the way for the control of malaria.
Colombia formalizes its membership with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), becoming the 37th nation of the organization.

Barquisimeto shooting: During a demonstration, pro-government colectivos shoot at disputed President and Speaker of the National Assembly Juan Guaidó and his supporters in Barquisimeto, Venezuela, leaving five injured.

January 
The  Peruvian parliamentary election is held to elect all  members of the Congress of the Republic of Peru.
 Calabasas helicopter crash: Nine people killed in accident in Calabasas, California, including retired basketball player Kobe Bryant and his daughter Gianna; cause later attributed to heavy fog.
SpaceX launches the Crew- mission, carrying four crew members of Expedition  and  to the International Space Station aboard Crew Dragon Endeavour.
April  – Albania holds parliamentary elections.
Hualien train derailment: In Taiwan, a Taroko Express train collided with a truck that rolled down a slope and derailed, resulting in  deaths and  injuries.

May 
A coup d'état in Mali removes interim president Bah Ndaw and the acting prime minister, Moctar Ouane, from power and restores military rule leading to the country being suspended from the Economic Community of West African States and the African Union, as well as France suspending its military operations in the country.
The Government of Guillermo Lasso is formed in Ecuador.
Microsoft releases the desktop operating system Windows .
France takes over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union, after the Slovenian presidency.

April  – The second round of voting of the  East Timorese presidential election is held and the National Congress for Timorese Reconstruction party presidential candidate, former president and former prime minister José Ramos-Horta is elected.
December  – Leo Varadkar succeeds Micheál Martin as Taoiseach (Prime Minister) of Ireland, as part of a rotation agreement made in .
July  – July  – The  World Games is held in Birmingham, Alabama, United States.

March 
 South Korean presidential election: People Power Party candidate Yoon Suk-yeol is narrowly elected President of South Korea.
Russian invasion of Ukraine: Russia is condemned by world leaders following an air strike in Mariupol that destroys a hospital including a maternity and children's ward.
July  – SAG-AFTRA announces it will begin a strike against the major film and TV studios in protest of low compensation, ownership of work, and generative AI.
June  – The United Nations Security Council votes unanimously to end MINUSMA, its peacekeeping mission in Mali.
Kivu conflict: Angola announces the deployment of troops to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, following the failure of a ceasefire between government forces and M23 rebels in North Kivu.

March 
The  Chinese presidential election is held with the National People's Congress unanimously re-electing Xi Jinping as the President of the People's Republic of China to an unprecedented third term.
Iran and Saudi Arabia agree to resume diplomatic relations which were severed in , at talks mediated by China.
Silicon Valley Bank, the 16th largest bank in the United States, fails, creating then the largest bank failure since the  financial crisis, affecting companies around the world.
Kivu conflict: Angola announces the deployment of troops to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, following the failure of a ceasefire between government forces and M23 rebels in North Kivu.
April  – Two document leaks from the Pentagon detailing foreign military aid relating to the Russian invasion of Ukraine are leaked onto the Internet.
October  –  Mozambican general election: Daniel Chapo is elected president while the ruling FRELIMO party retains a majority in the Assembly of the Republic.

October 
The  Kazakh nuclear power referendum is held and approved.
 Tunisian presidential election: Incumbent Kais Saied is reelected for a second term.

November 
The  Gabonese constitutional referendum is held and approved.
French-Algerian dissident writer Boualem Sansal is put in custody by Algerian authorities after his landing in Algiers.
Croatian parliamentary election: Incumbent Prime Minister Andrej Plenković's Croatian Democratic Union coalition wins a plurality of seats.

December  –  Romanian presidential election: The Constitutional Court of Romania annuls the results of the first round, amid accusations of Russian interference after the unexpected advancement of pro-Russian candidate Călin Georgescu to the runoff.
September  – At least  people are killed and over  are injured after the Glória funicular derailment in the centre of Lisbon, Portugal.

January 
Poland takes over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union, after the Hungarian presidency.
Bulgaria and Romania complete the process of joining the Schengen Area, lifting land border controls.
Liechtenstein becomes the 37th country to legalize same-sex marriage.
Ukraine halts the transportation of many Russian gas supplies through the country following the expiration of a five-year transit deal, while also becoming a state party in the International Criminal Court.
Fifteen people (including the perpetrator) are killed and  others are injured during a vehicle-ramming and shooting attack in New Orleans, Louisiana, United States.
Thirteen people are killed and  more injured in a shooting in Cetinje, Montenegro.
South Korea experiences one of its worst wildfires in modern history; over   hectares of land are destroyed in South Gyeongsang Province, killing at least  people.
January  – Gaza war: A ceasefire goes into effect, lasting until an Israeli surprise attack on  March.
May – – The Eurovision Song Contest  is held in Basel, Switzerland. Austrian contestant JJ wins with the song "Wasted Love".
August  – The  Estonian presidential election is scheduled to be held.
October  – If not triggered earlier, the  Israeli legislative election will be held no later than this date.
February  – The  Costa Rican general election is scheduled to be held.
January  – The United States seizes two shadow fleet tankers, including one under a Russian flag, in the United States oil blockade during Operation Southern Spear.
The  Cape Verdean parliamentary election is scheduled to be held.

In Chalcolithic Europe, the two circles of bluestones that form the inner part of Stonehenge are erected.
Shahr-e Sukhteh, "The Burnt City" in Persia, is abandoned.
Late spring  – Seahenge is built in Britain.

: By this time, kings in Sumer have ceased to be automatically high priests of the city deity. (Roux ) Infiltration and conquest of Mesopotamia by ancient Semitic-speaking peoples begins. ( RD Almanac)

Mesannepada, who has already dominated the city of Nippur, takes advantage of an eclipse of power in Kish (caused by an incursion by the Elamites of Awan) to seize the city. He becomes the ruler of all of Lower Mesopotamia as he becomes the king of Kish, and his name appears on a pearl in Mari.
: Reign of Akalamdug, king of Ur.

Reign of Mesilim, king of Kish. He was an apparent suzerain over the Lagash king Luga-shag-engur and the Adab king Nin-kisalsi. A conflict between Lagash and the neighboring Umma begins over fields claimed by each of the parties. An initial crisis is settled by Mesilim in favor of Lagash.
Reign of A'annepada, king of Ur.
End of the Early Dynastic I Period, and the beginning of the Early Dynastic II Period in Mesopotamia.
Earliest records of oil wrestling from Babylonia and Egypt.
Abandonment of the Mature Harappan settlement at Kalibangan in India due to the drying-up of the Ghaggar River.
Supposed reign of the semi-legendary Sumerian king Gilgamesh.
–: Early Dynastic II Period in Mesopotamia.
: Estimated ending of the Cucuteni-Trypillian culture in the region of modern-day Romania, Moldova, and southwestern Ukraine.
Second Dynasty wars in Ancient Egypt.
– : Seated Harp Player, from Keros, Cyclades, is made. It is now at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
The beginning of the period of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors in China.
Estimated germination of the oldest living tree and organism on earth as of  the Methuselah Tree, the second-oldest known organism. Sprouting in what would become Inyo County, California.
– : Votive statues from the Square Temple of Eshnunna (modern Tell Ashmar, Iraq) were made. One of them is now in the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago. Excavated –.

: The oldest currently living organism, a Great Basin bristlecone pine, undergoes germination in the White Mountains of California.
: Narmer (Menes) unifies Upper and Lower Egypt into one country; he rules this new country from Memphis.

An earthquake near a Neolithic culture at Sotira in Cyprus destroys much of the local infrastructure.
The Post Track, an ancient causeway in the Somerset Levels, England, is built, c. . It is one of the oldest engineered roads discovered in Northern Europe.

The Sweet Track, an ancient causeway also in the Somerset Levels, the oldest timber trackway discovered in Northern Europe, is built in  or ; tree-ring dating (dendrochronology) enabled very precise dating.
